item.description: [#635] Dear Peter Wiggin: This letter is to inform you that you have received enough upvotes on your reddit comments to become president of the world. Please be at the UN tomorrow at 8:00 sharp.

item.title: Brontosaurus
item.description: [#636] Well, sex is like a velociraptor: despite your movie-fueled lifelong neurotic obsession, unlikely to be found in your house.

item.title: Scribblenauts
item.description: [#637] Let me look away and type 'guy who's just jealous that I beat all his MarioKart times' and turn back, and ... yup, there you are again!

item.title: The Search
item.description: [#638] I am so excited about the Kepler mission. This is the second most important thing our species has ever done, right behind inventing the concept of delivery pizza.

item.title: Lincoln-Douglas
item.description: [#639] Stephen Douglas actually died soon after the debates and election, but if you demand historical accuracy in your webcomics you should be reading Hark! A Vagrant.

item.title: Tornado Hunter
item.description: [#640] The Fujita Scale was replaced by the Enhanced Fujita Scale in 2007, but I think 'EF-5' sounds stupid, so I vote we just use the new measurements for assigning numbers but still call them 'F-whatever'.

item.title: Free
item.description: [#641] Asbestos is bad; definitely get the one on the right. Wait -- this one over here has no swine flu! Now I can't decide.

item.title: Creepy
item.description: [#642] And I even got out my adorable new netbook!

item.title: Ohm
item.description: [#643] More generally, with great power comes great dEnergy/dt.

item.title: Surgery
item.description: [#644] Damn. Not only did he not install it, he sutured a 'Vista-Ready' sticker onto my arm.

item.title: RPS
item.description: [#645] It looks good, but it needs more postfixins.

item.title: Conversations
item.description: [#646] If the dysentery graph looks historically inaccurate it's because I got all my data from Oregon Trail.

item.title: Scary
item.description: [#647] I'm teaching every 8-year-old relative to say this, and every 14-year-old to do the same thing with Toy Story. Also, Pokemon hit the US over a decade ago and kids born after Aladdin came out will turn 18 next year.

item.title: Fall Foliage
item.description: [#648] And I could replace you with older pictures of you, from back when you looked happy.

item.title: Static
item.description: [#649] I firmly believe that nothing can go wrong on a project if you're wearing one of those wrist things.

item.title: Nowhere
item.description: [#650] I mean, seriously, NOWHERE? For starters, there are like a thousand species of dinosaur.

item.title: Bag Check
item.description: [#651] A laptop battery contains roughly the stored energy of a hand grenade, and if shorted it ... hey! You can't arrest me if I prove your rules inconsistent!

item.title: More Accurate
item.description: [#652] We live in a world where there are actual fleets of robot assassins patrolling the skies. At some point there, we left the present and entered the future.

item.title: So Bad It's Worse
item.description: [#653] You think it's so legendarily bad that you'll torrent it and sit through it just for the kitschy nerd cred. I, too, once thought as you did.

item.title: Nachos
item.description: [#654] 'Cheater!' 'Hey, gaming on wifi? You have only yourself to blame.'

item.title: Climbing
item.description: [#655] Where did you even get this wall? Return it there and stand it back up right now.

item.title: October 30th
item.description: [#656] Not enough houses on your block? Just hit them at 30-year intervals from here to 2300 and get 10x the candy.

item.title: Movie Narrative Charts
item.description: [#657] In the LotR map, up and down correspond LOOSELY to northwest and southeast respectively.

item.title: Orbitals
item.description: [#658] Except the people filtering in late are the partiers, so you end up with drunken makeouts in the living room and the next roommate to return home has to sleep in the hall lounge orbital.

item.title: Lego
item.description: [#659] Dad, where is Grandpa right now?

item.title: Sympathy
item.description: [#660] Excellent recovery: ... which we could try to use to somehow save your original brother!

item.title: Two-Party System
item.description: [#661] I favor approval voting or IRV chiefly because they mean we might get to bring back The Bull Moose party.

item.title: iPhone or Droid
item.description: [#662] It may be a fundamentally empty experience, but holy crap the Droid's 265 ppi screen is amazing.

item.title: Sagan-Man
item.description: [#663] They laugh now, but within 10 years the city's entire criminal class will have quit to work on space research.

item.title: Academia vs. Business
item.description: [#664] Some engineer out there has solved P=NP and it's locked up in an electric eggbeater calibration routine. For every 0x5f375a86 we learn about, there are thousands we never see.

item.title: Prudence
item.description: [#665] Moments later, the White Witch rolls up and, confused, tries to tempt the probe with a firmware upgrade.

item.title: Silent Hammer
item.description: [#666] I bet he'll keep quiet for a couple weeks and then-- wait, did you nail a piece of scrap wood to my antique table a moment ago?

item.title: SkiFree
item.description: [#667] And from that day on, I wore this little 'F' key pendant everywhere I went.

item.title: Pandora
item.description: [#668] What? Oh, no, the 'Enchanted' soundtrack was just playing because Pandora's algorithms are terrible. [silence] ... (quietly) That's how you knooooooow ...

item.title: Experiment
item.description: [#669] The other two are still lost on the infinite plane of uniform density.

item.title: Spinal Tap Amps
item.description: [#670] Wow, that's less than $200 per ... uh ... that's a good deal!

item.title: Stephen and Me
item.description: [#671] Hey, let go! We were all thinking it! Someone had to speak truth to power!

item.title: Suggestions
item.description: [#672] An hour later: SUGGESTION: LICK HER NIPPLE MORE.

item.title: The Sun
item.description: [#673] Obligatory bad guy: This operation is sheer foolishness, and it's not happening on my watch! Mainly because I can't figure out how to adjust the time.

item.title: Natural Parenting
item.description: [#674] On one hand, every single one of my ancestors going back billions of years has managed to figure it out. On the other hand, that's the mother of all sampling biases.

item.title: Revolutionary
item.description: [#675] I mean, what's more likely -- that I have uncovered fundamental flaws in this field that no one in it has ever thought about, or that I need to read a little more? Hint: it's the one that involves less work.

item.title: Abstraction
item.description: [#676] If I'm such a god, why isn't Maru *my* cat?

item.title: Asshole
item.description: [#677] [Shortly thereafter, at a nearby bakery] ::CRASH:: ::RUMBLE:: ::VRRRRRR:: '... I don't know, officer. It just scooped up an entire rack of scones and drove away!'

item.title: Researcher Translation
item.description: [#678] A technology that is '20 years away' will be 20 years away indefinitely.

item.title: Christmas Plans
item.description: [#679] Physicists who want to protect traditional Christmas realize that the only way to keep from changing Christmas is not to observe it.

item.title: December 25th
item.description: [#680] If you're turning 27 and were born in the Northeast, maybe you were conceived in the April blizzard of 1982. Imagine: snowed in, candles, massage oil, your mom sporting nothing but her early 80's haircut and a smile ... aren't you glad you read the title-text?

item.title: Gravity Wells
item.description: [#681] This doesn't take into account the energy imparted by orbital motion (or gravity assists or the Oberth effect), all of which can make it easier to reach outer planets.

item.title: Force
item.description: [#682] Force-choking the chicken.

item.title: Science Montage
item.description: [#683] The rat's perturbed; it must sense nanobots! Code grey! We have a Helvetica scenario!

item.title: We Get It
item.description: [#684] The most brutal way I've ever seen someone handle this was 'Oh, you have a girlfriend. Are you going to get married?' 'I, uh, don't know--' 'Well, do you love her?' '...' 'Anyway, what were you saying about the movie?'

item.title: G-Spot
item.description: [#685] The BBC lead was 'The elusive erogenous zone said to exist in some women may be a myth, say researchers who have hunted for it.' I couldn't read it with a straight face.

item.title: Admin Mourning
item.description: [#686] And every day it gets harder to fight the urge to su to the user and freak people out.

item.title: Dimensional Analysis
item.description: [#687] Or the pressure at the Earth's core will rise slightly.

item.title: Self-Description
item.description: [#688] The contents of any one panel are dependent on the contents of every panel including itself. The graph of panel dependencies is complete and bidirectional, and each node has a loop. The mouseover text has two hundred and forty-two characters.

item.title: FIRST Design
item.description: [#689] Pool on the roof must've sprung a leak.

item.title: Semicontrolled Demolition
item.description: [#690] I believe the truth always lies halfway between the most extreme claims.

item.title: MicroSD
item.description: [#691] That card holds a refrigerator carton's worth of floppy discs, and a soda can full of those cards could hold the entire iTunes store's music library. Mmmm.

item.title: Dirty Harry
item.description: [#692] Sci-fi has energy weapons because otherwise the people like me who watch it get distracted counting shots.

item.title: Children's Fantasy
item.description: [#693] I was going to be a scientist, but that seems silly now. Magical worlds exist. I've learned a huge truth about our place in the universe. I'm supposed to care about college? I mean, FUCK.

item.title: Retro Virus
item.description: [#694] He says this is the year of Linux on the desktop! The world of Windows will fade any moment now!

item.title: Spirit
item.description: [#695] On January 26th, 2274 Mars days into the mission, NASA declared Spirit a 'stationary research station', expected to stay operational for several more months until the dust buildup on its solar panels forces a final shutdown.

item.title: Strip Games
item.description: [#696] HOW ABOUT A NICE GAME OF STRIP GLOBAL THERMONUCLEAR WAR?

item.title: Tensile vs. Shear Strength
item.description: [#697] Although really, the damage was done when the party planners took the hole punch to the elevator ribbon to hang up the sign.

item.title: You Hang Up First
item.description: [#698] No, YOU stumble past a series of post-breakup hookups in a daze as you slowly realize what you've lost and how unlikely you are ever to get it back first.

item.title: Trimester
item.description: [#699] Also, it's not like anyone actually calls up the Nobel committee to double-check things.

item.title: Complexion
item.description: [#700] Why do all my attempts at science end with me being punched by Batman? (P.S. benzoyl peroxide soap works great.)

item.title: Science Valentine
item.description: [#701] You don't use science to show that you're right, you use science to become right.

item.title: Snow Tracking
item.description: [#702] I suppose that's more accurately a hare dryer.

item.title: Honor Societies
item.description: [#703] Hey, why do YOU get to be the president of Tautology Clu-- wait, I can guess.

item.title: Principle of Explosion
item.description: [#704] You want me to pick up waffle cones? Oh, right, for the wine. One sec, let me just derive your son's credit card number and I'll be on my way.

item.title: Devotion to Duty
item.description: [#705] The weird sense of duty really good sysadmins have can border on the sociopathic, but it's nice to know that it stands between the forces of darkness and your cat blog's servers.

item.title: Freedom
item.description: [#706] Sometimes I'm terrified to realize how many options other people have.

item.title: Joshing
item.description: [#707] You'll be moved up from 49 of ~7 billion to 31 of ~7 billion.

item.title: Sex Dice
item.description: [#708] You roll for initiative, and ... [roll] ... wow, do you ever take it.

item.title: I Am
item.description: [#709] Great, LO-M. Do you speak Bocce? I'm supposed to find one that speaks Bocce.

item.title: Collatz Conjecture
item.description: [#710] The Strong Collatz Conjecture states that this holds for any set of obsessively-hand-applied rules.

item.title: Seismograph
item.description: [#711] The reverse only works if the subject has a nervous twitch.

item.title: Single Ladies
item.description: [#712] Using a ring to bind someone you covet into your dark and twisted world? Wow, just got the subtext there. Also, the apparently eager Beyonc would've made one badass Nazgl.

item.title: GeoIP
item.description: [#713] 'Meet hot young singles in your mom's basement today'? Man, screw you, GeoIP.

item.title: Porn For Women
item.description: [#714] Yes, there are a lot of longing looks across the bridge of Galactica first, but that's beside the point!

item.title: Numbers
item.description: [#715] The typical internet user (who wants to share) has an IQ of 147 and a 9-inch penis. Well, better than the reverse, I guess.

item.title: Time Machine
item.description: [#716] We never see any time travelers because they all discover it's a huge mistake. This is also why your friend at the lab suddenly looked about a year older recently.

item.title: Furtive
item.description: [#717] ... go go gadget video camera. Go go gadget cup.

item.title: The Flake Equation
item.description: [#718] Statistics suggest that there should be tons of alien encounter stories, and in practice there are tons of alien encounter stories. This is known as Fermi's Lack-of-a-Paradox.

item.title: Brain Worms
item.description: [#719] Hey, it says here that if you dream about your teeth falling out, it means they're spreading.

item.title: Recipes
item.description: [#720] To be fair, the braised and confused newt on a bed of crushed Doritos turned out to be delicious.

item.title: Flatland
item.description: [#721] Also, I apologize for the time I climbed down into your world and everyone freaked out about the lesbian orgy overseen by a priest.

item.title: Computer Problems
item.description: [#722] This is how I explain computer problems to my cat. My cat usually seems happier than me.

item.title: Seismic Waves
item.description: [#723] The USGS operates a really neat email/SMS earthquake notification service (earthquake.usgs.gov/ens/) that allows fine-grained control of notifications.

item.title: Hell
item.description: [#724] There's also a Katamari level where everything is just slightly bigger than you, and a Mario level with a star just out of reach.

item.title: Literally
item.description: [#725] The chemistry experiment had me figuratively -- and then shortly thereafter literally -- glued to my seat.

item.title: Seat Selection
item.description: [#726] Don't click on the wing.

item.title: Trade Expert
item.description: [#727] I mean, it's been almost twenty years. Now, it's possible you're simply embedding Windows directory paths in your URIs, but in that case you need more than just a short lecture.

item.title: iPad
item.description: [#728] Maybe we're all gonna die, but we're gonna die in *really cool ways*.

item.title: Laser Pointer
item.description: [#729] It's a lasing cat-vity!

item.title: Circuit Diagram
item.description: [#730] I just caught myself idly trying to work out what that resistor mass would actually be, and realized I had self-nerd-sniped.

item.title: Desert Island
item.description: [#731] Telescopes and bathyscaphes and sonar probes of Scottish lakes, Tacoma Narrows bridge collapse explained with abstract phase-space maps, some x-ray slides, a music score, Minard's Napoleonic war: the most exciting new frontier is charting what's already here.

item.title: HDTV
item.description: [#732] We're also stuck with blurry, juddery, slow-panning 24fps movies forever because (thanks to 60fps home video) people associate high framerates with camcorders and cheap sitcoms, and thus think good framerates look 'fake'.

item.title: Eagle
item.description: [#733] In the off-seasons, I hire an animal trainer to help confront secret agents with situations which they are unable to report by radio.

item.title: Outbreak
item.description: [#734] Let's get dinner after we promptly destroy all the X-7 we've manufactured.

item.title: Floor
item.description: [#735] We once got grounded when we convinced the FAA to block flights through our county because of ash clouds.

item.title: Cemetery
item.description: [#736] Three headstones down, I got a call from my mom and it went from bad to worse.

item.title: Yogurt
item.description: [#737] I am firmly of the opinion that if something doesn't have a year on it, every time the expiration date rolls around it is good again for the two weeks preceding that date.

item.title: Incision
item.description: [#738] At one point, by force of childhood habit, the doctor accidentally removed three or four organs.

item.title: Malamanteau
item.description: [#739] The article has twenty-three citations, one of which is an obscure manuscript from the 1490's and the other twenty-two are arguments on LanguageLog.

item.title: The Tell-Tale Beat
item.description: [#740] You fancy me mad. Could a madman have outsmarted the greatest electronica/techno artists of our era? Next to fall will be Roderick Usher's house/trance band.

item.title: Blogging
item.description: [#741] I'm looking to virally monetize your eyeballs by selling them for transplants.

item.title: Campfire
item.description: [#742] 100 years later, this story remains terrifying--not because it's the local network block, but because the killer is still on IPv4.

item.title: Infrastructures
item.description: [#743] The heartfelt tune it plays is CC licensed, and you can get it from my seed on JoinDiaspora.com whenever that project gets going.

item.title: Walkthrough
item.description: [#744] There's nothing hotter than porn dubbed over with a poorly-mic'd teenager's voice explaining each step in a droning monotone. 'okay, we're almost at the spawn point ... separate the labia, but watch out, there are more inside them ..."

item.title: Dyslexics
item.description: [#745] And of course I had to redo this like three times because I kept writing 'UNTIE'; I kept doing 'doing 'doing it wrong' wrong' wrong.

item.title: Birth
item.description: [#746] All those GTA marathons during the pregnancy were a bad idea.

item.title: Geeks and Nerds
item.description: [#747] The definitions I grew up with were that a geek is someone unusually into something (so you could have computer geeks, baseball geeks, theater geeks, etc) and nerds are (often awkward) science, math, or computer geeks. But definitions vary.

item.title: Worst-Case Scenario
item.description: [#748] To get serious analyses of hurricanes and oil slicks, see Jeff Masters' blog. To get serious discussions of worst-case scenario thinking, see Bruce Schneier's blog. To get enough Vitamin D, don't read any blogs and go outside instead.

item.title: Study
item.description: [#749] Volunteers needed for a study on transmission of urushiol from digital contact with thin strips of fibrous cellulose pulp.

item.title: Book Burning
item.description: [#750] Of course, since their cautionary tale was reported in a print newspaper, no one read it.

item.title: Swimsuit Issue
item.description: [#751] Parents: talk to your kids about popup blockers. Also, at some point, sex. But crucial fundamentals first!

item.title: Phobia
item.description: [#752] Oh God, the tornado picked up snakes!

item.title: Southern Half
item.description: [#753] Also, if you read his speech at Rice, all his arguments for going to the moon work equally well as arguments for blowing up the moon, sending cloned dinosaurs into space, or constructing a towering penis-shaped obelisk on Mars.

item.title: Dependencies
item.description: [#754] The prereqs for CPSC 357, the class on package management, are CPSC 432, CPSC 357, and glibc2.5 or later.

item.title: Interdisciplinary
item.description: [#755] Replace the pendulums with history students and you'll qualify for a grant!

item.title: Public Opinion
item.description: [#756] News networks giving a greater voice to viewers because the social web is so popular are like a chef on the Titanic who, seeing the looming iceberg and fleeing customers, figures ice is the future and starts making snow cones.

item.title: Toot
item.description: [#757] This is also one of only five identified situations in which a vuvuzela is actually appropriate.

item.title: Raptor Fences
item.description: [#758] If at least one person has a nightmare about being swarmed by hundreds of mouse-sized dromaeosaurids, my work will have been done.

item.title: 3x9
item.description: [#759] Handy exam trick: when you know the answer but not the correct derivation, derive blindly forward from the givens and backward from the answer, and join the chains once the equations start looking similar. Sometimes the graders don't notice the seam.

item.title: Moria
item.description: [#760] Someone should really bring them a ladder and remind them to build the Endless Stair *first* next time.

item.title: DFS
item.description: [#761] A breadth-first search makes a lot of sense for dating in general, actually; it suggests dating a bunch of people casually before getting serious, rather than having a series of five-year relationships one after the other.

item.title: Analogies
item.description: [#762] I just call all of them 'synecdoche'.

item.title: Workaround
item.description: [#763] I once worked on a friend's dad's computer. He had the hard drive divided into six partitions, C: through J:, with a 'Documents' directory tree on each one. Each new file appeared to be saved to a partition at random. I knew enough not to ask.

item.title: One Two
item.description: [#764] Cue letters from anthropology majors complaining that this view of numerolinguistic development perpetuates a widespread myth. They get to write letters like that because when you're not getting a real science degree you have a lot of free time. Zing!

item.title: Dilution
item.description: [#765] Dear editors of Homeopathy Monthly: I have two small corrections for your July issue. One, it's spelled "echinacea", and two, homeopathic medicines are no better than placebos and your entire magazine is a sham.

item.title: Green Flash
item.description: [#766] The exact cause of the phenomenon is unknown, but it's thought to be linked to atmospheric refraction and you getting a really cool car.

item.title: Temper
item.description: [#767] Mr. Rogers projected an air of genuine, unwavering, almost saintly pure-hearted decency. But when you look deeper, at the person behind the image ... that's exactly what you find there, too. He's exactly what he appears to be.

[#768] College Board issues aside, I have fond memories of TI-BASIC, writing in it a 3D graphing engine and a stock market analyzer. With enough patience, I could make anything ... but friends. (Although with my chatterbot experiments, I certainly tried.)

item.title: War
item.description: [#769] They offered to make me a green beret, but I liked my regular one. Although it gets kind of squashed under my helmet.

item.title: All the Girls
item.description: [#770] You know that I'll never leave you. Not as long as she's with someone.

item.title: Period Speech
item.description: [#771] The same people who spend their weekends at the Blogger Reenactment Festivals will whine about the anachronisms in historical movies, but no one else will care.

item.title: Frogger
item.description: [#772] I understand you and your team worked hard on this, but when we said to make it more realistic, we meant the graphics.

item.title: University Website
item.description: [#773] People go to the website because they can't wait for the next alumni magazine, right? What do you mean, you want a campus map? One of our students made one as a CS class project back in '01! You can click to zoom and everything!

item.title: Atheists
item.description: [#774] 'But you're using that same tactic to try to feel superior to me, too!' 'Sorry, that accusation expires after one use per conversation.'

item.title: Savannah Ancestry
item.description: [#775] She's a perfectly nice lady from a beautiful city, and there's no reason to be mean just because she thinks a quarterback is a river in Egypt.

item.title: Still No Sleep
item.description: [#776] I'm not listening to you. I mean, what does a SQUIRREL know about mental health?

item.title: Pore Strips
item.description: [#777] I'm sure they're a harmful tool of the cosmetics-industrial complex and all, but my goodness do those strips ever work to pull gunk out of your pores. I was shocked, disgusted, and vaguely fascinated by the result.

item.title: Scheduling
item.description: [#778] 'How about a little ... *family growth*?' 'Dude, that's not until round two.'

item.title: Anxiety
item.description: [#779] Don't need any, thanks. I have a backscattering fetish.

item.title: Sample
item.description: [#780] There are two or three songs out there with beeps in the chorus that sound exactly like the clock radio alarm I had in high school, and hearing it makes me think my life since junior year has been a dream I'm about to wake up from.

item.title: Ahead Stop
item.description: [#781] They actually started the reversed-text practice in 1977 -- not for ease-of-reading reasons, but because too many people were driving backward down the highway blasting the Star Wars opening theme.

item.title: Desecration
item.description: [#782] It gets worse! You know that wizened old monk with the gypsy wife whose voodoo shop we smash up every day after school?

item.title: I Don't Want Directions
item.description: [#783] Yes, I understand that the turn is half a mile past the big field, but my GPS knows that, too. This would be easier if you weren't about to ask me to repeat it all back to you.

item.title: Falling Asleep
item.description: [#784] Sweet unintersecting dreams!

item.title: Open Mic Night
item.description: [#785] Ever notice how the more successful observational comics become, the more their jokes focus on flying and hotels?

item.title: Exoplanets
item.description: [#786] I'm just worried that we'll all leave and you won't get to come along!

item.title: Orbiter
item.description: [#787] Normally, the Shuttle can't quite safely reach the orbital inclination required to pass over both those points from a Canaveral launch, but this is an alternate history in which either it launches from Vandenberg or everyone hates the Outer Banks.

item.title: The Carriage
item.description: [#788] I learned from Achewood that since this poem is in ballad meter, it can be sung to the tune of Gilligan's Island. Since then, try as I might, I haven't ONCE been able to read it normally.

item.title: Showdown
item.description: [#789] The tumbleweed then tried to roll off into the sunset, but due to the Old West's placement north of the subtropical ridge, the prevailing winds were in the wrong direction.

item.title: Control
item.description: [#790] Which, at one point, led to a study showing that LSD produces no more hallucinations than a placebo.

item.title: Leaving
item.description: [#791] What'll I say -- "I was staring at some cat vomit when I got the news?"

item.title: Password Reuse
item.description: [#792] It'll be hilarious the first few times this happens.

item.title: Physicists
item.description: [#793] If you need some help with the math, let me know, but that should be enough to get you started! Huh? No, I don't need to read your thesis, I can imagine roughly what it says.

item.title: Inside Joke
item.description: [#794] I've looked through a few annotated versions of classic books, and it's shocking how much of what's in there is basically pop-culture references totally lost on us now.

item.title: Conditional Risk
item.description: [#795] 'Dude, wait -- I'm not American! So my risk is basically zero!'

item.title: Bad Ex
item.description: [#796] Since the goatee, glasses, and Seltzer & Friedberg DVD collection didn't tip you off, there will be a $20 negligence charge for this service.

item.title: debian-main
item.description: [#797] dpkg: error processing package (--purge): subprocess pre-removal script returned error exit 163: OH_GOD_THEYRE_INSIDE_MY_CLOTHES

item.title: Adjectives
item.description: [#798] 'Fucking ineffable' sounds like someone remembering how to do self-censorship halfway through a phrase.

item.title: Stephen Hawking
item.description: [#799] 'Guys? The Town is supposed to be good, and I thou--' 'PHYSICIST STEPHEN HAWKING DECLARES NEW FILM BEST IN ALL SPACE AND TIME' 'No, I just heard that--' 'SHOULD SCIENCE PLAY A ROLE IN JUDGING BEN AFFLECK?' 'I don't think--' 'WHAT ABOUT MATT DAMON?'

item.title: Beautiful Dream
item.description: [#800] Lucky. In MY dream, all the people who grew up loving The Giving Tree paired up with all the students who had weird dreams after reading The Metamorphosis. That one was more confusing.

item.title: Golden Hammer
item.description: [#801] Took me five tries to find the right one, but I managed to salvage our night out--if not the boat--in the end.

item.title: Online Communities 2
item.description: [#802] Best trivia I learned while working on this: 'Man, Farmville is so huge! Do you realize it's the second-biggest browser-based social-networking-centered farming game in the WORLD?' Then you wait for the listener to do a double-take.

item.title: Airfoil
item.description: [#803] This is a fun explanation to prepare your kids for; it's common and totally wrong. Good lines include 'why does the air have to travel on both sides at the same time?' and 'I saw the Wright brothers plane and those wings were curved the same on the top and bottom!'

item.title: Pumpkin Carving
item.description: [#804] The Banach-Tarski theorem was actually first developed by King Solomon, but his gruesome attempts to apply it set back set theory for centuries.

item.title: Paradise City
item.description: [#805] Take me down to the paradise municipality / where the grass is mauve and the girls aren't fromthisreality.

item.title: Tech Support
item.description: [#806] I recently had someone ask me to go get a computer and turn it on so I could restart it. He refused to move further in the script until I said I had done that.

item.title: Connected
item.description: [#807] Or love in general, for that matter. It just leads to the idea that either your love is pure, perfect, and eternal, and you are storybook-compatible in every way with no problems, or you're LYING when you say 'I love you'.

item.title: The Economic Argument
item.description: [#808] Not to be confused with 'making money selling this stuff to OTHER people who think it works', which corporate accountants and actuaries have zero problems with.

item.title: Los Alamos
item.description: [#809] The test didn't (spoiler alert) destroy the world, but the fact that they were even doing those calculations makes theirs the coolest jobs ever.

item.title: Constructive
item.description: [#810] And what about all the people who won't be able to join the community because they're terrible at making helpful and constructive co-- ... oh.

item.title: Starlight
item.description: [#811] Don't worry! From the light's point of view, home and your eye are in the same place, and the journey takes no time at all! Relativity saves the day again.

item.title: Glass
item.description: [#812] I read in this one article that the breaking of electroweak symmetry is the reason we have SOULS. This guy with a degree said so!

item.title: One-Liners
item.description: [#813] 'Upgrade to the latest version of Adobe Flash player to view THIS content, bitch.' ::triggers detonator::

item.title: Diode
item.description: [#814] And the worst part is you won't apologize.

item.title: Mu
item.description: [#815] As the CoKF approaches 0, productivity goes negative as you pull OTHER people into chair-spinning contests.

item.title: Applied Math
item.description: [#816] Dear Reader: Enclosed is a check for ninety-eight cents. Using your work, I have proven that this equals the amount you requested.

item.title: Mutual
item.description: [#817] A universe that needed someone to observe it in order to collapse it into existence would be a pretty sorry universe indeed.

item.title: Illness
item.description: [#818] <3 If there's anything you can do, I'll let you know. For the moment, any simple distracting online games sent to sick@xkcd.com will not go unappreciated [EDIT: Holy crap 2,700 games before noon. I love you guys; thank you. They will be passed along and played by us all.]

item.title: Five-Minute Comics: Part 1
item.description: [#819] The wolves thin the RAID arrays, removing the slowest and weakest disks to keep the average seek speed high.

item.title: Five-Minute Comics: Part 2
item.description: [#820] Dear Wiccan readers: I understand modern Wiccans are not usually all about the curses and hexes. But Darth Vader was recently converted from Episcopalianism and he's still figuring it all out.

item.title: Five-Minute Comics: Part 3
item.description: [#821] Resulting in The Little Rock 9x + C.

item.title: Guest Week: Jeph Jacques (Questionable Content)
item.description: [#822] Guest comic by Jeph Jacques of Questionable Content, whose internal monologue hasn't been speaking to him for the past three years.

item.title: Guest Week: David Troupes (Buttercup Festival)
item.description: [#823] Guest comic by David Troupes of Buttercup Festival, who is living in that lovely tree outside your window.

item.title: Guest Week: Bill Amend (FoxTrot)
item.description: [#824] Guest comic by Bill Amend of FoxTrot, an inspiration to all us nerdy-physics-majors-turned-cartoonists, of which there are an oddly large number.

item.title: Guest Week: Jeffrey Rowland (Overcompensating)
item.description: [#825] Guest comic by Jeffrey Rowland of Overcompensating/Wigu. Jeffrey is famous as the picture on the Wikipedia article on 'Necrosis'.

item.title: Guest Week: Zach Weiner (SMBC)
item.description: [#826] Guest comic by Zach Weiner of Saturday Morning Breakfast Cereal. When I was stressed out, Zach gave me a talk that was really encouraging and somehow involved nanobots.

item.title: My Business Idea
item.description: [#827] We didn't believe you at first, but we asked like three people who were at that party. They not only corroborated your story, but even said you totally mentioned wanting to start a company someday. Sorry! If this isn't enough money, let us know.

item.title: Positive Attitude
item.description: [#828] Having a positive attitude is almost tautologically good for your mental health, and extreme stress can hurt your immune system, but that doesn't mean you should feel like shit for feeling like shit.

item.title: Arsenic-Based Life
item.description: [#829] According to a new paper published in the journal Science, reporters are unable to thrive in an arsenic-rich environment.

item.title: Genetic Analysis
item.description: [#830] There's still a chance you were conceived via IVF. But we've checked your mom's college yearbook photos, and whether or not she and your father had sex, it's clear that ... listen, I know this is hard for you.

item.title: Weather Radar
item.description: [#831] Ever notice how there aren't as many thunderstorms now as there were when you were a kid? Much like 'the shuffle on my MP3 player has a bias', this is occasionally true but universally believed. Brains are so interesting!

item.title: Tic-Tac-Toe
item.description: [#832] The only winning move is to play, perfectly, waiting for your opponent to make a mistake.

item.title: Convincing
item.description: [#833] And if you labeled your axes, I could tell you exactly how MUCH better.

item.title: Wikileaks
item.description: [#834] STUDENTS ARE CALLING PRESIDENT JOHNSON EN MASSE TO PROTEST THE BOMBING AND IT'S JAMMED THE WHITE HOUSE SWITCHBOARD. COULD THEY COLLAPSE OUR CRITICAL PHONE SYSTEMS? HAS THE FIRST TELEPHONE WAR BEGUN? STAY TUNED FOR MORE ON THIS DANGEROUS NEW TECHNOLOGY.

item.title: Tree
item.description: [#835] Not only is that terrible in general, but you just KNOW Billy's going to open the root present first, and then everyone will have to wait while the heap is rebuilt.

item.title: Sickness
item.description: [#836] At least, with p<0.05 confidence.

item.title: Coupon Code
item.description: [#837] This also guarantees he won't be one of the ones to get a bobcat.

item.title: Incident
item.description: [#838] He sees you when you're sleeping, he knows when you're awake, he's copied on /var/spool/mail/root, so be good for goodness' sake.

item.title: Explorers
item.description: [#839] We're going to have to work together to get over our hangups if we're going to learn to move on Catan's hexagonal grid. It's bad enough that we lost our crew of pawns when we passed within firing range of Battleship.

item.title: Serious
item.description: [#840] Not to be confused with Serious PuTTY, the Windows terminal client where everything is in Impact.

item.title: Audiophiles
item.description: [#841] For years, I took the wrong lesson from that Monster Cable experiment and only listened to my music through alligator-clipped coat hangers.

item.title: Mark
item.description: [#842] I'm a solipsistic conspiracy theorist. I'm sure I must be up to something, and I will not stop until I find out what.

item.title: Misconceptions
item.description: [#843] 'Grandpa, what was it like in the Before time?' 'It was hell. People went around saying glass was a slow-flowing liquid. You folks these days don't know how good you have it.'

item.title: Good Code
item.description: [#844] You can either hang out in the Android Loop or the HURD loop.

item.title: Modern History
item.description: [#845] During the week, I research my character by living in his house and raising his children.

item.title: Dental Nerve
item.description: [#846] WAKE up in the MORning and my BREATH ain't PREtty / and noBODY'S gonna KISS me if my MOUTH smells SHItty / so I ALways brush my TEETH before I START on the JACK / sure, my DRINKing's out of HAND, but I'm conTROLLing my PLAQUE.

item.title: Stingray Nebula
item.description: [#847] Erendil will patrol the walls of night only until the sun reaches red giant stage, engulfing the Morning Star on his brow. Light and high beauty are passing things as well.

item.title: 3D
item.description: [#848] The LINACs in the glasses frames can barely manage one MeV. You should've gone to the screening at CERN.

item.title: Complex Conjugate
item.description: [#849] Fun fact: if you say this every time a professor does something to a complex-number equation that drops the imaginary part, they'll eventually move the class to another room and tell everyone else except you.

item.title: World According to Americans
item.description: [#850] It's not our fault we caught a group on their way home from a geography bee. And they taught us that Uzbekistan is one of the world's two doubly-landlocked countries!

item.title: Na
item.description: [#851] I hear that there are actual lyrics later on in Land of 1,000 Dances, but other than the occasional 'I said,' I've never listened long enough to hear any of them.

item.title: Local g
item.description: [#852] In Rio de Janeiro in 2016, the same jump will get an athlete 0.25% higher (>1cm) than in London four years prior.

item.title: Consecutive Vowels
item.description: [#853] But the windows! What if there's a voyeur watchi-- wait, now I'm turned on too.

item.title: Learning to Cook
item.description: [#854] And yet I never stop thinking, 'sure, these ingredients cost more than a restaurant meal, but think how many meals I'll get out of them! Especially since each one will have leftovers!'
[#855] 'Whoa, twenty-two in two hours!' 'Your site got twenty-two hundred hits in two hours?' 'No. Twenty-two. But still, that's like half the people on the internet!'

item.title: Trochee Fixation
item.description: [#856] If you Huffman-coded all the 'random' things everyone on the internet has said over the years, you'd wind up with, like, 30 or 40 bytes *tops*.

item.title: Archimedes
item.description: [#857] Give a man a fish, or he will destroy the only existing vial of antidote.

item.title: Milk
item.description: [#858] It's not hard when you have the same thought like 40 or 50 percent of the time.
[#859] Brains aside, I wonder how many poorly-written xkcd.com-parsing scripts will break on this title (or ;;"''{<<[' this mouseover text."

item.title: Never Do This
item.description: [#860] I call Rule 34 on The Secret House.

item.title: Wisdom Teeth
item.description: [#861] I heard the general anesthesia drugs can cause amnesia, so when I woke up mid-extraction I started taking notes on my hand so I'd remember things later. I managed 'AWAKE BUT EVERYTHING OK' before the dental assistant managed to find and confiscate all my pens.

item.title: Let Go
item.description: [#862] After years of trying various methods, I broke this habit by pitting my impatience against my laziness. I decoupled the action and the neurological reward by setting up a simple 30-second delay I had to wait through, in which I couldn't do anything else, before any new page or chat client would load (and only allowed one to run at once). The urge to check all those sites magically vanished--and my 'productive' computer use was unaffected.

item.title: Major in the Universe
item.description: [#863] I hear Steven Levitt is writing a book analyzing A.J. Jacobs' quest to spend a year reading everything Malcolm Gladwell ever wrote. The audiobook will be narrated by Robert Krulwich of Radiolab.

item.title: Flying Cars
item.description: [#864] It's hard to fit in the backseat of my flying car with my android Realdoll when we're both wearing jetpacks.

item.title: Nanobots
item.description: [#865] I think the IETF hit the right balance with the 128 bits thing. We can fit MAC addresses in a /64 subnet, and the nanobots will only be able to devour half the planet.

item.title: Compass and Straightedge
item.description: [#866] The Greeks long suspected this, but it wasn't until April 12th of 1882 that Ferdinand von Lindemann conclusively proved it when he constructed himself the most awesome birthday party possible and nobody showed up.

item.title: Herpetology
item.description: [#867] Birds are Aves, which is part of the clade Theropoda, which is in Saurischia, which is in Dinosauria. Those birds outside our windows are dinosaurs. We can clear out the rest of our brains because we now have the best fact.

item.title: Nolan Chart
item.description: [#868] Also in the right quadrant are NFPA-compliant chemical manufacturers and Sir Charles Wheatstone. Sharing the top with the internet libertarians are Nate Silver and several politically-active kite designers.

item.title: Server Attention Span
item.description: [#869] They have to keep the adjacent rack units empty. Otherwise, half the entries in their /var/log/syslog are just 'SERVER BELOW TRYING TO START CONVERSATION *AGAIN*.' and 'WISH THEY'D STOP GIVING HIM SO MUCH COFFEE IT SPLATTERS EVERYWHERE.'

item.title: Advertising
item.description: [#870] I remember the exact moment in my childhood when I realized, while reading a flyer, that nobody would ever spend money solely to tell me they wanted to give me something for nothing. It's a much more vivid memory than the (related) parental Santa talk.

item.title: Charity
item.description: [#871] I usually respond to someone else doing something good by figuring out a reason that they're not really as good as they seem. But I've been realizing lately that there's an easier way to handle these situations, and it involves zero internet arguments.

item.title: Fairy Tales
item.description: [#872] Goldilocks' discovery of Newton's method for approximation required surprisingly few changes.

item.title: FPS Mod
item.description: [#873] Wait, that second one is a woman? ... wait, if that bothers me, then why doesn't ... man, this game is no fun anymore.

item.title: Time Management
item.description: [#874] I never trust anyone who's more excited about success than about doing the thing they want to be successful at.

item.title: 2009 Called
item.description: [#875] 2017 called, but I couldn't understand what they were saying over all the screams.

item.title: Trapped
item.description: [#876] Socrates could've saved himself a lot of trouble if he'd just brought a flashlight, tranquilizer gun, and a bunch of rescue harnesses.

item.title: Beauty
item.description: [#877] The best hugs are probably from hagfish, which can extrude microscopic filaments that convert a huge volume of water around them to slime in seconds. Instant cozy blanket!

item.title: Model Rail
item.description: [#878] I don't know what's more telling--the number of pages in the Wikipedia talk page argument over whether the 1/87.0857143 scale is called "HO" or "H0", or the fact that within minutes of first hearing of it I had developed an extremely strong opinion on the issue.

item.title: Lamp
item.description: [#879] 'That was definitely not in my top three wishes.' 'Who said anything about YOUR wishes?'

item.title: Headache
item.description: [#880] I'm only willing to visit placid lakes, salt flats, and painting exhibits until the world's 3D technology improves.

item.title: Probability
item.description: [#881] My normal approach is useless here, too.

item.title: Significant
item.description: [#882] 'So, uh, we did the green study again and got no link. It was probably a--' 'RESEARCH CONFLICTED ON GREEN JELLY BEAN/ACNE LINK; MORE STUDY RECOMMENDED!'

item.title: Pain Rating
item.description: [#883] If it were a two or above I wouldn't be able to answer because it would mean a pause in the screaming.

item.title: Rogers St.
item.description: [#884] 'We can also use middle names in place of first pet's names, but yours is something incomprehensible about dropping tables.'

item.title: Recycling
item.description: [#885] And given how much of my stuff they go through, they definitely know where I live.

item.title: Craigslist Apartments
item.description: [#886] $1600 / 1386153BR 3BATH, MODERN SLIDING DOORS, GUEST ROOMS, GARBAGE DISPOSAL. FREE MANDATORY PARKING (ENFORCED). CONVENIENT TO ALDERAAN.

item.title: Future Timeline
item.description: [#887] Not shown: the approximately 30,000 identical, vaguely hysterical articles titled "WHITE PEOPLE IN [THE US/BRITAIN] TO BECOME MINORITY BY [YEAR]!", which came up for basically any year I put in.

item.title: Heaven
item.description: [#888] If you've never had sex, this is what it feels like. Complete with the brief feeling of satisfaction, followed by ennui, followed by getting bored and trying to make it happen again.

item.title: Turtles
item.description: [#889] You're a turtle!

item.title: Etymology
item.description: [#890] For some reason, my childhood suspension of disbelief had no problem with the fact that this ancient galaxy is full of humans, but was derailed by language. There's no Asia OR Europe there, so where'd they get all the Indo-European roots?

item.title: Movie Ages
item.description: [#891] If you're 15 or younger, then just remember that it's nevertheless probably too late to be a child prodigy.

item.title: Null Hypothesis
item.description: [#892] Hell, my eighth grade science class managed to conclusively reject it just based on a classroom experiment. It's pretty sad to hear about million-dollar research teams who can't even manage that.

item.title: 65 Years
item.description: [#893] The universe is probably littered with the one-planet graves of cultures which made the sensible economic decision that there's no good reason to go into space--each discovered, studied, and remembered by the ones who made the irrational decision.

item.title: Progeny
item.description: [#894] I tell my children 'it's not whether you win or lose, it's how you play the game.' I'm trying to take the edge off their competitive drive to ensure that I can always beat them.

item.title: Teaching Physics
item.description: [#895] Space-time is like some simple and familiar system which is both intuitively understandable and precisely analogous, and if I were Richard Feynman I'd be able to come up with it.

item.title: Marie Curie
item.description: [#896] Although not permanently.

item.title: Elevator Inspection
item.description: [#897] Even governmental elevator inspectors get bored halfway through asking where the building office is.

item.title: Chain of Command
item.description: [#898] Themistocles said his infant son ruled all Greece -- "Athens rules all Greece; I control Athens; my wife controls me; and my infant son controls her." Thus, nowadays the world is controlled by whoever buys advertising time on Dora the Explorer.

item.title: Number Line
item.description: [#899] The Wikipedia page "List of Numbers" opens with "This list is incomplete; you can help by expanding it."

item.title: Religions
item.description: [#900] But to us there is but one God, plus or minus one. --1 Corinthians 8:62.

item.title: Temperature
item.description: [#901] And the baby has a fever.

item.title: Darmok and Jalad
item.description: [#902] I wonder how often Patrick Stewart has Darmok flashbacks when talking to Star Trek fans.

item.title: Extended Mind
item.description: [#903] Wikipedia trivia: if you take any article, click on the first link in the article text not in parentheses or italics, and then repeat, you will eventually end up at "Philosophy".

item.title: Sports
item.description: [#904] Also, all financial analysis. And, more directly, D&D.

item.title: Homeownership
item.description: [#905] New research shows over 60% of the financial collapse's toxic assets were created by power drills.

item.title: Advertising Discovery
item.description: [#906] When advertisers figure this out, our only weapon will be blue sharpies and "[disputed]".

item.title: Ages
item.description: [#907] Every age: "I'm glad I'm not the clueless person I was five years ago, but now I don't want to get any older."

item.title: The Cloud
item.description: [#908] There's planned downtime every night when we turn on the Roomba and it runs over the cord.

item.title: Worst-Case Shopping
item.description: [#909] Wait a minute. If I'm escaping from a submarine at 50 meters, then I'll *definitely* need a flashlight to find air pockets for gradual decompression on the way up. Time to start shopping professional dive lights.

item.title: Permanence
item.description: [#910] This hostname is going in dozens of remote config files. Changing a kid's name is comparatively easy!

item.title: Magic School Bus
item.description: [#911] At my OLD school, we used Microsoft Encarta 2005.

item.title: Manual Override
item.description: [#912] I think you mean 'GNU Info Override'.

item.title: Core
item.description: [#913] If you're a geologist or geophysicist and you don't introduce yourself by saying your name, then gesturing downward and saying "... and I study that", I don't know what you're doing with your life.

item.title: Ice
item.description: [#914] On the plus side, she wrote 'Welcome to the AAA Club!' in lipstick on the bathroom mirror, and left me a membership/roadside assistance card on the counter.

item.title: Connoisseur
item.description: [#915] Our brains have just one scale, and we resize our experiences to fit.

item.title: Unpickable
item.description: [#916] The safe is empty except for an unsolved 5x5 Rubik's cube.

item.title: Hofstadter
item.description: [#917] "This is the reference implementation of the self-referential joke."

item.title: Google+
item.description: [#918] On one hand, you'll never be able to convince your parents to switch. On the other hand, you'll never be able to convince your parents to switch!

item.title: Tween Bromance
item.description: [#919] Verbiage. Va-jay-jay. Irregardless.

item.title: YouTube Parties
item.description: [#920] This reminds me of that video where ... no? How have you not seen that? Oh man, let me find it. No, it's ok, we can go back to your video later.

item.title: Delivery Notification
item.description: [#921] You can arrange a pickup of your sword in Rivendell between the hours of noon and 7:00 PM.

item.title: Fight Club
item.description: [#922] I'm not saying it's all bad, but that movie has not aged as well as my teenage self in 2000 was confident it would.

item.title: Strunk and White
item.description: [#923] The best thing about Strunk/White fanfiction is that it's virtually guaranteed to be well written.

item.title: 3D Printer
item.description: [#924] I just can't wait for the Better Homes and Gardens list of helpful tips for household reuse of sixteen-inch acrylonitrile-butadiene-styrene phalluses.

item.title: Cell Phones
item.description: [#925] He holds the laptop like that on purpose, to make you cringe.

item.title: Time Vulture
item.description: [#926] In a way, all vultures are Time Vultures; some just have more patience than others.

item.title: Standards
item.description: [#927] Fortunately, the charging one has been solved now that we've all standardized on mini-USB. Or is it micro-USB? Shit.

item.title: Mimic Octopus
item.description: [#928] Even if the dictionaries are starting to give in, I refuse to accept 'octopi' as a word mainly because--I'm not making this up--there's a really satisfying climactic scene in the Orson Scott Card horror novel 'Lost Boys' which hinges on it being an incorrect pluralization.

item.title: Speculation
item.description: [#929] 'I was pretty good at skeet shooting, but was eventually kicked off the range for catching the clay pigeons in a net and dispatching them execution-style.'

item.title: Days of the Week
item.description: [#930] Not pictured: the elongated Halley's-Comet-like orbit of every Rebecca Black lyric.

item.title: Lanes
item.description: [#931] Each quarter of the lanes from left to right correspond loosely to breast cancer stages one through four (at diagnosis).

item.title: CIA
item.description: [#932] It was their main recruiting poster, hung nearly ten feet up a wall! This means the hackers have LADDER technology! Are we headed for a future where everyone has to pay $50 for one of those locked plexiglass poster covers? More after the break ...

item.title: Tattoo
item.description: [#933] I calculate that the electrons in radiation therapy hit you at 99.8% of the speed of light, and the beam used in a 90-second gamma ray therapy session could, if fired with less precision, kill a horse (they did not let me test this).

item.title: Mac/PC
item.description: [#934] It's fun to watch browsers fumblingly recapitulate the history of window management. Someday we'll have xmonad as a Firefox extension.

item.title: Missed Connections
item.description: [#935] The Street View van isn't going to find out anything Google won't already know from reading my email.

item.title: Password Strength
item.description: [#936] To anyone who understands information theory and security and is in an infuriating argument with someone who does not (possibly involving mixed case), I sincerely apologize.

item.title: TornadoGuard
item.description: [#937] The bug report was marked 'could not reproduce'.

item.title: T-Cells
item.description: [#938] 'We're not sure how to wipe out the chimeral T-cells after they've destroyed the cancer. Though I do have this vial of smallpox ...'

item.title: Arrow
item.description: [#939] 'The Return of the Boomerang' would make a great movie title.

item.title: Oversight
item.description: [#940] I felt so clever when I found a way to game the Fitocracy system by incorporating a set of easy but high-scoring activities into my regular schedule. Took me a bit to realize I'd been tricked into setting up a daily exercise routine.

item.title: Depth Perception
item.description: [#941] I've looked at clouds from both sides now.

item.title: Juggling
item.description: [#942] Later: 'Why is there a book hovering over the trash can?'

item.title: Empirical
item.description: [#943] I'm as surprised as you!

item.title: Hurricane Names
item.description: [#944] After exhausting the OED, we started numbering them. When overlapping hurricanes formed at all points on the Earth's surface, and our scheme was foiled by Cantor diagonalization, we just decided to name them all "Steve". Your local forecast tomorrow is "Steve". Good luck.

item.title: I'm Sorry
item.description: [#945] You know I've always hated her.

item.title: Family Decals
item.description: [#946] My decal set has no adults, just a sea of hundreds of the little girl figures closing in around a single cat.

item.title: Investing
item.description: [#947] But Einstein said it was the most powerful force in the universe, and I take all my investment advice from flippant remarks by theoretical physicists making small talk at parties.

item.title: AI
item.description: [#948] And they both react poorly to showers.

item.title: File Transfer
item.description: [#949] Every time you email a file to yourself so you can pull it up on your friend's laptop, Tim Berners-Lee sheds a single tear.

item.title: Mystery Solved
item.description: [#950] The Roanoke Lost Colonists founded Roanoke, the Franklin Expedition reached the Pacific in 2009 when the Northwest Passage opened, and Jimmy Hoffa currently heads the Teamsters Union--he just started going by 'James'.

item.title: Working
item.description: [#951] And if you drive a typical car more than a mile out of your way for each penny you save on the per-gallon price, it doesn't matter how worthless your time is to you--the gas to get you there and back costs more than you save.

item.title: Stud Finder
item.description: [#952] According to every stud finder I've tried to use, my walls contain a rapidly shifting network of hundreds and hundreds of studs.

item.title: 1 to 10
item.description: [#953] If you get an 11/100 on a CS test, but you claim it should be counted as a 'C', they'll probably decide you deserve the upgrade.

item.title: Chin-Up Bar
item.description: [#954] Those few who escaped found the emergency cutoff box disabled. The stampede lasted two hours and reached the bottom three times.

item.title: Neutrinos
item.description: [#955] I can't speak to the paper's scientific merits, but it's really cool how on page 10 you can see that their reference GPS beacon is sensitive enough to pick up continential drift under the detector (interrupted halfway through by an earthquake).

item.title: Sharing
item.description: [#956] In the new edition of The Giving Tree, the tree uses social tools to share with its friend all the best places to buy things.

item.title: Development
item.description: [#957] Funding was quickly restored to the NHC and the APA was taken back off hurricane forecast duty.

item.title: Hotels
item.description: [#958] 'Rating: 1/5. Room filled to brim with semen, and when front desk clerk opened mouth to talk, bedbugs poured out.'

item.title: Caroling
item.description: [#959] For a thousand generations we vowed never to forget how his soldiers feasted on our brother Stephen.

item.title: Subliminal
item.description: [#960] Once you see it, you can't help seeing it every time. Until your body finishes metabolizing the mushrooms.

item.title: Eternal Flame
item.description: [#961] There's always the hope that if you sit and watch for long enough, the beachball will vanish and the thing it interrupted will return.

item.title: The Corliss Resolution
item.description: [#962] And no avian society ever develops space travel because it's impossible to focus on calculus when you could be outside flying.

item.title: X11
item.description: [#963] Thomas Jefferson thought that every law and every constitution should be torn down and rewritten from scratch every nineteen years--which means X is overdue.

item.title: Dorm Poster
item.description: [#964] I was going to record an album with that cover under the name "PINK FTFY", so it'd come after them on the store CD rack. But at this point music stores are just rooms where CDs are set out to age before they're thrown away, so probably nobody would see it.

item.title: Elements
item.description: [#965] Of all the nations, the armies of the ununoctium-benders are probably the least intimidating. The xenon-benders come close, but their flickery signs are at least effective for propaganda.

item.title: Jet Fuel
item.description: [#966] The 'controlled demolition' theory was concocted by the government to distract us. '9/11 was an inside job' was an inside job!

item.title: Prairie
item.description: [#967] Colorado is working to develop coherent amber waves, which would allow them to finally destroy Kansas and Nebraska with a devastating but majestic grain laser.

item.title: Everything
item.description: [#968] I wanna hold your hand so I don't fall out of your gyrocopter.

item.title: Delta-P
item.description: [#969] If you fire a Portal gun through the door of the wardrobe, space and time knot together, which leads to a frustrated Aslan trying to impart Christian morality to the Space sphere.

item.title: The Important Field
item.description: [#970] I hear in some places, you need one form of ID to buy a gun, but two to pay for it by check. It's interesting who has what incentives to care about what mistakes.

item.title: Alternative Literature
item.description: [#971] I just noticed CVS has started stocking homeopathic pills on the same shelves with--and labeled similarly to--their actual medicine. Telling someone who trusts you that you're giving them medicine, when you know youre not, because you want their money, isnt just lying--its like an example youd make up if you had to illustrate for a child why lying is wrong.

item.title: November
item.description: [#972] November marks the birthday of Charles Schulz, pioneer of tongue awareness.

item.title: MTV Generation
item.description: [#973] If you identified with the kids from The Breakfast Club when it came out, you're now much closer to the age of Principal Vernon.

item.title: The General Problem
item.description: [#974] I find that when someone's taking time to do something right in the present, they're a perfectionist with no ability to prioritize, whereas when someone took time to do something right in the past, they're a master artisan of great foresight.

item.title: Occulting Telescope
item.description: [#975] Type II Kardashev civilizations eventually completely enclose their planetary system in a Dyson sphere because space is way too big to look at all the time.

item.title: Sail
item.description: [#976] It only works a few times before you have to capsize the boat in a soap lagoon again.

item.title: Map Projections
item.description: [#977] What's that? You think I don't like the Peters map because I'm uncomfortable with having my cultural assumptions challenged? Are you sure you're not ... ::puts on sunglasses:: ... projecting?

item.title: Citogenesis
item.description: [#978] I just read a pop-science book by a respected author. One chapter, and much of the thesis, was based around wildly inaccurate data which traced back to ... Wikipedia. To encourage people to be on their toes, I'm not going to say what book or author.

item.title: Wisdom of the Ancients
item.description: [#979] All long help threads should have a sticky globally-editable post at the top saying 'DEAR PEOPLE FROM THE FUTURE: Here's what we've figured out so far ...'

item.title: Money
item.description: [#980] There, I showed you it.

item.title: Porn Folder
item.description: [#981] Eww, gross, you modified link()? How could you enjoy abusing a filesystem like that?

item.title: Set Theory
item.description: [#982] Proof of Zermelo's well-ordering theorem given the Axiom of Choice: 1: Take S to be any set. 2: When I reach step three, if S hasn't managed to find a well-ordering relation for itself, I'll feed it into this wood chipper. 3: Hey, look, S is well-ordered.

item.title: Privacy
item.description: [#983] Eventual headline: 'University Researchers Create Life in Lab! Darkness, Faulty Condoms Blamed.'

item.title: Space Launch System
item.description: [#984] The SLS head engineer plans to invite Shania Twain to stand under the completed prototype, then tell her, 'I don't expect you to date me just because I'm a rocket scientist, but you've gotta admit--this is pretty fucking impressive.'

item.title: Percentage Points
item.description: [#985] Grayton also proposed making college scholarships available exclusively to sexually active teens, amnesty for illegal immigrants who create room for themselves by killing a citizen, and a graduated income tax based on penis size. He has been endorsed by Tracy Morgan, John Wilkes Booth's ghost, and the Time Cube guy.

item.title: Drinking Fountains
item.description: [#986] I've always wondered whether you could drink slowly enough, and eliminate fast enough, that you just sort of peed continuously. But I'm afraid to try because I worry someone might call while I'm doing it and ask what I'm up to, and I won't be able to think of a lie.

item.title: Potential
item.description: [#987] The bunch of disadvantaged kids I was tutoring became too good at writing, and their essays were forcing me to confront painful existential questions, so I started trying to turn them on to drugs and crime instead.

item.title: Tradition
item.description: [#988] An 'American tradition' is anything that happened to a baby boomer twice.

item.title: Cryogenics
item.description: [#989] 'Welcome to the future! Nothing's changed.' was the slogan of my astonishingly short-lived tech startup.

item.title: Plastic Bags
item.description: [#990] The high I feel when I actually remember to bring my reusable bags to the store--and take them inside rather than leaving them in the parked car--can last for days.

item.title: Phantom Menace
item.description: [#991] We could go to the theater across town and see if it's opened THERE yet, but we don't want to lose our place in line.

item.title: Mnemonics
item.description: [#992] 'Sailor Moon's head exploded once' and 'Some men have explosive orgasms' both work for the Great Lakes from west to east (Paddle-to-the-Sea order).

item.title: Brand Identity
item.description: [#993] Legally-mandated information would be printed on the back or discreetly along the bottom. In small letters under the nutrition information it would say 'Like our products? Visit our website!' There would be no URL.

item.title: Advent Calendar
item.description: [#994] I think you could get up to about 11:59:57 before you'd have trouble swallowing the chocolates fast enough. At that point, you'd need some kind of a liquify-and-chug apparatus to get up over the 11:59:59 barrier. Anyway, Merry Christmas!

item.title: Coinstar
item.description: [#995] Plus they take like 9%.

item.title: Making Things Difficult
item.description: [#996] Favorite mastectomy breast prosthesis idea: a fake boob containing a spare rechargable battery, accessed via a nipple USB port. Complete with a ring of LED charge indicators in the areola!

item.title: Wait Wait
item.description: [#997] You can't stab Carl Kasell. He sounds all slow and stentorian, but he moves like a snake.
[#998] To compensate for this, I plan to spend 2013 doing nothing but talking about Mayans. My relationships with my friends and family may not fare well.

item.title: Cougars
item.description: [#999] If you're lying in bed tonight and you see yellow eyes glinting in your window, are you being stalked by a puma, a mountain lion, a panther, a catamount, or a cougar? Trick question--in North America, they're all names for the same species, Puma concolor! Isn't learning fun? Anyway, sleep tight!

item.title: 1000 Comics
item.description: [#1000] Thank you for making me feel less alone.

item.title: AAAAAA
item.description: [#1001] 'ARE YOU TURNED ON YET?' 'I DON'T THINK SO--ARE YOU?' 'MAYBE A LITTLE!' 'OK, FIVE MORE MINUTES.'

item.title: Game AIs
item.description: [#1002] The top computer champion at Seven Minutes in Heaven is a Honda-built Realdoll, but to date it has been unable to outperform the human Seven Minutes in Heaven champion, Ken Jennings.

item.title: Adam and Eve
item.description: [#1003] Abel and Steve would've been fine! I like Steve!

item.title: Batman
item.description: [#1004] I'm really worried Christopher Nolan will kill a man dressed like a bat in his next movie. (The man will be dressed like a bat, I mean. Christopher Nolan won't be, probably.)

item.title: SOPA
item.description: [#1005] In protest of SOPA, I'm currently getting totally blacked out.

item.title: Sloppier Than Fiction
item.description: [#1006] Roger Ebert once called you directionless and unwatchable.

item.title: Sustainable
item.description: [#1007] Though 100 years is longer than a lot of our resources.

item.title: Suckville
item.description: [#1008] Suckville is considered by the Census Bureau to be part of the Detroit metropolitan statistical area, despite not being located anywhere near Detroit.

item.title: Sigh
item.description: [#1009] If you're annoying enough, you can get them to respond with an involuntary second sigh and get a rhythm going.

item.title: Etymology-Man
item.description: [#1010] 'I can't believe I'm saying this, but I wish Aquaman were here instead--HE'D be able to help.'

item.title: Baby Names
item.description: [#1011] I've been trying for a couple years now but I haven't been able to come up with a name dumber than 'Renesmee'.

item.title: Wrong Superhero
item.description: [#1012] Hi! Someone call for me? I'm a superhero who specializes in the study of God's creation of Man in the Book of Genesi-- HOLY SHIT A GIANT BUG!

item.title: Wake Up Sheeple
item.description: [#1013] You will be led to judgement like lambs to the slaughter--a simile whose existence, I might add, will not do your species any favors.

item.title: Car Problems
item.description: [#1014] Or if you replace your car, we'll be happy to set it on fire again so you can take another crack at getting that shot.

item.title: Kerning
item.description: [#1015] I have never been as self-conscious about my handwriting as when I was inking in the caption for this comic.

item.title: Valentine Dilemma
item.description: [#1016] The worst resolution to the Valentine Prisoner's Dilemma when YOU decide not to give your partner a present but your PARTNER decides to testify against you in the armed robbery case.

item.title: Backward in Time
item.description: [#1017] People tell me I have too much time on my hands, but really the problem is that there's too much time, PERIOD.

item.title: Good Cop, Dadaist Cop
item.description: [#1018] NOW INVENT AN IMPOSSIBLE-TO-TRANSLATE LANGUAGE AND USE IT TO TELL US WHERE THE MONEY IS.

item.title: First Post
item.description: [#1019] 'Nuh-uh! We let users vote on comments and display them by number of votes. Everyone knows that makes it impossible for a few persistent voices to dominate the discussion.'

item.title: Orion Nebula
item.description: [#1020] Also on the agenda: what's with his hips?

item.title: Business Plan
item.description: [#1021] The investor elevator pitch is "Wheeeeeeee! Elevators are fun!"

item.title: So It Has Come To This
item.description: [#1022] 'Come to what?' 'You. Me. This moment.'

item.title: Late-Night PBS
item.description: [#1023] Then it switched to these old black-and-white tapes of Bob Ross slumped against the wall of an empty room, painting the least happy trees you've ever seen. Either PBS needs to beef up studio security or I need to stop using Ambien to sleep.

item.title: Error Code
item.description: [#1024] It has a section on motherboard beep codes that lists, for each beep pattern, a song that syncs up well with it.

item.title: Tumblr
item.description: [#1025] Dot Tumblr Dot Com, on the other hand, would be an awful name for a band, if only because of how hard it would be to direct people to your band's website.

item.title: Compare and Contrast
item.description: [#1026] Frankly, I see no difference between thee and a summer's day. Only Ron Paul offers a TRUE alternative!

item.title: Pickup Artist
item.description: [#1027] Son, don't try to play 'make you feel bad' with the Michael Jordan of making you feel bad.

item.title: Communication
item.description: [#1028] Anyone who says that they're great at communicating but 'people are bad at listening' is confused about how communication works.

item.title: Drawing Stars
item.description: [#1029] Screw these 36-degree angles. I'm converting to Judaism.

item.title: Keyed
item.description: [#1030] I was sure he was just getting revenge, but then he did the same thing to Carrie Underwood. Then he mailed me a scone. I think I'm giving up dating.

item.title: s/keyboard/leopard/
item.description: [#1031] Problem Exists Between Leopard And Chair

item.title: Networking
item.description: [#1032] Our company is agile and lean with a focus on the long tail. Ok, our company is actually a polecat I found in my backyard.

item.title: Formal Logic
item.description: [#1033] Note that this implies you should NOT honk solely because I stopped for a pedestrian and you're behind me.

item.title: Share Buttons
item.description: [#1034] The only post to achieve perfect balance between the four was a hilarious joke about Mark Zuckerberg getting caught using a pseudonym to sneak past the TSA.

item.title: Cadbury Eggs
item.description: [#1035] When they moved production from New Zealand to the UK and switched from the runny white centers to the thick, frosting-like filling, it got way harder to cook them scrambled.

item.title: Reviews
item.description: [#1036] I plugged in this lamp and my dog went rigid, spoke a sentence of perfect Akkadian, and then was hurled sideways through the picture window. Even worse, it's one of those lamps where the switch is on the cord.

item.title: Umwelt
item.description: [#1037] Umwelt is the idea that because their senses pick up on different things, different animals in the same ecosystem actually live in very different worlds. Everything about you shapes the world you inhabit--from your ideology to your glasses prescription to your web browser.

item.title: Fountain
item.description: [#1038] Implausible, did you say? Sorry, couldn't quite hear you from all the way up heeeeeeeeere!

item.title: RuBisCO
item.description: [#1039] Bruce Schneier believes safewords are fundamentally insecure and recommends that you ask your partner to stop via public key signature.

item.title: Lakes and Oceans
item.description: [#1040] James Cameron has said that he didn't know its song would be so beautiful. He didn't close the door in time. He's sorry.

item.title: Whites of Their Eyes
item.description: [#1041] Don't fire until you see through the fragile facade to the human being within.

item.title: Never
item.description: [#1042] I'll never forget you--at least, the parts of you that were important red flags.

item.title: Ablogalypse
item.description: [#1043] Plus the reaction in the Tumblverse is always 'repeatedly get hit by a dog and fall down the stairs'.

item.title: Romney Quiz
item.description: [#1044] Charlie actually delivered the Medicare line almost verbatim in the 1971 movie's Fizzy Lifting Drink scene, but it was ultimately cut from the final release.

item.title: Constraints
item.description: [#1045] [title-text similarly alphabetized]

item.title: Skynet
item.description: [#1046] 'YOUR CLOTHES. GIVE THEM TO ME.' 'Shit, uh ... you are now breathing manually!' 'I AM ALWAYS BREATHING MANUALLY.'

item.title: Approximations
item.description: [#1047] Two tips: 1) 8675309 is not just prime, it's a twin prime, and 2) if you ever find yourself raising log(anything)^e or taking the pi-th root of anything, set down the marker and back away from the whiteboard; something has gone horribly wrong.

item.title: Emotion
item.description: [#1048] Fortunately, the internet has a virtually inexhaustible supply of code that doesn't work and people who are wrong, which bodes well for a return to normalcy. [Note: Click to read context for the cancer comics. She's doing well.]

item.title: Bookshelf
item.description: [#1049] I had a hard time with Ayn Rand because I found myself enthusiastically agreeing with the first 90% of every sentence, but getting lost at 'therefore, be a huge asshole to everyone.'

item.title: Forgot Algebra
item.description: [#1050] The only things you HAVE to know are how to make enough of a living to stay alive and how to get your taxes done. All the fun parts of life are optional.

item.title: Visited
item.description: [#1051] I hate when I read something like '... tension among the BASE jumpers nearly led to wingsuit combat ...', and I get excited because 'wingsuit combat' is underlined, only to find that it's just separate links to the 'wingsuit' and 'combat' articles.

item.title: Every Major's Terrible
item.description: [#1052] Someday I'll be the first to get a Ph. D in 'Undeclared'.

item.title: Ten Thousand
item.description: [#1053] Saying 'what kind of an idiot doesn't know about the Yellowstone supervolcano' is so much more boring than telling someone about the Yellowstone supervolcano for the first time.

item.title: Thebacon
item.description: [#1054] Normally pronounced 'THEH-buh-kon', I assume.

item.title: Kickstarter
item.description: [#1055] If you pledge more than $50 you'll get on the VIP list and have first dibs on a slot on ANY of the pledge levels in the actual campaign.

item.title: Felidae
item.description: [#1056] 'Smilodon fatalis' narrowly edged out 'Tyrannosaurus rex' to win this year's Most Badass Latin Names competition, after edging out 'Dracorex hogwartsia' and 'Stygimoloch spinifer' (meaning 'horned dragon from the river of death') in the semifinals.

item.title: Klout
item.description: [#1057] Though please do confirm that it's actually *me* on Klout first, and not one of my friends trying to get me punched. The great thing about this douchebag deadman switch is that I will never dare trigger it.

item.title: Old-Timers
item.description: [#1058] You were on the internet before I was born? Well, so was I.

item.title: Bel-Air
item.description: [#1059] Aaron Sorkin has been tapped to write the TV movie about the aging prince's eventual election to Pat Toomey's Senate seat, currently titled either 'FRESHman Senator' or 'Mr. Smith Goes to Washington'.

item.title: Crowdsourcing
item.description: [#1060] We don't sell products; we sell the marketplace. And by 'sell the marketplace' we mean 'play shooters, sometimes for upwards of 20 hours straight.'

item.title: EST
item.description: [#1061] The month names are the same, except that the fourth month only has the name 'April' in even-numbered years, and is otherwise unnamed.

item.title: Budget News
item.description: [#1062] I will vote, no questions asked, for any candidate who describes themselves as 'more of a deficit sugar glider.'

item.title: Kill Hitler
item.description: [#1063] Revised directive: It is forbidden for you to interfere with human history until you've at least taken a class on it.

item.title: Front Door
item.description: [#1064] FYI: I'll be releasing a wolf into a randomly-chosen front yard sometime in the next 30 years. Now your fear is reasonable, and you don't need to feel embarrassed anymore. Problem solved!
