item.title: Shoes
item.description: [#1065] I *do* hear that they're the most comfortable thing to wear on your feet since sliced bread.

item.title: Laundry
item.description: [#1066] During the second semester, the path is briefly routed through the dishwasher.

item.title: Pressures
item.description: [#1067] Everyone's caught by surprise when a theory of quantum gravity is developed by a sound technician wearing patent leather shoes while editing Clerks II.

item.title: Swiftkey
item.description: [#1068] Although the Markov chain-style text model is still rudimentary; it recently gave me "Massachusetts Institute of America". Although I have to admit it sounds prestigious.

item.title: Alphabet
item.description: [#1069] Do I get to remove letters entirely? Or just rearrange them? Because the 'k/c' situation is ridiculous. Look, we can make out whenever. This is *immortality*!

item.title: Words for Small Sets
item.description: [#1070] If things are too quiet, try asking a couple of friends whether "a couple" should always mean "two". As with the question of how many spaces should go after a period, it can turn acrimonious surprisingly fast unless all three of them agree.

item.title: Exoplanets
item.description: [#1071] Planets are turning out to be so common that to show all the planets in our galaxy, this chart would have to be nested in itself--with each planet replaced by a copy of the chart--at least three levels deep.

item.title: Seventies
item.description: [#1072] Hey, man, the 1670s called. They were like 'Wherefore this demonic intrument? By what orcery does it produce uch ounds?"

item.title: Weekend
item.description: [#1073] Of the two Garfields, you wouldn't think the cat would turn out to be the more compelling presidential speechwriter, but there you go.

item.title: Moon Landing
item.description: [#1074] Ok, so Spirit and Opportunity are pretty awesome. And Kepler. And New Horizons, Cassini, Curiosity, TiME, and Project M. But c'mon, if the Earth were a basketball, in 40 years no human's been more than half an inch from the surface.

item.title: Warning
item.description: [#1075] Also possibly several miles beyond that.

item.title: Groundhog Day
item.description: [#1076] If you closely examine the cosmic background radiation, you can pick up lingering echoes of 'I Got You Babe'.

item.title: Home Organization
item.description: [#1077] Lifehacking!

item.title: Knights
item.description: [#1078] 1. Nf3 ... 2. Nc3 ... 0-1

item.title: United Shapes
item.description: [#1079] That eggplant is in something of a flaccid state.

item.title: Visual Field
item.description: [#1080] I recently learned something that solved a mystery that had bugged me since childhood--why, when I looked at an analog clock, the hand would sometimes seem to take a couple seconds to start ticking. Google "stopped clock illusion".

item.title: Argument Victory
item.description: [#1081] Really, the comforting side in most conspiracy theory arguments is the one claiming that anyone who's in power has any plan at all.

item.title: Geology
item.description: [#1082] That's a gneiss butte.

item.title: Writing Styles
item.description: [#1083] I liked the idea, suggested by h00k on bash.org, of a Twitter bot that messages prominent politicians to tell them when they've unnecessarily used sms-speak abbreviations despite having plenty of characters left.

item.title: Server Problem
item.description: [#1084] Protip: Annoy Ray Kurzweil by always referring to it as the 'Cybersingularity'.

item.title: ContextBot
item.description: [#1085] If you read all vaguebooking/vaguetweeting with the assumption that they're saying everything they can without revealing classified military information, the internet gets way more exciting.

item.title: Eyelash Wish Log
item.description: [#1086] Ooh, another one. Uh ... the ability to alter any coefficients of friction at will during sporting events.

item.title: Cirith Ungol
item.description: [#1087] My all-time favorite example of syntactic ambiguity comes from Wikipedia: 'Charlotte's Web is a children's novel by American author E. B. White, about a pig named Wilbur who is saved from being slaughtered by an intelligent spider named Charlotte.'

item.title: Five Years
item.description: [#1088] 'Well, no further questions. You're hired!' 'Oh, sorry! I'm no longer interested. There's a bunch of future I gotta go check out!'

item.title: Internal Monologue
item.description: [#1089] Oh right, eye contact. Ok, good, holding the eye contact ... holding ... still holding ... ok, too long! Getting weird! Quick, look thoughtfully into space and nod. Oh, dammit, said 'yeah' again!

item.title: Formal Languages
item.description: [#1090] [audience looks around] 'What just happened?' 'There must be some context we're missing.'

item.title: Curiosity
item.description: [#1091] As of this writing the NASA/JPL websites are still overloaded. Trying CURIOSITY-REAR-CAM_[256px_x_256px].torrent.SwEsUb.DVDRip.XviD-aXXo.jpg instead.

item.title: Michael Phelps
item.description: [#1092] [shortly] ... he ate ALL of it!?

item.title: Forget
item.description: [#1093] 'Baby Got Back' turned 20 this year. My favorite nostalgia show is VH1's 'I Love The Inexorable March of Time Toward the Grave That Awaits Us All.'

item.title: Interview
item.description: [#1094] Hey, before you go, can you explain to me what job I now have?

item.title: Crazy Straws
item.description: [#1095] The new crowd is heavily shaped by this guy named Eric, who's basically the Paris Hilton of the amateur plastic crazy straw design world.

item.title: Clinically Studied Ingredient
item.description: [#1096] Blatantly banking on customers not understanding that it's like a Hollywood studio advertising that their new movie was 'watched by Roger Ebert'.

item.title: A Hypochondriac's Nightmare
item.description: [#1097] BUT WHAT IF I REASSURE MYSELF WITH A JOKE AND THEN DON'T WORRY ABOUT THE RASH AND IT TURNS OUT TO BE DEATH MITES AND I COULD HAVE CAUGHT IT

item.title: Star Ratings
item.description: [#1098] I got lost and wandered into the world's creepiest cemetery, where the headstones just had names and star ratings. Freaked me out. When I got home I tried to leave the cemetery a bad review on Yelp, but as my hand hovered over the 'one star' button I felt this distant chill ...

item.title: Tuesdays
item.description: [#1099] Try our bottomless drinks and fall forever!

item.title: Vows
item.description: [#1100] So, um. Do you want to get a drink after the game?

item.title: Sketchiness
item.description: [#1101] factory --- spire --- onslaught --- extractor --- judge

item.title: Fastest-Growing
item.description: [#1102] I lead a small but extraordinarily persuasive religion whose only members are door-to-door proselytizers from other faiths.

item.title: Nine
item.description: [#1103] FYI: If you get curious and start trying to calculate the time adjustment function that minimizes the gap between the most-used and least-used digit (for a representative sample of common cook times) without altering any time by more than 10%, and someone asks you what you're doing, it's easier to just lie.

item.title: Feathers
item.description: [#1104] Click to see a video of a modern bird using stability flapping during predatory behavior. It all fits! Also, apparently Microraptor had *four* wings? The past keeps getting cooler! (And there's more of it every day!)

item.title: License Plate
item.description: [#1105] The next day: 'What? Six bank robberies!? But I just vandalized the library!' 'Nice try. They saw your plate with all the 1's and I's.' 'That's impossible! I've been with my car the whole ti-- ... wait. Ok, wow, that was clever of her.'

item.title: ADD
item.description: [#1106] 20 balloons float away while I'm busy permanently tying one to a tree to deal with it for good. Unfortunately, that one balloon was 'land a rocket on the moon in Kerbal Space Program.'

item.title: Sports Cheat Sheet
item.description: [#1107] I would subscribe to a Twitter feed that supplied you with one reasonable sports opinion per day, like 'The Red Sox can't make the playoffs (championship games), but in last night's game their win seriously damaged the chances of the Yankees (longstanding rival team).'

item.title: Cautionary Ghost
item.description: [#1108] But then the Ghost of Subjunctive Past showed up and told me to stay strong on 'if it were'.

item.title: Refrigerator
item.description: [#1109] I want this engraved on my tombstone like the Epitaph of Stevinus.

item.title: Click and Drag
item.description: [#1110] Click and drag.

item.title: Premiere
item.description: [#1111] 'But what's the buzz about the film?' 'We're hoping it's distracting.'

item.title: Think Logically
item.description: [#1112] I've developed a more logical set of rules but the people on the chess community have a bunch of stupid emotional biases and won't reply to my posts.

item.title: Killed In Action
item.description: [#1113] We can't let this happen again. We need to build a secure TWO-day-before-retirement safe room.

item.title: Metallurgy
item.description: [#1114] This exotic blade was wrought from a different fallen star. The meteorite was a carbonaceous chondrite, so it's basically a lump of gravel glued into the shape of a sword. A SPACE sword!

item.title: Sky
item.description: [#1115] I dropped a bird and I didn't hear it hit bottom.

item.title: Traffic Lights
item.description: [#1116] There's an intersection I drive through sometimes that has a forward green arrow, a red light, and a 'no turns' sign all on one pole. I honestly have no idea what it's telling me to do.

item.title: My Sky
item.description: [#1117] According to my mom, my first word was (looking up at the sky) 'Wow!'

item.title: Microsoft
item.description: [#1118] Facebook, Apple, and Google all got away with their monopolist power grabs because they don't have any 'S's in their names for critics to snarkily replace with '$'s.

item.title: Undoing
item.description: [#1119] I've been sneaking out at night and installing lamps on the underside of every photovoltaic panel I can find. Sure, there are upwards of 80% losses, but I prefer to think of them as nearly 20% gains.

item.title: Blurring the Line
item.description: [#1120] People into masturbatory navel-gazing have a lot to learn about masturbation.

item.title: Identity
item.description: [#1121] Not sure why I just taught everyone to flawlessly impersonate me to pretty much anyone I know. Just remember to constantly bring up how cool it is that birds are dinosaurs and you'll be set.

item.title: Electoral Precedent
item.description: [#1122] No white guy who's been mentioned on Twitter has gone on to win.

item.title: The Universal Label
item.description: [#1123] Works for any grocery or non-grocery. Even thyme is just H and time.

item.title: Law of Drama
item.description: [#1124] 'Drama' is just 'people being upset', when someone says they're always surrounded by drama and they just ignore it, it starts to make sense that their strategy might be backfiring.

item.title: Objects In Mirror
item.description: [#1125] Universes in mirror, like those in windshield, are larger than they appear.

item.title: Epsilon and Zeta
item.description: [#1126] The average error in the NHC forecasted position of a hurricane three days in the future has shrunk to a third of what it was in 1990--a staggering accomplishment. However, as you may have gathered, forecasts of future storm *strength* have proved more difficult to improve.

item.title: Congress
item.description: [#1127] It'd be great if some news network started featuring partisan hack talking heads who were all Federalists and Jacksonians, just to see how long it took us to catch on.

item.title: Fifty Shades
item.description: [#1128] Wishbone and the Illustrated Classics series have gotten me through every conversation I've ever had about Dickens, Treasure Island, The Anarchist's Cookbook, and Our Bodies, Ourselves.

item.title: Cell Number
item.description: [#1129] There's also a +1 sometimes, which is there to keep everyone on their toes. In the future, people who got to pick cool numbers by signing up for Google Voice early will be revered as wizards.

item.title: Poll Watching
item.description: [#1130] The choices we make Tuesday could have MASSIVE and PERMANENT effects on the charts on Nate Silver's blog!

item.title: Math
item.description: [#1131] As of this writing, the only thing that's 'razor-thin' or 'too close to call' is the gap between the consensus poll forecast and the result.

item.title: Frequentists vs. Bayesians
item.description: [#1132] 'Detector! What would the Bayesian statistician say if I asked him whether the--' [roll] 'I AM A NEUTRINO DETECTOR, NOT A LABYRINTH GUARD. SERIOUSLY, DID YOUR BRAIN FALL OUT?' [roll] '... yes.'

item.title: Up Goer Five
item.description: [#1133] Another thing that is a bad problem is if you're flying toward space and the parts start to fall off your space car in the wrong order. If that happens, it means you won't go to space today, or maybe ever.

item.title: Logic Boat
item.description: [#1134] Or a cabbage, for that matter. The goat makes sense. Goats are fine.

item.title: Arachnoneurology
item.description: [#1135] SPIDER PSYCHOLOGY (21st Ed.) is a comprehensive overview of arachnoneurology, neuro-arachnology, forensic arachnology, neuro-arachnoneurology (the study of the brains of spider neurology experts), and arachnoarachnology (the study of too many spiders).

item.title: Broken Mirror
item.description: [#1136] 'I see you're in this mood again.' 'I am always in this mood.'

item.title: LTR
item.description: [#1137] Collaborative editing can quickly become a textual rap battle fought with increasingly convoluted invocations of U+202a to U+202e.

item.title: Heatmap
item.description: [#1138] There are also a lot of global versions of this map showing traffic to English-language websites which are indistinguishable from maps of the location of internet users who are native English speakers.

item.title: Rubber and Glue
item.description: [#1139] I'm rubber. You're rubber. We contemplate the reality of our existence in mute, vulcanized horror.

item.title: Calendar of Meaningful Dates
item.description: [#1140] In months other than September, the 11th is mentioned substantially less often than any other date. It's been that way since long before 9/11 and I have no idea why.

item.title: Two Years
item.description: [#1141] She won the first half of all our chemo Scrabble games, but then her IV drugs started kicking in and I *dominated*.

item.title: Coverage
item.description: [#1142] My resonant tunneling diode phone has limited range but a short enough wavelength to penetrate even the densest cages. This gives me a major combat advantage, hopefully.

item.title: Location
item.description: [#1143] Ingress: Foursquare With Space Noises.

item.title: Tags
item.description: [#1144] : Like this.

item.title: Sky Color
item.description: [#1145] Feynman recounted another good one upperclassmen would use on freshmen physics students: When you look at words in a mirror, how come they're reversed left to right but not top to bottom? What's special about the horizontal axis?

item.title: Honest
item.description: [#1146] I didn't understand what you meant. I still don't. But I'll figure it out soon!

item.title: Evolving
item.description: [#1147] Biologists play reverse Pokmon, trying to avoid putting any one team member on the front lines long enough for the experience to cause evolution.

item.title: Nothing to Offer
item.description: [#1148] cerebrospinal fluid, pericardial fluid, sputum, aqueous humor, perilymph, chyme, hydatid fluid, interstitial fluid, rheum, and gin.

item.title: Broomstick
item.description: [#1149] 'Broom first, then slippers.' 'How do I know you'll return the broom once you've secured your ticket?' 'I'll leave my little dog as collateral.' 'Great. Pleasure doing business!'

item.title: Instagram
item.description: [#1150] I'm gonna call the cops and get Chad arrested for theft, then move all my stuff to the house across the street. Hopefully the owners there are more responsible.

item.title: Tests
item.description: [#1151] In fact, one of the boxes is full of Staphylococcus. The wrapping paper is coated in E. coli, though, so it's an understandable mistake. You know, we should really stop accepting gifts from that guy.

item.title: Communion
item.description: [#1152] The local police, growing increasingly concerned about this church, ask parishioners to take a sip of wine and then spit it back out for DNA testing. It's blood, and it matches a 1970s murder victim.

item.title: Proof
item.description: [#1153] The prosecution calls Gottfried Leibniz.

item.title: Resolution
item.description: [#1154] If at first you don't succeed, that's one data point.

item.title: Kolmogorov Directions
item.description: [#1155] People get really grumpy when they realize you're giving them directions for how to go to the store and buy a GPS.

item.title: Conditioning
item.description: [#1156] 'Why are you standing in the yard wearing a papal hat and a robe covered in seeds?' 'Well, the Pope is visiting our town next month ...'

item.title: Sick Day
item.description: [#1157] Wikipedia path: Virus -> Immune system -> Innate immune system -> Parasites -> List of parasites of humans -> Naegleria fowleri -> Primary amoebic meningoencephalitis -> Deciding I DEFINITELY shouldn't connect an aquarium pump to my sinuses

item.title: Rubber Sheet
item.description: [#1158] It IS about physics. It ALL is.

item.title: Countdown
item.description: [#1159] For all we know, the odds are in our favor.

item.title: Drop Those Pounds
item.description: [#1160] If the flyers don't work, we'll switch to the LEAST subtle method of informing a town of the existence of a trebuchet club.

item.title: Hand Sanitizer
item.description: [#1161] Hipster CDC Reports Flu Epidemic Peaked Years Ago

item.title: Log Scale
item.description: [#1162] Knuth Paper-Stack Notation: Write down the number on pages. Stack them. If the stack is too tall to fit in the room, write down the number of pages it would take to write down the number. THAT number won't fit in the room? Repeat. When a stack fits, write the number of iterations on a card. Pin it to the stack.

item.title: Debugger
item.description: [#1163] It can take a site a while to figure out that there's a problem with their 'report a bug' form.

item.title: Home Alone
item.description: [#1164] Starring Macaulay Culkin.

item.title: Amazon
item.description: [#1165] Amazon.com took a surprise early lead with 'Time required to transport a package from Iquitos, Peru to Manaus, Brazil' but then lost it at 'Minutes to skeletonize a cow'.

item.title: Argument
item.description: [#1166] The misguided search for a perpetual motion machine has run substantially longer than any attempted perpetual motion machine.

item.title: Star Trek into Darkness
item.description: [#1167] Of course, factions immediately sprang up in favor of '~*~sTaR tReK iNtO dArKnEsS~*~', 'xX_StAr TrEk InTo DaRkNess_Xx', and 'Star Trek lnto Darkness' (that's a lowercase 'L').

item.title: tar
item.description: [#1168] I don't know what's worse--the fact that after 15 years of using tar I still can't keep the flags straight, or that after 15 years of technological advancement I'm still mucking with tar flags that were 15 years old when I started.

item.title: Expedition
item.description: [#1169] I'm pretty sure I've logged more hours in Google Maps over the past decade than in any game.

item.title: Bridge
item.description: [#1170] And it says a lot about you that when your friends jump off a bridge en masse, your first thought is apparently 'my friends are all foolish and I won't be like them' and not 'are my friends ok?'.

item.title: Perl Problems
item.description: [#1171] To generate #1 albums, 'jay --help' recommends the -z flag.

item.title: Workflow
item.description: [#1172] There are probably children out there holding down spacebar to stay warm in the winter! YOUR UPDATE MURDERS CHILDREN.

item.title: Steroids
item.description: [#1173] A human is a system for converting dust billions of years ago into dust billions of years from now via a roundabout process which involves checking email a lot.

item.title: App
item.description: [#1174] If I click 'no', I've probably given up on everything, so don't bother taking me to the page I was trying to go to. Just drop me on the homepage. Thanks.

item.title: Moving Sidewalks
item.description: [#1175] I think I could spend hours just stepping on and off of conveyor belts moving at various speeds.

item.title: Those Not Present
item.description: [#1176] 'Yeah, that squid's a total asshole.' [scoot scoot]

item.title: Time Robot
item.description: [#1177] NO FATE BUT THE NARRATIVES WE IMPOSE ON LIFE'S RANDOM CHAOS TO DISTRACT OURSELVES FROM OUR EXISTENTIAL PLIGHT

item.title: Pickup Artists
item.description: [#1178] It sounds like a great way to make friends! Is it near that Friend Zone you keep talking about? I wanna go!

item.title: ISO 8601
item.description: [#1179] ISO 8601 was published on 06/05/88 and most recently amended on 12/01/04.

item.title: Virus Venn Diagram
item.description: [#1180] Within five minutes of the Singularity appearing, somebody will suggest defragging it.

item.title: PGP
item.description: [#1181] If you want to be extra safe, check that there's a big block of jumbled characters at the bottom.

item.title: Rembrandt Photo
item.description: [#1182] ::click:: Come back! You didn't see the one of Whistler's mother!

item.title: Rose Petals
item.description: [#1183] Joke's on you--the Roomba and I had a LOVELY evening.

item.title: Circumference Formula
item.description: [#1184] Assume r' refers to the radius of Earth Prime, and r'' means radius in inches.

item.title: Ineffective Sorts
item.description: [#1185] StackSort connects to StackOverflow, searches for 'sort a list', and downloads and runs code snippets until the list is sorted.

item.title: Bumblebees
item.description: [#1186] Did you know sociologists can't explain why people keep repeating that urban legend about bumblebees not being able to fly!?

item.title: Aspect Ratio
item.description: [#1187] I'm always disappointed when 'Anamorphic Widescreen' doesn't refer to a widescreen Animorphs movie.

item.title: Bonding
item.description: [#1188] I'm trying to build character but Eclipse is really confusing.

item.title: Voyager 1
item.description: [#1189] So far Voyager 1 has 'left the Solar System' by passing through the termination shock three times, the heliopause twice, and once each through the heliosheath, heliosphere, heliodrome, auroral discontinuity, Heaviside layer, trans-Neptunian panic zone, magnetogap, US Census Bureau Solar System statistical boundary, Kuiper gauntlet, Oort void, and crystal sphere holding the fixed stars.

item.title: Time
item.description: [#1190] The end.

item.title: The Past
item.description: [#1191] If history has taught us anything, we can use that information to destroy it.

item.title: Humming
item.description: [#1192] I'm so bad at carrying a tune, those 'find a song by humming its melody' websites throw an HTTP 406 error as soon as I start to hum.

item.title: Externalities
item.description: [#1193]

item.title: Stratigraphic Record
item.description: [#1194] All we have are these stupid tantalizing zircons and the scars on the face of the Moon.

item.title: Flowchart
item.description: [#1195] The way out is to use the marker you have to add a box that says 'get a marker' to the line between you and 'start', then add a 'no' line from the trap box to 'end'.

item.title: Subways
item.description: [#1196] About one in three North American subway stops are in NYC.

item.title: All Adobe Updates
item.description: [#1197] ALERT: Some pending mandatory software updates require version 21.1.2 of the Oracle/Sun Java(tm) JDK(tm) Update Manager Runtime Environment Meta-Updater, which is not available for your platform.

item.title: Geologist
item.description: [#1198] 'It seems like it's still alive, Professor.' 'Yeah, a big one like this can keep running around for a few billion years after you remove the head."

item.title: Silence
item.description: [#1199] All music is just performances of 4'33" in studios where another band happened to be playing at the time.

item.title: Authorization
item.description: [#1200] Before you say anything, no, I know not to leave my computer sitting out logged in to all my accounts. I have it set up so after a few minutes of inactivity it automatically switches to my brother's.

item.title: Integration by Parts
item.description: [#1201] If you can manage to choose u and v such that u = v = x, then the answer is just (1/2)x^2, which is easy to remember. Oh, and add a '+C' or you'll get yelled at.

item.title: Girls and Boys
item.description: [#1202] To get more knowledge

item.title: Time Machines
item.description: [#1203] 'All time machine systems nominal ... T-minus ten ... eleven ...'

item.title: Detail
item.description: [#1204] 2031: Google defends the swiveling roof-mounted scanning electron microscopes on its Street View cars, saying they 'don't reveal anything that couldn't be seen by any pedestrian scanning your house with an electron microscope.'

item.title: Is It Worth the Time?
item.description: [#1205] Don't forget the time you spend finding the chart to look up what you save. And the time spent reading this reminder about the time spent. And the time trying to figure out if either of those actually make sense. Remember, every second counts toward your life total, including these right now.

item.title: Einstein
item.description: [#1206] Einstein was WRONG when he said that provisional patent #39561 represented a novel gravel-sorting technique and should be approved by the Patent Office.

item.title: AirAware
item.description: [#1207] It ships with a version of Google Now that alerts you when it's too late to leave for your appointments.

item.title: Footnote Labyrinths
item.description: [#1208] Every time you read this mouseover, toggle between interpreting nested footnotes as footnotes on footnotes and interpreting them as exponents (minus one, modulo 6, plus 1).

item.title: Encoding
item.description: [#1209] I don't see how; the C0 block is right there at the beginning.

item.title: I'm So Random
item.description: [#1210] In retrospect, it's weird that as a kid I thought completely random outbursts made me seem interesting, given that from an information theory point of view, lexical white noise is just about the opposite of interesting by definition.

item.title: Birds and Dinosaurs
item.description: [#1211] Sure, T. rex is closer in height to Stegosaurus than a sparrow. But that doesn't tell you much; 'Dinosaur Comics' author Ryan North is closer in height to certain dinosaurs than to the average human.

item.title: Interstellar Memes
item.description: [#1212] The strongest incentive we have to develop faster-than-light travel is that it would let us apologize in advance.

item.title: Combination Vision Test
item.description: [#1213] If you see two numbers but they're both the same and you have to squint to read them, you have synesthesia, colorblindness, diplopia, and myopia.

item.title: Geoguessr
item.description: [#1214] I'm not sure if you can get Epcot, but my friend just got LegoLand. He guessed California but it was the one in Denmark. Meanwhile, I'm rapidly becoming a connoisseur of unmarked dirt roads over flat, barren landscapes.

item.title: Insight
item.description: [#1215] The great thing is, the sentence is really just a reminder to the listener to worry about whatever aspects of the technology they're already feeling alarmist about, which in their mind gives you credit for addressing their biggest anxieties.

item.title: Sticks and Stones
item.description: [#1216] Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words can make me think I deserved it.

item.title: Cells
item.description: [#1217] Now, if it selectively kills cancer cells in a petri dish, you can be sure it's at least a great breakthrough for everyone suffering from petri dish cancer.

item.title: Doors of Durin
item.description: [#1218] If we get the doors open and plug up the dam on the Sirannon so the water rises a little, the pool will start draining into Moria. How do you think the Watcher would fare against a drenched Balrog?

item.title: Reports
item.description: [#1219] If that fails, just multiply every number by a thousand. 'The 2nd St speed limit should be set at 25,000 mph, which would likely have prevented 1,000 of the intersection's 3,000 serious accidents last month.'

item.title: Hipsters
item.description: [#1220] You may point out that this very retreat into ironic detachment while still clearly participating in the thing in question is the very definition of contemporary hipsterdom. But on the other hand, wait, you're in an empty room. Who are you talking to?

item.title: Nomenclature
item.description: [#1221] [shouted, from the field] 'Aunt Beast hit a pop fly to second! Dive for it, Mrs Whatsit!'

item.title: Pastime
item.description: [#1222] Good thing we're too smart to spend all day being uselessly frustrated with ourselves. I mean, that'd be a hell of a waste, right?

item.title: Dwarf Fortress
item.description: [#1223] I may be the kind of person who wastes a year implementing a Turing-complete computer in Dwarf Fortress, but that makes you the kind of person who wastes ten more getting that computer to run Minecraft.

item.title: Council of 300
item.description: [#1224] 'And hypnotize someone into thinking they've uploaded it and passed it around.' 'But then won't the uploader get suspicious that it pauses at 301+ for a while? Why don't we just forge the number entirel--' ::BLAM:: 'The Council of 299 is adjourned.'

item.title: Ice Sheets
item.description: [#1225] Data adapted from 'The Laurentide and Innuitian ice sheets during the Last Glacial Maximum' by A.S. Dyke et. al., which was way better than the sequels 'The Laurentide and Innuitian ice sheets during the Last Glacial Maximum: The Meltdown' and 'The Laurentide and Innuitian ice sheets during the Last Glacial Maximum: Continental Drift'.

item.title: Balloon Internet
item.description: [#1226] I run a business selling rural internet access. My infrastructure consists of a bunch of Verizon wifi hotspots that I sign up for and then cancel at the end of the 14-day return period.

item.title: The Pace of Modern Life
item.description: [#1227] 'Unfortunately, the notion of marriage which prevails ... at the present time ... regards the institution as simply a convenient arrangement or formal contract ... This disregard of the sanctity of marriage and contempt for its restrictions is one of the most alarming tendencies of the present age.' --John Harvey Kellogg, Ladies' guide in health and disease (1883)

item.title: Prometheus
item.description: [#1228] 'I'm here to return what Prometheus stole.' would be a good thing to say if you were a fighter pilot in a Michael Bay movie where for some reason the world's militaries had to team up to defeat every god from human mythology, and you'd just broken through the perimeter and gotten a missile lock on Mount Olympus.

item.title: Screensaver
item.description: [#1229] I'm entering my 24th year of spending eight hours a day firing the Duck Hunt gun at the flying toasters. I'm sure I'll hit one soon.

item.title: Polar/Cartesian
item.description: [#1230] Protip: Any two-axis graph can be re-labeled 'coordinates of the ants crawling across my screen as a function of time'.

item.title: Habitable Zone
item.description: [#1231] They have a telescope pointed RIGHT AT US!

item.title: Realistic Criteria
item.description: [#1232] I'm leaning toward fifteen. There are a lot of them.

item.title: Relativity
item.description: [#1233] It's commonly believed that Lorentz contraction makes objects appear flatter along the direction of travel. However, this ignores light travel times. In fact, a fast-moving butt would appear rotated toward the observer but not substantially distorted. Shakira was right.

item.title: Douglas Engelbart (1925-2013)
item.description: [#1234] Actual quote from The Demo: '... an advantage of being online is that it keeps track of who you are and what youre doing all the time ...'

item.title: Settled
item.description: [#1235] Well, we've really only settled the question of ghosts that emit or reflect visible light. Or move objects around. Or make any kind of sound. But that covers all the ones that appear in Ghostbusters, so I think we're good.

item.title: Seashell
item.description: [#1236] This is roughly equivalent to 'number of times I've picked up a seashell at the ocean' / 'number of times I've picked up a seashell', which in my case is pretty close to 1, and gets much closer if we're considering only times I didn't put it to my ear.

item.title: QR Code
item.description: [#1237] Remember, the installer is watching the camera for the checksum it generated, so you have to scan it using your own phone.

item.title: Enlightenment
item.description: [#1238] But the rules of writing are like magic spells. If you never acquire them, then not using them says nothing.

item.title: Social Media
item.description: [#1239] The social media reaction to this asteroid announcement has been sharply negative. Care to respond?

item.title: Quantum Mechanics
item.description: [#1240] You can also just ignore any science assertion where 'quantum mechanics' is the most complicated phrase in it.

item.title: Annoying Ringtone Champion
item.description: [#1241] It beat out 'Clock radio alarm', 'B-flat at 194 decibels', 'That noise from Dumb & Dumber', and 'Recording of a sobbing voice begging you to answer'.

item.title: Scary Names
item.description: [#1242] Far off to the right of the chart is the Helvetica Scenario.

item.title: Snare
item.description: [#1243] It's going in A collection of satellites skewered with pins and mounted in display boxes. Not necessarily MY collection.

item.title: Six Words
item.description: [#1244] Ahem. We are STRICTLY an Orbiter shop.

item.title: 10-Day Forecast
item.description: [#1245] Oh, definitely not; they don't have Amazon Prime.

item.title: Pale Blue Dot
item.description: [#1246] Our planet is a lonely speck in the great enveloping cosmic dark. In our obscurity, in all this vastness, there is no hint that help will come from elsewhere to save us from ourselves. There is no road out of this oblivion; we must embrace it. We must join with the darkness. Ba'al the Annihilator offers us no happiness, no answers, naught but the cold embrace of the void. To imagine any other end is delusion. We must give in to the will of Ba'al, for he will one day consume us and our world alike. I therefore call on Congress to fully fund space exploration, and to join with Ba'al, the Eater of Souls. Thank you.

item.title: The Mother of All Suspicious Files
item.description: [#1247] Better change the URL to 'https' before downloading.

item.title: Sphere
item.description: [#1248] This message brought to you by the Society of Astronomers Trapped on the Surface of a Sphere.

item.title: Meteor Showers
item.description: [#1249] Remember, meteors always hit the tallest object around.

item.title: Old Accounts
item.description: [#1250] If you close an account while it's still friends with people, it contributes to database linkage accumulation slowdown, which is a major looming problem for web infrastructure and definitely not a thing I just made up.

item.title: Anti-Glass
item.description: [#1251] 'Why don't you just point it at their eye directly?' 'What is this, 2007?'

item.title: Increased Risk
item.description: [#1252] You may point out that strictly speaking, you can use that statement to prove that all risks are tiny--to which I reply HOLY SHIT WATCH OUT FOR THAT DOG!

item.title: Exoplanet Names
item.description: [#1253] If you have any ideas, I hear you can send them to iaupublic@iap.fr.

item.title: Preferred Chat System
item.description: [#1254] If you call my regular number, it just goes to my pager.

item.title: Columbus
item.description: [#1255] And thus was smallpox introduced into the previously Undying Lands.

item.title: Questions
item.description: [#1256] To whoever typed 'why is arwen dying': GOOD. FUCKING. QUESTION.

item.title: Monster
item.description: [#1257] It was finally destroyed with a nuclear weapon carrying the destructive energy of the Hiroshima bomb.

item.title: First
item.description: [#1258] Fortunately, exactly zero other annoying internet behaviors have developed during this time.

item.title: Bee Orchid
item.description: [#1259] In sixty million years aliens will know humans only by a fuzzy clip of a woman in an Axe commercial.

item.title: LD50
item.description: [#1260] The dose is much lower when administered orally. We're still trying to get the paper into the needles for subcutaneous injection.

item.title: Shake That
item.description: [#1261] How do I work it? IT'S ALREADY WORKING!

item.title: Unquote
item.description: [#1262] I guess it's a saying from the Old Country.

item.title: Reassuring
item.description: [#1263] 'At least humans are better at quietly amusing ourselves, oblivious to our pending obsolescence' thought the human, as a nearby Dell Inspiron contentedly displayed the same bouncing geometric shape screensaver it had been running for years.

item.title: Slideshow
item.description: [#1264] Points to anyone who hacks the Flickr devs' computers to make their text editors do this when you click on anything.

item.title: Juicer
item.description: [#1265] But the rind is where all the vitamins are!

item.title: Halting Problem
item.description: [#1266] I found a counterexample to the claim that all things must someday die, but I don't know how to show it to anyone.

item.title: Mess
item.description: [#1267] 'Sorry, I left out my glass of water from last night.' OH GOD I APPARENTLY LIVE IN A GARBAGE PIT.

item.title: Alternate Universe
item.description: [#1268] As best as I can tell, I was transported here from Earth Prime sometime in the late 1990s. Your universe is identical in every way, except for the lobster thing and the thing where some of you occasionally change your clocks for some reason.

item.title: Privacy Opinions
item.description: [#1269] I'm the Philosopher until someone hands me a burrito.

item.title: Functional
item.description: [#1270] Functional programming combines the flexibility and power of abstract mathematics with the intuitive clarity of abstract mathematics.

item.title: Highlighting
item.description: [#1271] And if clicking on any word pops up a site-search for articles about that word, I will close all windows in a panic and never come back.

item.title: Shadowfacts
item.description: [#1272] 'Look to my coming on the fifth day. At dawn, look to the east.' 'And look to the west to see our shadows!'

item.title: Tall Infographics
item.description: [#1273] 'Big Data' doesn't just mean increasing the font size.

item.title: Open Letter
item.description: [#1274] Are you ok? Do you need help?

item.title: int(pi)
item.description: [#1275] If replacing all the '3's doesn't fix your code, remove the 4s, too, with 'ceiling(pi) / floor(pi) * pi * r^floor(pi)'. Mmm, floor pie.

item.title: Angular Size
item.description: [#1276] If the celestial sphere were mapped to the Earth's surface, astronomy would get a LOT easier; you'd just need a magnifying glass.

item.title: Ayn Random
item.description: [#1277] In a cavern deep below the Earth, Ayn Rand, Paul Ryan, Rand Paul, Ann Druyan, Paul Rudd, Alan Alda, and Duran Duran meet together in the Secret Council of /(b[plurandy]+b ?){2}/i.

item.title: Giraffes
item.description: [#1278] If you fund my Kickstarter ...

item.title: Reverse Identity Theft
item.description: [#1279] I asked a few friends whether they'd had this happen, then looked up the popularity of their initials/names over time. Based on those numbers, it looks like there must be at least 750,000 people in the US alone who think 'Sure, that's probably my email address' on a regular basis.

item.title: Mystery News
item.description: [#1280] If you find and stop the video, but you've--against all odds--gotten curious about the trade summit, just leave the tab opened. It will mysteriously start playing again 30 minutes later!

item.title: Minifigs
item.description: [#1281] The LEGO Group is already the world's largest tire manufacturer.

item.title: Monty Hall
item.description: [#1282] A few minutes later, the goat from behind door C drives away in the car.

item.title: Headlines
item.description: [#1283] 1916: 'PHYSICIST DAD' TURNS HIS ATTENTION TO GRAVITY, AND YOU WON'T BELIEVE WHAT HE FINDS. [PICS] [NSFW]

item.title: Improved Keyboard
item.description: [#1284] I'm always installing tons of weird experimental keyboards because it serves as a good reminder that nothing I was going to type was really worth the trouble.

item.title: Third Way
item.description: [#1285] 'The monospaced-typewriter-font story is a COMPLETE FABRICATION! WAKE UP, SHEEPLE' 'It doesn't matter! Studies support single spaces!' 'Those results weren't statistically significant!' 'Fine, you win. I'm using double spaces right now!' 'Are not! We can all hear your stupid whitespace.'

item.title: Encryptic
item.description: [#1286] It was bound to happen eventually. This data theft will enable almost limitless [xkcd.com/792]-style password reuse attacks in the coming weeks. There's only one group that comes out of this looking smart: Everyone who pirated Photoshop.

item.title: Puzzle
item.description: [#1287] Prediction for Carlsen v. Anand: ... 25. Qb8+ Nxb8 26. Rd8# f6 27. "... dude." Qf5 28. "The game is over, dude." Qxg5 29. Rxe8 0-1 30. "Dude, your move can't be '0-1'. Don't write that down." [Black flips board]

item.description: [#1290] You absolute-fucking-... shit.

item.title: Shoot for the Moon
item.description: [#1291] Shoot for the Moon. If you miss, you'll end up co-orbiting the Sun alongside Earth, living out your days alone in the void within sight of the lush, welcoming home you left behind.

item.title: Pi vs. Tau
item.description: [#1292] Conveniently approximated as e+2, Pau is commonly known as the Devil's Ratio (because in the octal expansion, '666' appears four times in the first 200 digits while no other run of 3+ digits appears more than once.)

item.title: Job Interview
item.description: [#1293] When you talk about the job experience you'll give me, why do you pronounce 'job' with a long 'o'?

item.title: Telescope Names
item.description: [#1294] The Thirty Meter Telescope will be renamed The Flesh-Searing Eye on the Volcano.

item.description: [#1298] It's a beautiful day in the neighborhood!

item.title: I Don't Own a TV
item.description: [#1299] Theory: Smugness is proportional to the negative second derivative of TV ownership rate with respect to time.

item.title: Galilean Moons
item.description: [#1300] I'm SO glad I escaped. They almost had me caught in their weird ... thing.

item.title: File Extensions
item.description: [#1301] I have never been lied to by data in a .txt file which has been hand-aligned.

item.title: Year in Review
item.description: [#1302] All in all, I give this year a C-. There were no aurora visible from my house and that comet evaporated. They'd better not cancel the 2017 eclipse.

item.title: Profile Info
item.description: [#1303] It's ok, they'll always let you opt out! Like they did with the YouTube real name profile thing.

item.title: Glass Trolling
item.description: [#1304] Plus, when someone finally grabs your glasses and stomps on them, it costs way less than $1,500 to replace them.

item.title: Undocumented Feature
item.description: [#1305] And it doesn't pop up a box every time asking you to use your real name. In fact, there's no way to set your name at all. You just have to keep reminding people who you are.

item.title: Sigil Cycle
item.description: [#1306] The cycle seems to be 'we need these symbols to clarify what types of things we're referring to!' followed by 'wait, it turns out words already do that.'

item.description: [#1307] The 6 Weirdest Objects The Buzzfeed Writers Are Throwing Out Their Windows At Us

item.title: Christmas Lights
item.description: [#1308] Merry Christmas from xkcd!

item.title: Infinite Scrolling
item.description: [#1309] Maybe we should give up on the whole idea of a 'back' button. 'Show me that thing I was looking at a moment ago' might just be too complicated an idea for the modern web.

item.title: Goldbach Conjectures
item.description: [#1310] The weak twin primes conjecture states that there are infinitely many pairs of primes. The strong twin primes conjecture states that every prime p has a twin prime (p+2), although (p+2) may not look prime at first. The tautological prime conjecture states that the tautological prime conjecture is true.

[#1311] Some future reader, who may see the term, without knowing the history of it, may imagine that it had reference to some antiquated bridge of the immortal Poet, thrown across the silver Avon, to facilitate his escape after some marauding excursion in a neighbouring park; and in some Gentleman's Magazine of the next century, it is not impossible, but that future antiquaries may occupy page after page in discussing so interesting a matter. We think it right, therefore, to put it on record in the Oriental Herald that the 'Shakesperian Rope Bridges' are of much less classic origin; that Mr Colin Shakespear, who, besides his dignity as Postmaster, now signs himself 'Superintendent General of Shakesperian Rope Bridges', is a person of much less genius than the Bard of Avon. --The Oriental Herald, 1825

item.title: Haskell
item.description: [#1312] The problem with Haskell is that it's a language built on lazy evaluation and nobody's actually called for it.

item.title: Regex Golf
item.description: [#1313] /bu|[rn]t|[coy]e|[mtg]a|j|iso|n[hl]|[ae]d|lev|sh|[lnd]i|[po]o|ls/ matches the last names of elected US presidents but not their opponents.

item.title: Photos
item.description: [#1314] I hate when people take photos of their meal instead of eating it, because there's nothing I love more than the sound of other people chewing.

item.title: Questions for God
item.description: [#1315] What sins could possibly darken the heart of a STEAMBOAT? I asked The Shadow, but he says he only covers men.

item.title: Inexplicable
item.description: [#1316] 'It has a ghost in it. Take it back.' 'No.'

item.title: Theft
item.description: [#1317] Is he ALSO wondering at what point our thoughts diverged, if they even have yet? 'dude, I think he just took your credit card' AM I THE ORIGINAL? HOW DO I TELL?

item.title: Actually
item.description: [#1318] Protip: You can win every exchange just by being one level more precise than whoever talked last. Eventually, you'll defeat all conversational opponents and stand alone.

item.title: Automation
item.description: [#1319] 'Automating' comes from the roots 'auto-' meaning 'self-', and 'mating', meaning 'screwing'.

item.title: Walmart
item.description: [#1320] What I really want is to hang out where I hung out with my friends in college, but have all my older relatives there too.

item.title: Cold
item.description: [#1321] 'You see the same pattern all over. Take Detroit--' 'Hold on. Why do you know all these statistics offhand?' 'Oh, um, no idea. I definitely spend my evenings hanging out with friends, and not curating a REALLY NEAT database of temperature statistics. Because, pshh, who would want to do that, right? Also, snowfall records.'

item.title: Winter
item.description: [#1322] Stay warm, little flappers, and find lots of plant eggs!

item.title: Protocol
item.description: [#1323] Changing the names would be easier, but if you're not comfortable lying, try only making friends with people named Alice, Bob, Carol, etc.

item.title: Weather
item.description: [#1324] At least if you're really into, like, Turkish archaeology, store clerks aren't like 'hey, how 'bout those Derinkuyu underground cities!' when they're trying to be polite.

item.title: Rejection
item.description: [#1325] Perhaps you need a crash course in taking hints. Here's your first lesson: We're not actually walking somewhere together; I'm trying to leave this conversation and you're following me.

item.title: Sharks
item.description: [#1326] 'Now, minions, I'm off to inspect our shark cages.' 'Do you really need to inspect them this often?' 'PRISONERS MUST NEVER ESCAPE.'

item.title: Mobile Marketing
item.description: [#1327] We're firing you, but the online headline-writing division wants to hire you.

item.description: [#1328] I have a bunch of things open right now.

item.description: [#1329] At first I was making fun of them, but joke's on me--the deer is surprisingly ergonomic, except for the kicks.

item.title: Kola Borehole
item.description: [#1330] Tonight's top story: Lucifer, the Prince of Darkness, died in his home this morning at the age of [unintelligible rune]. Due to the large number of sharks inhabiting his former kingdom, no body could be recovered.

item.title: Frequency
item.description: [#1331] This comic shows estimated average frequency. I wanted to include the pitch drop experiment, but it turns out the gif format has some issues with decade-long loops.

item.title: Slippery Slope
item.description: [#1332] Sure, taking a few seconds to be respectful toward someone about something they care about doesn't sound hard. But if you talk to hundreds of people every day and they all start expecting that same consideration, it could potentially add up to MINUTES wasted. And for WHAT?

item.title: First Date
item.description: [#1333] I sympathize with the TPP protagonist because I, too, have progressed through a surprising number of stages of life despite spending entire days stuck against simple obstacles.

item.title: Second
item.description: [#1334] Let me just scroll down and check behind that rock. Annnnd ... nope, page copyright year starts with '19'. Oh God, is this a WEBRING?

item.description: [#1335] This image stays roughly in sync with the day (assuming the Earth continues spinning). Shortcut: xkcd.com/now

item.description: [#1336] A helicopter bursts from a chrysalis and alights on a rock, rotors still damp.

item.description: [#1337] HACK THE STARS

item.title: Land Mammals
item.description: [#1338] Bacteria still outweigh us thousands to one--and that's not even counting the several pounds of them in your body.

item.title: When You Assume
item.description: [#1339] You know what happens when you assert--you make an ass out of the emergency response team.

item.title: Unique Date
item.description: [#1340] If our current civilization lasts another 8,000 years, it's probably fair to assume the Long Now Foundation got things right, and at some point we started listening to them and switched to five-digit years.

item.title: Types of Editors
item.description: [#1341] m-x machineofdeath-mode

item.title: Ancient Stars
item.description: [#1342] 'The light from those millions of stars you see is probably many thousands of years old' is a rare example of laypeople substantially OVERestimating astronomical numbers.

item.title: Manuals
item.description: [#1343] The most ridiculous offender of all is the sudoers man page, which for 15 years has started with a 'quick guide' to EBNF, a system for defining the grammar of a language. 'Don't despair', it says, 'the definitions below are annotated.'

item.title: Digits
item.description: [#1344] It's taken me 20 years to get over skyline tetris.

item.title: Answers
item.description: [#1345] Stanford sleep researcher William Dement said that after 50 years of studying sleep, the only really solid explanation he knows for why we do it is 'because we get sleepy'.

item.title: Career
item.description: [#1346] They'd convince me to come out of retirement for one last job: biting into a giant lump of slightly soft wax a couple of times.

item.title: t Distribution
item.description: [#1347] If data fails the Teacher's t test, you can just force it to take the test again until it passes.

item.title: Before the Internet
item.description: [#1348] We watched DAYTIME TV. Do you realize how soul-crushing it was? I'd rather eat an iPad than go back to watching daytime TV.

item.title: Shouldn't Be Hard
item.description: [#1349] (six hours later) ARGH. How are these stupid microchips so durable?! All I want is to undo a massive industrial process with household tools!

item.title: Lorenz
item.description: [#1350] Every choice, no matter how small, begins a new story.

item.title: Metamaterials
item.description: [#1351] If I developed a hue-shifting metamaterial, I would photobomb people's Instagram pics with a sheet of material that precisely undid the filter they were using.

item.title: Cosmologist on a Tire Swing
item.description: [#1352] No matter how fast I swing, I can never travel outside this loop! Maybe space outside it doesn't exist! But I bet it does. This tire came from somewhere.

item.title: Heartbleed
item.description: [#1353] I looked at some of the data dumps from vulnerable sites, and it was ... bad. I saw emails, passwords, password hints. SSL keys and session cookies. Important servers brimming with visitor IPs. Attack ships on fire off the shoulder of Orion, c-beams glittering in the dark near the Tannhuser Gate. I should probably patch OpenSSL.

item.title: Heartbleed Explanation
item.description: [#1354] Are you still there, server? It's me, Margaret.

item.title: Airplane Message
item.description: [#1355] PHARAOH IRY-HOR, FROM THE 3100s BC, IS THE FIRST HUMAN WHOSE NAME WE KNOW.

item.title: Orbital Mechanics
item.description: [#1356] To be fair, my job at NASA was working on robots and didn't actually involve any orbital mechanics. The small positive slope over that period is because it turns out that if you hang around at NASA, you get in a lot of conversations about space.

item.title: Free Speech
item.description: [#1357] I can't remember where I heard this, but someone once said that defending a position by citing free speech is sort of the ultimate concession; you're saying that the most compelling thing you can say for your position is that it's not literally illegal to express.

item.description: [#1361] The less popular 8.8.4.4 is slated for discontinuation.

item.description: [#1362] Oh, because Facebook has worked out SO WELL for everyone.

item.title: xkcd Phone
item.description: [#1363] Presented in partnership with Qualcomm, Craigslist, Whirlpool, Hostess, LifeStyles, and the US Chamber of Commerce. Manufactured on equipment which also processes peanuts. Price includes 2-year Knicks contract. Phone may extinguish nearby birthday candles. If phone ships with Siri, return immediately; do not speak to her and ignore any instructions she gives. Do not remove lead casing. Phone may attract/trap insects; this is normal. Volume adjustable (requires root). If you experience sudden tingling, nausea, or vomiting, perform a factory reset immediately. Do not submerge in water; phone will drown. Exterior may be frictionless. Prolonged use can cause mood swings, short-term memory loss, and seizures. Avert eyes while replacing battery. Under certain circumstances, wireless transmitter may control God.

item.title: Like I'm Five
item.description: [#1364] 'Am I taking care of you? I have a thesis to write!' 'My parents are at their house; you visited last--' 'No, no, explain like you're five.'

item.description: [#1367] But still, my scheme for creating and saving user config files and data locally to preserve them across reinstalls might be useful for--wait, that's cookies.

item.description: [#1368] 'The world's greatest [whatever]' is subjective, but 'One of the world's greatest [whatever]s' is clearly objective. Anyway, that's why I got you this 'one of the world's greatest moms' mug!

item.description: [#1369] 'TMI' he whispered, gazing into the sea.

item.title: 4.5 Degrees
item.description: [#1379] The good news is that according to the latest IPCC report, if we enact aggressive emissions limits now, we could hold the warming to 2C. That's only HALF an ice age unit, which is probably no big deal.

item.description: [#1380] We will have an entire wing of the library devoted to copies of book #26, because ohmygod it's the one where Jake and Cassie finally KISS!!!

item.description: [#1390] I mean, it's not like we could just demand to see the code that's governing our lives. What right do we have to poke around in Facebook's private affairs like that?

item.title: Darkness
item.description: [#1391] This was actually wish #406. Wish #2 was for him to lose the ability to remember that each new wish wasn't my first.

item.title: Dominant Players
item.description: [#1392] When Vera Menchik entered a 1929 tournament, a male competitor mocked her by suggesting that a special 'Vera Menchik Club' would be created for any player who lost to her. When the tournament began, he promptly became the first member of said club, and over the years it accumulated a large and illustrious roster.

item.title: Timeghost

item.description: [#1394] See also: Spider-Man reboot in which he can produce several inches of web, doesn't need as much chalk powder on his hands when he goes rock climbing, and occasionally feels vaguely uneasy about situations.

item.title: Power Cord
item.description: [#1395] In this situation, gzip /dev/inside to deflate, then pipe the compressed air to /dev/input to clean your keyboard. Avert your eyes when you do.

item.description: [#1396] Once again topping the list of tonight's hottest rising stars in Hollywood is Persei!

item.description: [#1397] Don't turn it on.

item.title: Snake Facts
item.description: [#1398] Biologically speaking, what we call a 'snake' is actually a human digestive tract which has escaped from its host.

item.description: [#1399] Although the oral exam for the doctorate was just 'can you do that weird laugh?'

item.description: [#1402] To motivate it to fire its harpoons hard enough, Rosetta's Philae lander has been programmed to believe it is trying to kill the comet.

item.description: [#1403] MY RESULTS ARE A SIGNIFICANT IMPROVEMENT ON THE STATE OF THE AAAAAAAAAAAART

item.description: [#1404] I don't understand the things you do, and you therefore may represent an interaction with the quantum vacuum virtual plasma.

item.description: [#1405] No, only LAVA is called 'magma' while underground. Any other object underground is called 'lava'.

item.title: Universal Converter Box
item.description: [#1406] Comes with a 50-lb sack of gender changers, and also an add-on device with a voltage selector and a zillion circular center pin DC adapter tips so you can power any of those devices from the 90s.

item.title: Worst Hurricane
item.description: [#1407] 'Finding a 105-year-old who's lived in each location and asking them which hurricane they think was the worst' is left as an exercise for the reader.

item.description: [#1408] You ARE getting older, though.

item.description: [#1409] SELECT * FROM GHOSTS

item.description: [#1410] 58% of the state has gone into plaid.

item.title: Loop
item.description: [#1411] Ugh, today's kids are forgetting the old-fashioned art of absentmindedly reading the same half-page of a book over and over and then letting your attention wander and picking up another book.

item.title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles
item.description: [#1412] My upcoming album, 'Linked List', has covers of 'The Purple People Eater', the Ninja Turtles theme, 'Itsy Bitsy Teenie Weenie Yellow Polka Dot Bikini', and the Power Rangers theme, with every song played to the tune of the next.

item.title: Suddenly Popular
item.description: [#1413] Are Your Teens Practicing Amplexus? Learn These Six Telltale Signs!

item.title: Writing Skills
item.description: [#1414] I'd like to find a corpus of writing from children in a non-self-selected sample (e.g. handwritten letters to the president from everyone in the same teacher's 7th grade class every year)--and score the kids today versus the kids 20 years ago on various objective measures of writing quality. I've heard the idea that exposure to all this amateur peer practice is hurting us, but I'd bet on the generation that conducts the bulk of their social lives via the written word over the generation that occasionally wrote book reports and letters to grandma once a year, any day.

item.title: Ballooning
item.description: [#1415] Time to dance in front of Mary Jane! If I'm lucky, she'll turn out not to practice pre-copulatory sexual cannibalism!

item.title: Pixels
item.description: [#1416] It's turtles all the way down.

item.title: Seven
item.description: [#1417] The days of the week are Monday, Arctic, Wellesley, Green, Electra, Synergize, and the Seventh Seal.

item.title: Horse
item.description: [#1418] Officer suspended from horse.

item.title: On the Phone
item.description: [#1419] 'No idea what I was thinking! Haha! But anyway, maybe we should check out what this Ba'al guy has to say.'

item.title: Watches
item.description: [#1420] Old people used to write obnoxious thinkpieces about how people these days always wear watches and are slaves to the clock, but now they've switched to writing thinkpieces about how kids these days don't appreciate the benefits of an old-fashioned watch. My position is: The word 'thinkpiece' sounds like a word made up by someone who didn't know about the word 'brain'.

item.title: Future Self
item.description: [#1421] Maybe I haven't been to Iceland because I'm busy dealing with YOUR crummy code.

item.title: My Phone is Dying
item.description: [#1422] When it explodes, it will cast off its outer layers, leaving behind nothing but a slowly fading PalmPilot, calculator, or two-way pager.

item.title: Conversation
item.description: [#1423] Later, at home: 'Dear diary: Still can't figure out what to write here ...'

item.title: En Garde
item.description: [#1424] 'Touch!' 'Nope, I sighed and stared at you with resignation, so I regained emotional right-of-way.'

item.title: Tasks
item.description: [#1425] In the 60s, Marvin Minsky assigned a couple of undergrads to spend the summer programming a computer to use a camera to identify objects in a scene. He figured they'd have the problem solved by the end of the summer. Half a century later, we're still working on it.

item.title: Reduce Your Payments
item.description: [#1426] I tried oxidizing them, but your bank uses some really weird paper and it wouldn't light.

item.title: iOS Keyboard
item.description: [#1427] More actual results: 'Hello. My name is Inigo Montoya. You [are the best. The best thing ever]', 'Revenge is a dish best served [by a group of people in my room]', and 'They may take our lives, but they'll never take our [money].'

item.title: Move Fast and Break Things
item.description: [#1428] I was almost fired from a job driving the hearse in funeral processions, but then the funeral home realized how much business I was creating for them.

item.title: Data
item.description: [#1429] If you want to have more fun at the expense of language pedants, try developing an hypercorrection habit.

item.title: Proteins
item.description: [#1430] Check it out--when I tug the C-terminal tail, the binding tunnel squeezes!

item.title: Marriage
item.description: [#1431] People often say that same-sex marriage now is like interracial marriage in the 60s. But in terms of public opinion, same-sex marriage now is like interracial marriage in the 90s, when it had already been legal nationwide for 30 years.

item.title: The Sake of Argument
item.description: [#1432] 'It's not actually ... it's a DEVICE for EXPLORING a PLAUSIBLE REALITY that's not the one we're in, to gain a broader understanding about it.' 'oh, like a boat!' '...' 'Just for the sake of argument, we should get a boat! You can invite the Devil, too, if you want.'

item.title: Lightsaber
item.description: [#1433] A long time in the future, in a galaxy far, far, away, astronomers in the year 2008 sight an unusual gamma-ray burst originating from somewhere far across the universe.

item.title: Where Do Birds Go
item.description: [#1434] Water/ice has a lot of weird phases. Maybe asking 'where do birds go when it rains' is like asking 'where does Clark Kent go whenever Superman shows up?'

item.title: Presidential Alert
item.description: [#1435] When putting his kids to bed, after saying 'Goodnight', Obama has to stop himself from saying 'God bless you, and God bless the United States of America.'

item.title: Orb Hammer
item.description: [#1436] Ok, but make sure to get lots of pieces of rock, because later we'll decide to stay in a room on our regular orb and watch hammers hold themselves and hit rocks for us, and they won't bring us very many rocks.

item.title: Higgs Boson
item.description: [#1437] 'Can't you just use the LHC you already built to find it again?' 'We MAY have disassembled it to build a death ray.' 'Just one, though.' 'Nothing you should worry about.' 'The death isn't even very serious.'

item.title: Houston
item.description: [#1438] 'Oh, hey Mom. No, nothing important, just at work.'

item.title: Rack Unit
item.description: [#1439] There's also nothing in the TOSes that says you can't let a dog play baseball in the server room!

item.title: Geese
item.description: [#1440] Anyway, that's a common misconception. Geese live for a long time; all the ones we can see will probably keep flying around for billions of years before they explode.

item.title: Turnabout
item.description: [#1441] Whenever I miss a shot with a sci-fi weapon, I say 'Apollo retroreflector' really fast, just in case.

item.title: Chemistry
item.description: [#1442] These are all sans-serif compounds. Serif compounds are dramatically different and usually much more reactive.

item.title: Language Nerd
item.description: [#1443] Not to go all sentence fragment on you.

item.title: Cloud
item.description: [#1444] Cloud computing has a ways to go.

item.title: Efficiency
item.description: [#1445] I need an extension for my research project because I spent all month trying to figure out whether learning Dvorak would help me type it faster.

item.title: Landing
item.description: [#1446] [LIVE]

item.title: Meta-Analysis
item.description: [#1447] Life goal #29 is to get enough of them rejected that I can publish a comparative analysis of the rejection letters.

item.title: Question
item.description: [#1448] The universe long dead, IsaAC surveyed the formless chaos. At last, he had arrived at an answer. 'I like you,' he declared to the void, 'but I don't LIKE like you.'

item.title: Red Rover
item.description: [#1449] I just learned about the Slide Mountain Ocean, which I like because it's three nouns that sound like they can't possibly all refer to the same thing.

item.title: AI-Box Experiment
item.description: [#1450] I'm working to bring about a superintelligent AI that will eternally torment everyone who failed to make fun of the Roko's Basilisk people.

item.title: Background Screens
item.description: [#1451] No way, we gotta rewind and cross-reference this map with the list of coordinates we saw on the other screen. This Greenland thing could be big.

item.title: Jurassic World
item.description: [#1452] Hey guys! What's eating you? Ha ha ha it's me! Oh, what fun we have.

item.title: fMRI
item.description: [#1453] They also showed activation in the parts of the brain associated with exposure to dubious study methodology, concern about unremoved piercings, and exasperation with fMRI techs who won't stop talking about Warped Tour.

item.title: Done
item.description: [#1454] I'm sorry, but the author of this Facebook comment clearly believes you were.

item.title: Trolley Problem
item.description: [#1455] For $5 I promise not to orchestrate this situation, and for $25 I promise not to take further advantage of this ability to create incentives.

item.title: On the Moon
item.description: [#1456] "I believe that this nation should commit itself to achieving the goal, before this decade is out, of landing a man on Venus and returning him safely to--" [an aide frantically whispers in the president's ear for a moment] "... of landing a man on Venus."

item.title: Feedback
item.description: [#1457] A new study finds that if you give rats a cell phone and a lever they can push to improve the signal, the rats will chew on the cell phone until it breaks and your research supervisors will start to ask some questions about your grant money.

item.title: Small Moon
item.description: [#1458] GENERAL JAN DODONNA: An analysis of the plans provided by Princess Leia has reinvigorated the arguments of the 'artificial moonlet' and 'rogue planet-station' camps. I fear this question is fracturing the Rebellion.

item.title: Documents
item.description: [#1459] Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Copy of Untitled.doc

item.title: SMFW
item.description: [#1460] wtfw it's like smho tbfh, imdb.

item.title: Payloads
item.description: [#1461] With a space elevator, a backyard full of solar panels could launch about 500 horses per year, and a large power plant could launch 10 horses per minute.

item.title: Blind Trials
item.description: [#1462] Plus, you have to control for the fact that some people are into being blindfolded.

item.title: Altitude
item.description: [#1463] "TURN OFF THE LASER GUIDE STAR" "WHY" "STAR CATS"

item.title: Santa
item.description: [#1464] He probably just poops over the side of the sleigh.

item.title: xkcd Phone 2
item.description: [#1465] Washable, though only once.

item.title: Phone Checking
item.description: [#1466] 'Where were you when you learned you'd won?' 'I was actually asleep; I woke up when I refreshed the webite and saw the news.'

item.title: Email
item.description: [#1467] My New Year's resolution for 2014-54-12/30/14 Dec:12:1420001642 is to learn these stupid time formatting strings.

item.title: Worrying
item.description: [#1468] If the breaking news is about an event at a hospital or a lab, move it all the way over to the right.

item.title: UV
item.description: [#1469] Hey, why stop at our house? We could burn down ALL these houses for the insurance money.

item.title: Kix
item.description: [#1470] My parents sent me to several years of intensive Kix test prep.

item.title: Gut Fauna
item.description: [#1471] I know it seems unpleasant, but of the two ways we typically transfer them, I promise this is the one you want.

item.title: Geography
item.description: [#1472] The place I'd least like to live is the farm in the background of those diagrams showing how tornadoes form.

item.title: Location Sharing
item.description: [#1473] Our phones must have great angular momentum sensors because the compasses really suck.

item.title: Screws
item.description: [#1474] If you encounter a hex bolt, but you only brought screwdrivers, you can try sandwiching the head of the bolt between two parallel screwdriver shafts, squeezing the screwdrivers together with a hand at either end, then twisting. It doesn't work and it's a great way to hurt yourself, but you can try it!

item.title: Technically
item.description: [#1475] "Technically that sentence started with 'well', so--" "Ooh, a rock with a fossil in it!"

item.title: Ceres
item.description: [#1476] Earth clearly hasn't been inspected, since it's definitely contaminated with salmonella.

item.title: Star Wars
item.description: [#1477] A long, long time (plus 40 years) ago, in a galaxy far, far away (plus a corrective factor involving the Hubble constant) ...

item.title: P-Values
item.description:
[#1478] If all else fails, use "significant at a p>0.05 level" and hope no one notices.

0.05 level" and hope no one notices." style="height: auto" />

item.title: Troubleshooting
item.description: [#1479] "Oh, you're using their Chrome APP, not their Chrome EXTENSION. They're very similar but one handles window creation differently." is a thing I hope I can stop saying soon.

item.title: Super Bowl
item.description: [#1480] My hobby: Pretending to miss the sarcasm when people show off their lack of interest in football by talking about 'sportsball' and acting excited to find someone else who's interested, then acting confused when they try to clarify.

item.title: API
item.description: [#1481] ACCESS LIMITS: Clients may maintain connections to the server for no more than 86,400 seconds per day. If you need additional time, you may contact IERS to file a request for up to one additional second.

item.title: #NowPlaying
item.description: [#1482] If you click on the post, it takes you to search results for the note on various online music stores.

item.title: Quotative Like
item.description: [#1483] God was like, "Let there be light," and there was light.

item.title: Apollo Speeches
item.description: [#1484] While our commitment to recycling initiatives has been unwavering, this is not a cost any of us should be expected to pay.

item.title: Friendship
item.description: [#1485] The only other Wikipedia vandalism that I would feel zero remorse about is editing the article on active US militia groups to replace "militia" with "fanclub".

item.title: Vacuum
item.description: [#1486] Do you think you could actually clean the living room at some point, though?

item.title: Tornado
item.description: [#1487] Nearby, there were also no injuries when a multi-vortex tornado hit one of those spinning teacup rides.

item.title: Flowcharts
item.description: [#1488] Whoa, and if you overlay a Fibonacci spiral on a golden spiral it matches up almost perfectly!

item.title: Fundamental Forces
item.description: [#1489] "Of these four forces, there's one we don't really understand." "Is it the weak force or the strong--" "It's gravity."

item.title: Atoms
item.description: [#1490] When I was little I had trouble telling my dad apart from the dog. I always recognized my mom because she had a bunch of extra plutoniums in her middle. I never did ask her why ...

item.title: Stories of the Past and Future
item.description: [#1491] Little-known fact: The 'Dawn of Man' opening sequence in 2001 cuts away seconds before the Flintstones theme becomes recognizable.

item.title: Dress Color
item.description: [#1492] This white-balance illusion hit so hard because it felt like someone had been playing through the Monty Hall scenario and opened their chosen door, only to find there was unexpectedly disagreement over whether the thing they'd revealed was a goat or a car.

item.title: Meeting
item.description: [#1493] Here at CompanyName.website, our three main strengths are our web-facing chairs, our huge collection of white papers, and the fact that we physically cannot die.

item.title: Insurance
item.description: [#1494] LIFEHACKS: You can just take all the luggage off the airport conveyer belt and leave with it. They don't check that it's yours at the door!

item.title: Hard Reboot
item.description: [#1495] Googling inevitably reveals that my problem is caused by a known bug triggered by doing [the exact combination of things I want to do]. I can fix it, or wait a few years until I don't want that combination of things anymore, using the kitchen timer until then.

item.title: Art Project
item.description: [#1496] It's my most ambitious project yet, judging by the amount of guacamole.

item.title: New Products
item.description: [#1497] If you ever hear "Wait, is that Kim Dotcom's new project? I'm really excited about it and already signed up, although I'm a little nervous about whether everyone should hand over control of their medical...", it's time to dig a bunker in your backyard.

item.title: Terry Pratchett
item.description: [#1498] Thank you for teaching us how big our world is by sharing so many of your own.

item.title: Arbitrage
item.description: [#1499] The invisible hand of the market never texts me back.

item.title: Upside-Down Map
item.description: [#1500] Due to their proximity across the channel, there's long been tension between North Korea and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Southern Ireland.

item.title: Mysteries
item.description: [#1501] At the bottom left: The mystery of why, when I know I needed to be asleep an hour ago, I decide it's a good time to read through every Wikipedia article in the categories 'Out-of-place artifacts', 'Earth mysteries', 'Anomalous weather', and 'List of people who disappeared mysteriously'.

item.title: Wasted Time
item.description: [#1502] Since it sounds like your time spent typing can't possibly be less productive than your time spent not typing, have you tried typing SLOWER?

item.title: Squirrel Plan
item.description: [#1503] [Halfway to the Sun ...] Heyyyy ... what if this BALLOON is full of acorns?!

item.title: Opportunity
item.description: [#1504] We all remember those famous first words spoken by an astronaut on the surface of Mars: "That's one small step fo- HOLY SHIT LOOK OUT IT'S GOT SOME KIND OF DRILL! Get back to the ... [unintelligible] ... [signal lost]"

item.title: Ontological Argument
item.description: [#1505] A God who holds the world record for eating the most skateboards is greater than a God who does not hold that record.

item.title: xkcloud
item.description: [#1506]

item.title: Metaball
item.description: [#1507] Shoot, it landed in the golf course. Gonna be hard to get it down the--oh, never mind, it rolled onto the ice hazard. Face-off!

item.title: Operating Systems
item.description: [#1508] One of the survivors, poking around in the ruins with the point of a spear, uncovers a singed photo of Richard Stallman. They stare in silence. "This," one of them finally says, "This is a man who BELIEVED in something."

item.title: Scenery Cheat Sheet
item.description: [#1509] At the boundary between each zone, stories blend together. Somewhere in the New Mexico desert, the Roadrunner is pursued by a tireless Anton Chigurh.

item.title: Napoleon
item.description: [#1510] "Mr. President, what if the unthinkable happens? What if the launch goes wrong, and Napoleon is not stranded on the Moon?" "Have Safire write up a speech."

item.title: Spice Girl
item.description: [#1511] Haha, you'll see!

item.title: Horoscopes
item.description: [#1512] If you live in the Northern hemisphere, anyway. In the southern hemisphere, due to the coriolis effect, babies are born nine months BEFORE they're conceived.

item.title: Code Quality
item.description: [#1513] I honestly didn't think you could even USE emoji in variable names. Or that there were so many different crying ones.

item.title: PermaCal
item.description: [#1514] The flood of PermaCalNTP leap-second notifications was bad enough, but when people started asking for millisecond resolution, the resulting DDOS brought down the internet.

item.title: Basketball Earth
item.description: [#1515] How many points do you get for dunking every basketball in existence at once?

item.title: Win by Induction
item.description: [#1516] This would be bad enough, but every 30th or 40th pokball has TWO of them inside.

item.title: Spectroscopy
item.description: [#1517] Although right now I'm more excited about ESPRESSO's radial velocity measurements, so I'm listening to This Kiss, her song about measuring "centrifugal motion" on "a rooftop under the sky".

item.title: Typical Morning Routine
