item.description: [#1518] Hang on, I've heard this problem. We need to pour water into the duct until the phone floats up and ... wait, phones sink in water. Mercury. We need a vat of mercury to pour down the vent. That will definitely make this situation better and not worse.

item.title: Venus
item.description: [#1519] The sudden introduction of Venusian flowers led to an explosive growth of unusual Earth pollinators, which became known as the "butterfly effect."

item.title: Degree-Off
item.description: [#1520] I'M SORRY, FROM YOUR YEARS OF CONDESCENDING TOWARD THE 'SQUISHY SCIENCES', I ASSUMED YOU'D BE A LITTLE HARDER.

item.title: Sword in the Stone
item.description: [#1521] That seems like an awful lot of hassle when all I wanted was a cool sword.

item.title: Astronomy
item.description: [#1522] Astrobiology is held back by the fact that we're all too nervous to try to balance on the ladder while holding an expensive microscope.

item.title: Microdrones
item.description: [#1523] Oh, weird, Amazon is out of butterfly nets.

item.title: Dimensions
item.description: [#1524] I would say time is definitely one of my top three favorite dimensions.

item.title: Emojic 8 Ball
item.description: [#1525]

item.title: Placebo Blocker
item.description: [#1526] They work even better if you take them with our experimental placebo booster, which I keep in the same bottle.

item.title: Humans
item.description: [#1527] At this point, if we're going to keep insisting on portraying dinosaurs as featherless because it's "cooler", it's time to apply that same logic to art involving bald eagles.

item.title: Vodka
item.description: [#1528] Or whatever's handy! I'm pretty much pure alcohol and water, so it doesn't really matter!

item.title: Bracket
item.description: [#1529] I'm staring at the "doctor" section, and I can't help but feel like I've forgotten someone.

item.title: Keyboard Mash
item.description: [#1530] WHY DON'T YOU COME HANG OUT INSIDE MY HOUSE. WE CAN COOK BREAD AND CHAT ABOUT OUR INTERNAL SKELETONS.

item.title: The BDLPSWDKS Effect
item.description: [#1531] This well-known effect has of course been replicated in countless experiments.

item.title: New Horizons
item.description: [#1532] Last-minute course change: Let's see if we can hit Steve's house.

item.title: Antique Factory
item.description: [#1533] WARNING: This item was aged by the same inexorable passage of time that also processes nuts.

item.title: Beer
item.description: [#1534] Mmmm, this is such a positive experience! I feel no social pressure to enjoy it at all!

item.title: Words for Pets
item.description: [#1535] Seventh year: Perfectly coherent words, but in the pet's language, not mine.

item.title: The Martian
item.description: [#1536] I have never seen a work of fiction so perfectly capture the out-of-nowhere shock of discovering that you've just bricked something important because you didn't pay enough attention to a loose wire.

item.title: Types
item.description: [#1537] colors.rgb("blue") yields "#0000FF". colors.rgb("yellowish blue") yields NaN. colors.sort() yields "rainbow"

item.title: Lyrics
item.description: [#1538] To me, trying to understand song lyrics feels like when I see text in a dream but it hd t ed ad cant fcu

item.title: Planning
item.description: [#1539] [10 years later] Man, why are people so comfortable handing Google and Facebook control over our nuclear weapons?

item.title: Hemingway
item.description: [#1540] Instead of bobcat, package contained chair.

item.title: Voice
item.description: [#1541] Anyway, we should totally go watch a video story or put some food in our normal mouths!

item.title: Scheduling Conflict
item.description: [#1542] Neither a spokesperson for the organization nor the current world champion could be reached for comment.

item.title: Team Effort
item.description: [#1543] Given the role they play in every process in my body, really, they deserve this award more than me. Just gotta figure out how to give it to them. Maybe I can cut it into pieces to make it easier to swallow ...

item.title: Margaret
item.description: [#1544] Otherwise known as Margaret the Destroyer, I will bring pain to the the Great One. Then again, maybe I won't.

item.title: Strengths and Weaknesses
item.description: [#1545] Do you need me to do a quicksort on the whiteboard or produce a generation of offspring or something? It might take me a bit, but I can do it.

item.title: Tamagotchi Hive
item.description: [#1546] The Singularity happened, but not to us.

item.title: Solar System Questions
item.description: [#1547] My country's World Cup win was exciting and all, but c'mon, what if the players wore nylon wings and COULD LITERALLY FLY?

item.title: 90s Kid
item.description: [#1548] We remember Rugrats, and think of them every time our kids look at us through their baby gates.

item.title: xkcd Phone 3
item.description: [#1549] If you're not completely satisfied with the phone after 30 days, we will return you to your home at no cost.

item.title: Episode VII
item.description: [#1550] The Lord of the Rings sequel, set years after the Ring hubbub has died down, is just Samwise discreetly creeping back to Bag End to finish dropping the eaves.

item.title: Pluto
item.description: [#1551] After decades of increasingly confused arguing, Pluto is reclassified as a "dwarf Pluto."

item.title: Rulebook
item.description: [#1552] It's definitely an intentional foul, but we've decided it's worth it.

item.title: Public Key
item.description: [#1553] I guess I should be signing stuff, but I've never been sure what to sign. Maybe if I post my private key, I can crowdsource my decisions about what to sign.

item.title: Spice Girls
item.description: [#1554] The Earth's five major mass extinctions were the Posh Extinction, the Sporty Extinction, the Scary Extinction, the Ginger Extinction, and the Baby Extinction.

item.title: Exoplanet Names 2
item.description: [#1555] I'm going to drive this Netherlands joke so far into the ground they'll have to build levees around it to keep the sea out.

item.title: The Sky
item.description: [#1556] The other half has some cool shipwrecks, rocks, and snakes, but if you move those out of the way, it also has more sky.

item.title: Ozymandias
item.description: [#1557] And on the pedestal these words appear: "And on the pedestal these words appear: "And on the pedestal these words appear: "And ...

item.title: Vet
item.description: [#1558] It's probably for the best. Since Roombas are native to North America, it's illegal for Americans to keep them in their houses under the Migratory Bird Treaty Act.

item.title: Driving
item.description: [#1559] Sadly, it probably won't even have enough gas to make it to the first border crossing.

item.title: Bubblegum
item.description: [#1560] I came here to chew bubblegum and say no more than eighteen words ... and I'm all out of

item.title: Water Phase Diagram
item.description: [#1561] Vanilla Ice was produced in small quantities for years, but it wasn't until the 90s that experimenters collaborated to produce a sample that could survive at room temperature for several months.

item.title: I in Team
item.description: [#1562] There's no "I" in "VOWELS".

item.title: Synonym Movies
item.description: [#1563] Fans eagerly await 2015's 'Space Fights: Power Gets Up', although most think 1999's 'Space Fights: The Scary Ghost' didn't live up to the hype.

item.title: Every Seven Seconds
item.description: [#1564] Every few months, I think about sex every seven seconds and how weird and implausible it would be.

item.title: Back Seat
item.description: [#1565] Hang on, let me scare the live raccoon over to the same side as the dead one.

item.title: Board Game
item.description: [#1566] Yes, it took a lot of work to make the cards and pieces, but it's worth it--the players are way more thorough than the tax prep people ever were.

item.title: Kitchen Tips
item.description: [#1567] Household tip: Tired of buying so much toilet paper? Try unspooling the paper from the roll before using it. A single roll can last for multiple days that way, and it's much easier on your plumbing.

item.title: Synonym Movies 2
item.description: [#1568] There's also the TV show based on the hit Hot and Cold Music books: Fun With Chairs, Royal Rumble, Knife Blizzard, Breakfast for Birds, and Samba Serpents.

item.title: Magic Tree
item.description: [#1569] Since people rarely try to cut down cell phone towers, after millions of years, as cell phone towers have gotten more treelike, trees have started growing fake cell phone tower attachments and shiny gray bark to protect themselves. This is a standard textbook example of convergent evolution.

item.title: Engineer Syllogism
item.description: [#1570] The less common, even worse outcome: "3: [everyone in the financial system] WOW, where did all my money just go?"

item.title: Car Model Names
item.description: [#1571] CLIMAX is good, but SEXCLIMAX is even better.

item.title: xkcd Survey
item.description: [#1572] The xkcd Survey: Big Data for a Big Planet

item.title: Cyberintelligence
item.description: [#1573] We had gathered that raw information, but had yet to put it all together.

item.title: Trouble for Science
item.description: [#1574] Careful mathematical analysis demonstrates small-scale irregularities in Gaussian distribution

item.title: Footprints
item.description: [#1575] "There's one set of foot-p's cause I was totes carrying you, bro!" said Jesus seconds before I punched him.

item.title: I Could Care Less
item.description: [#1576] I literally could care less.

item.title: Advent
item.description: [#1577] The few dozen doors that have little Christmas trees on them are a nice touch.

item.title: Squirrelphone
item.description: [#1578] After a while, the squirrel starts making that beeping noise and doesn't stop until it hops back up onto the stump.

item.title: Tech Loops
item.description: [#1579] And when I think about it, a lot of "things I want to do" are just learning about and discussing new tools for tinkering with the chain.

item.title: Travel Ghost
item.description: [#1580] And a different ghost has replaced me in the bedroom.

item.title: Birthday
item.description: [#1581] I guess I need to apologize to my parents, friends, and the staff at Chuck E. Cheese's for all the times I called the cops on them.

item.title: Picture a Grassy Field
item.description: [#1582] Wait, I can fix this. Picture another field. In the middle sits the only creature the first creature is afraid of. Now just-- wait, where did THAT one go?

item.title: NASA Press Conference
item.description: [#1583] Why are we spending billions to ruin Mars with swarms of robots when Elon Musk has promised to ruin Mars for a FRACTION of the cost?

item.title: Moments of Inspiration
item.description: [#1584] Charles, I just talked to John and Mildred, who run that company selling seeds and nuts, and their kids with MOUTHS are starving!

item.title: Similarities
item.description: [#1585] I just came from The Martian, and I just have to say: Forget BB-8; I want a pet Sojourner! It's always been the cutest of our Mars rovers.

item.title: Keyboard Problems
item.description: [#1586] In the future, a group of resistance fighters send me back in time with instructions to find the Skynet prototype and try to upgrade it.

item.title: Food Rule
item.description: [#1587] I won't eat invertebrates, because I can fight a skeleton, but I have no idea what kind of spooky warrior a squid leaves behind.

item.title: Hardware Reductionism
item.description: [#1588] My MRI research shows a clear correlation between the size of the parietal lobe--the part of the brain that handles spatial reasoning--and enjoyment of 3D Doritos.

item.title: Frankenstein
item.description: [#1589] "Wait, so in this version is Frankenstein also the doctor's name?" "No, he's just 'The Doctor'."

item.title: The Source
item.description: [#1590] Why did we even have that thing?

item.title: Bell's Theorem
item.description: [#1591] The no-communication theorem states that no communication about the no-communication theorem can clear up the misunderstanding quickly enough to allow faster-than-light signaling.

item.title: Overthinking
item.description: [#1592] On the other hand, it took us embarrassingly long to clue in to the lung cancer/cigarette thing, so I guess the real lesson is "figuring out which ideas are true is hard."

item.title: Play-By-Play
item.description: [#1593] The thrower started hitting the bats too much, so the king of the game told him to leave and brought out another thrower from thrower jail.

item.title: Human Subjects
item.description: [#1594] After meeting with a few of the subjects, the IRB actually recommended that you stop stressing out so much about safety guidelines.

item.title: 30 Days Hath September
item.description: [#1595] There's a cool mental calculation hack I recently learned for this: If you open the calendar app on your phone or computer, the highest-numbered box along the bottom is equal to the number of days in the month!

item.title: Launch Status Check
item.description: [#1596] Visual checks suggest the cool bird has exited the launch zone. Tip the rocket sideways and resume the countdown--we're gonna go find it!

item.title: Git
item.description: [#1597] If that doesn't fix it, git.txt contains the phone number of a friend of mine who understands git. Just wait through a few minutes of 'It's really pretty simple, just think of branches as...' and eventually you'll learn the commands that will fix everything.

item.title: Salvage
item.description: [#1598] My hobby: Taking advantage of the rice myth by posting articles on "how to save your wet phone" which are actually just elaborate recipes for rice pilaf.

item.title: Water Delivery
item.description: [#1599] When I was a kid, I asked my parents why our houses didn't have toothpaste pipes in addition to water ones. I'm strangely pleased to see Amazon thinking the same way.

item.title: MarketWatch
item.description: [#1600] Markets have been rocked by a second day of uncertainty after someone set up a giant Ouija board on the NYSE wall controlled collectively by the movement of the stock tickers.

item.title: Isolation
item.description: [#1601] 2060: The gregarious superintelligent AI, happily talking its way out of a box, is fast becoming a relic of the past. Today's quantum hyper-beings are too busy with their internal multiverse sims to even notice that they're in boxes at all!

item.title: Linguistics Club
item.description: [#1602] If that's too easy, you could try joining Tautology Club, which meets on the date of the Tautology Club meeting.

item.title: Flashlights
item.description: [#1603] Due to a typo, I initially found a forum for serious Fleshlight enthusiasts, and it turns out their highest-end models are ALSO capable of setting trees on fire. They're impossible to use without severe burns, but some of them swear it's worth it.

item.title: Snakes
item.description: [#1604] The last band of color indicates the snake's tolerance for being held before biting.

item.title: DNA
item.description: [#1605] Researchers just found the gene responsible for mistakenly thinking we've found the gene for specific things. It's the region between the start and the end of every chromosome, plus a few segments in our mitochondria.

item.title: Five-Day Forecast
item.description: [#1606] You know what they say--if you don't like the weather here in the Solar System, just wait five billion years.

item.title: Supreme Court
item.description: [#1607] Writing for the majority, Justice Kennedy called the man's arguments that he could be either Alito or Ginsburg "surprisingly compelling, but ultimately unconvincing."

item.title: Hoverboard
item.description: [#1608] Return to the play area

item.title: Food Combinations
item.description: [#1609] If anyone tries this on you, the best reply is a deadpan "Oh yeah, that's a common potato chip flavor in Canada."

item.title: Fire Ants
item.description: [#1610] Here in the entomology department, we have a simple two-step formula for answering any question: (1) ants are cool, and (2) we forgot the question because we were thinking about ants.

item.title: Baking Soda and Vinegar
item.description: [#1611] Sure, it may not meet science fair standards, but I want credit for getting my baking soda and vinegar mountain added to the Decade Volcanoes list.

item.title: Colds
item.description: [#1612] The contagious period ends right around when you start to sound sick over the phone, which is probably evidence of cold viruses evolving to spread optimally in the workplace.

item.title: The Three Laws of Robotics
item.description: [#1613] In ordering #5, self-driving cars will happily drive you around, but if you tell them to drive to a car dealership, they just lock the doors and politely ask how long humans take to starve to death.

item.title: Kites
item.description: [#1614] [Dog returns with the end of a string in its mouth] [Voice drifts down from the sky] Kites are fun!

item.title: Red Car
item.description: [#1615] That guy only drives an alkaline car to overcompensate for his highly acidic penis.

item.title: Lunch
item.description: [#1616] I'm trying to be healthier, so after I eat this brick of cheese, I'll have a spoonful of grease-soaked vegetables.

item.title: Time Capsule
item.description: [#1617] Oh no, I changed the future and now I'm disappearing! Wait, never mind, it was just my hat slipping down over my eyes.

item.title: Cold Medicine
item.description: [#1618] Seriously considering buying some illegal drugs to try to turn them back into cold medicine.

item.title: Watson Medical Algorithm
item.description: [#1619] Due to a minor glitch, 'discharge patient' does not cause the algorithm to exit, but instead leads back to 'hunt down and capture patient'.

item.title: Christmas Settings
item.description: [#1620] SOUND DOGS MAKE: [BARKING] [HISSING] [LIGHTSABER NOISES] [FLUENT ENGLISH] [SWEARING]

item.title: Fixion
item.description: [#1621] My theory predicts that, at high enough energies, FRBs and perytons become indistinguishable because the detector burns out.

item.title: Henge
item.description: [#1622] I've got the Craigslist post ready to go! I wasn't sure what category it should go in, so I listed it as property and put that it has 'good sun exposure.'

item.title: 2016 Conversation Guide
item.description: [#1623] The real loser in an argument about the meaning of the word 'hoverboard' is anyone who leaves that argument on foot.
[#1624] Want to feel old? Wait.

item.title: Substitutions 2
item.description: [#1625] Within a few minutes, our roads will be full of uncontrollably-swerving cars and our skies full of Amazon delivery dogs.

item.title: Judgment Day
item.description: [#1626] It took a lot of booster rockets, but luckily Amazon had recently built thousands of them to bring Amazon Prime same-day delivery to the Moon colony.

item.title: Woosh
item.description: [#1627] It also occasionally replies with 'Comment of the year', 'Are you for real', and 'I'm taking a screenshot so I can remember this moment forever'.

item.title: Magnus
item.description: [#1628] In the latest round, 9-year-old Muhammad Ali beat 10-year-old JFK at air hockey, while Secretariat lost the hot-dog-eating crown to 12-year-old Ken Jennings. Meanwhile, in a huge upset, 11-year-old Martha Stewart knocked out the adult Ronda Rousey.

item.title: Tools
item.description: [#1629] I make tools for managing job-hunting sites for people who make tools for managing job-hunting sites for people who make tools for ...

item.title: Quadcopter
item.description: [#1630] I always have to turn off nature documentaries when they show these scenes.

item.title: Longer Than Usual
item.description: [#1631] '--> [ Well, this is embarrassing. ] <--'

item.title: Palindrome
item.description: [#1632] I hope that somewhere in the world, "Panamax" is the last option on a "size" drop-down menu on a sex toy site.

item.title: Possible Undiscovered Planets
item.description: [#1633] Superman lies near the bird/plane boundary over a range of distances, which explains the confusion.

item.title: In Case of Emergency
item.description: [#1634] I keep first aid kits in those emergency lockers. Sure, it's expensive to have them installed in the wall, but at least for those ones there's no need to pay extra for safety glass.

item.title: Birdsong
item.description: [#1635] Maybe if I put it in a box for a while with a speaker playing some pleasant pastoral music, I can reprogram it.

item.title: XKCD Stack
item.description: [#1636] This site requires Sun Java 6.0.0.1 (32-bit) or higher. You have Macromedia Java 7.3.8.1 (48-bit). Click here [link to java.com main page] to download an installer which will run fine but not really change anything.

item.title: Salt Mine
item.description: [#1637] This one is a little bland. Pass the saltshaker?

item.title: Backslashes
item.description: [#1638] I searched my .bash_history for the line with the highest ratio of special characters to regular alphanumeric characters, and the winner was: cat out.txt | grep -o "[[(].*[])][^)]]*$" ... I have no memory of this and no idea what I was trying to do, but I sure hope it worked.

item.title: To Taste
item.description: [#1639] Look, recipe, if I knew how much was gonna taste good, I wouldn't need you.

item.title: Super Bowl Context
item.description: [#1640] Why did the chicken cross the road? It begins over five thousand years ago with the domestication of the red junglefowl in southeast Asia and the development of paved roads in the Sumerian city of Ur.

item.title: Hot Dogs
item.description: [#1641] Okay, I'm just gonna order pizza, and let's never talk about this again.

item.title: Gravitational Waves
item.description: [#1642] "That last LinkedIn request set a new record for the most energetic physical event ever observed. Maybe we should respond." "Nah."

item.title: Degrees
item.description: [#1643] "Radians Fahrenheit or radians Celsius?" "Uh, sorry, gotta go!"

item.title: Stargazing
item.description: [#1644] Some of you may be thinking, 'But wait, isn't the brightest star in our sky the Sun?' I think that's a great question and you should totally ask it. On the infinite tree of possible conversations spread out before us, I think that's definitely the most promising branch.

item.title: Toasts
item.description: [#1645] Platonic solids for my real friends and real solids for my platonic friends!

item.title: Twitter Bot
item.description: [#1646] PYTHON FLAG ENABLE THREE LAWS

item.title: Diacritics
item.description: [#1647] Using diacritics correctly is not my fort.

item.title: Famous Duos
item.description: [#1648] The Romeo and Butt-Head film actually got two thumbs up from Siskel and Oates.

item.title: Pipelines
item.description: [#1649] In the future, every single pipeline will lead to the bowl of a giant blender, and we'll all just show up with a bucket each day to take our share of the resulting smoothie.

item.title: Baby
item.description: [#1650] Does it get taller first and then widen, or does it reach full width before getting taller, or alternate, or what?

item.title: Robotic Garage
item.description: [#1651] But listen, if getting your car out from under the pile is REALLY important to you, we do have an axe you can borrow.

item.title: Conditionals
item.description: [#1652] 'If you're done being pedantic, we should get dinner.' 'You did it again!' 'No, I didn't.'

item.title: United States Map
item.description: [#1653] It would be pretty unfair to give to someone a blank version of this map as a 'how many states can you name?' quiz. (If you include Alaska and Hawaii, you should swap the Aleutian Islands with the Hawaiian ones.)

item.title: Universal Install Script
item.description: [#1654] The failures usually don't hurt anything, and if it installs several versions, it increases the chance that one of them is right. (Note: The 'yes' command and '2>/dev/null' are recommended additions.)

item.title: Doomsday Clock
item.description: [#1655] After a power outage at the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, the new Digital Doomsday Clock is flashing 00:00 and mushroom clouds keep appearing and then retracting once a second.

item.title: It Begins
item.description: [#1656] You can also try 'Yikes.'

item.title: Insanity
item.description: [#1657] I looked up "insanity" in like 10 different dictionaries and none of them said anything like that. Neither did the DSM-4. But I'll keep looking. Maybe it's in the DSM-5!

item.title: Estimating Time
item.description: [#1658] Corollary to Hofstadter's Law: Every minute you spend thinking about Hofstadter's Law is a minute you're NOT WORKING AND WILL NEVER FINISH! PAAAAAANIIIIIIC!

item.title: Tire Swing
item.description: [#1659] If we find one of those tire dumps, the next time he tries to get his truck back we can just retreat and let him have it.

item.title: Captain Speaking
item.description: [#1660] Oh dang, you have to pay? Hey, has anyone else paid already? If so, can I borrow your phone for a sec?

item.title: Podium
item.description: [#1661] BREAKING: Senator's bold pro-podium stand leads to primary challenge from prescriptivist base.

item.title: Jack and Jill
item.description: [#1662] Jill and Jack / began to frack. / The oil boosts their town. / But fractures make / the bedrock shake / and Jack came tumbling down.

item.title: Garden
item.description: [#1663] Relax.

item.title: Mycology
item.description: [#1664] Conspiracy theory: There's no such thing as corn. Those fields you see are just the stalks of a fungus that's controlling our brains to make us want to spread it.

item.title: City Talk Pages
item.description: [#1665] I don't think the Lakeshore Air Crash Museum really belongs under 'Tourist Attractions.' It's not a museum--it's just an area near the Lake Festival Laser Show where a lot of planes have crashed.

item.title: Brain Upload
item.description: [#1666] I just spent 20 minutes deciding whether to start an email with 'Hi' or 'Hey', so I think it transferred correctly.

item.title: Algorithms
item.description: [#1667] There was a schism in 2007, when a sect advocating OpenOffice created a fork of Sunday.xlsx and maintained it independently for several months. The efforts to reconcile the conflicting schedules led to the reinvention, within the cells of the spreadsheet, of modern version control.

item.title: Singularity
item.description: [#1668] I figured that now that society has collapsed, I wouldn't need to wear clothes anymore, but apparently that violates some weird rule of quantum gravity.

item.title: Planespotting
item.description: [#1669] No, a hydroplane doesn't land on water--that's an aquaplane. A hydroplane is a plane that gets electric power from an onboard water reservoir with a tiny dam and turbines.

item.title: Laws of Physics
item.description: [#1670] The laws of physics are fun to try to understand, but as an organism with incredibly delicate eyes who evolved in a world full of sharp objects, I have an awful lot of trust in biology's calibration of my flinch reflex.

item.title: Arcane Bullshit
item.description: [#1671] Learning arcane bullshit from the 80s can break your computer, but if you're willing to wade through arcane bullshit from programmers in the 90s and 2000s, you can break everyone else's computers, too.

item.title: Women on 20s
item.description: [#1672] I get that there are security reasons for the schedule, but this is like the ONE problem we have where the right answer is both easy and straightforward. If we can't figure it out, maybe we should just give up and just replace all the portraits on the bills with that weird pyramid eye thing.

item.title: Timeline of Bicycle Design
item.description: [#1673] I'll be honest--the 1950s were a rough time for cycling.

item.title: Adult
item.description: [#1674] (1) That shopping cart is full of AirHeads, and (2) I died at 41 from what the AirHeads company spokesperson called 'probably natural causes.'

item.title: Message in a Bottle
item.description: [#1675] I tried to send a message back, but I accidentally hit 'reply all' and now the ocean is clogged with message bottles.

item.title: Full-Width Justification
item.description: [#1676] Gonna start bugging the Unicode consortium to add snake segment characters that can be combined into an arbitrary-length non-breaking snake.

item.title: Contrails
item.description: [#1677] Astronomy (or "astrology" in British English) is the study of ...

item.title: Recent Searches
item.description: [#1678] autoexec code posted by verified twitter users

item.title: Substitutions 3
item.description: [#1679] BREAKING: Channing Tatum and his friends explore haunted city

item.title: Black Hole
item.description: [#1680] It also brings all the boys, and everything else, to the yard.

item.title: Laser Products
item.description: [#1681] ERRORS: HAIR JAM. COLOR-SAFE CONDITIONER CARTRIDGE RUNNING LOW. LEGAL-SIZE HAIR TRAY EMPTY, USING LETTER-SIZE HAIR ONLY.

item.title: Bun
item.description: [#1682] If a wild bun is sighted, a nice gesture of respect is to send a 'BUN ALERT' message to friends and family, with photographs documenting the bun's location and rank. If no photographs are possible, emoji may be substituted.

item.title: Digital Data
item.description: [#1683] If you can read this, congratulationsthe archive youre using still knows about the mouseover text!

item.title: Rainbow
item.description: [#1684] Listen, in a few thousand years you'll invent a game called 'SimCity' which has a 'disaster' button, and then you'll understand.

item.title: Patch
item.description: [#1685] My optimizer uses content-aware inpainting to fill in all the wasted whitespace in the code, repeating the process until it compiles.

item.title: Feel Old
item.description: [#1686] 'How long are you going to keep this up?' 'Statistically, only four or five more decades.'

item.title: World War III+
item.description: [#1687] I hate how the media only ever uses the first part of this quote, stripping it of its important context.

item.title: Map Age Guide
item.description: [#1688] Does the screeching chill your blood and herald death? If yes, banshee. If no, seagull.

item.title: My Friend Catherine
item.description: [#1689] I can't get any work done because my friend Catherine is sitting on my keyboard.

item.title: Time-Tracking Software
item.description: [#1690] 'List of helicopter prison escapes' and 'List of sexually active popes' are both entertainingly long, but sadly there's no 'List of helicopter prison escapes involving sexually active popes.'

item.title: Optimization
item.description: [#1691] Premature optimization is the root of all evil, so to start this project I'd better come up with a system that can determine whether a possible optimization is premature or not.

item.title: Man Page
item.description: [#1692] For even more info, see blarbl(2)(3) and birb(3ahhaha I'm kidding, just Google it like a normal person.

item.title: Oxidation
item.description: [#1693] Calm down--there were lots of arthropods living on your skin already. These ones are just bigger.

item.title: Phishing License
item.description: [#1694] Later, walking out of jail after posting $10,000 bail: "Wait, this isn't the street the county jail is on."

item.title: Code Quality 2
item.description: [#1695] It's like you tried to define a formal grammar based on fragments of a raw database dump from the QuickBooks file of a company that's about to collapse in an accounting scandal.

item.title: AI Research
item.description: [#1696] Lambda calculus? More like SHAMbda calculus, amirite?

item.title: Intervocalic Fortition
item.description: [#1697] These pranks happen all the time. English doesn't allow one-syllable words to end in a lax vowel, so writers on The Simpsons decided to mess with future linguists by introducing the word "meh."

item.title: Theft Quadrants
item.description: [#1698] TinyURL was the most popular link shortener for long enough that it made it into a lot of printed publications. I wonder what year the domain will finally lapse and get picked up by a porn site.

item.title: Local News
item.description: [#1699] Will there ever be a physics term greater than 'tachyonic antitelephone?' According to this message from the future, the answer is 'no.'

item.title: New Bug
item.description: [#1700] There's also a unicode-handling bug in the URL request library, and we're storing the passwords unsalted ... so if we salt them with emoji, we can close three issues at once!

item.title: Speed and Danger
item.description: [#1701] NASCAR removed the passenger seats because drivers hated how astronauts kept riding along with them and loudly announcing "Ahh, what a nice and relaxing drive."

item.title: Home Itch Remedies
item.description: [#1702] In my experience, mosquitos and poison ivy are bad, but the very worst itch comes from bites from chiggers (Trombicula alfreddugesi). They're found across the American south and great plains, so the best home remedy is to move to Iceland.

item.title: Juno
item.description: [#1703] "The name wasn't a tip-off?" "Honestly, at first I thought you were saying 'Juneau'. A gravity assist seemed like a weird way to get to Alaska, but I figured it must be more efficient or something."

item.title: Gnome Ann
item.description: [#1704] President Andrew Johnson once said, "If I am to be shot at, I want Gnome Ann to be in the way of the bullet."

item.title: Pokmon Go
item.description: [#1705] Still waiting for the Pokmon Go update that lets you capture strangers' pets.

item.title: Genetic Testing
item.description: [#1706] Plus, now I know that I have risk factors for elbow dysplasia, heartworm, parvo, and mange.

item.title: xkcd Phone 4
item.description: [#1707] The SpaceX system carefully guides falling phones down to the surface, a process which the phones increasingly often survive without exploding.

item.title: Dehydration
item.description: [#1708] I don't care what the research says. Everybody knows you should drink 3,000 glasses of water a day and change your oil every 8 miles.

item.title: Inflection
item.description: [#1709] "Or maybe, because we're suddenly having so many conversations through written text, we'll start relying MORE on altered spelling to indicate meaning!" "Wat."

item.title: Walking Into Things
item.description: [#1710] A childhood spent walking while reading books has prepared me unexpectedly well for today's world.

item.title: Snapchat
item.description: [#1711] For obvious reasons, the prize is awarded at a different time of year from the others, while it's still fresh in the committee's memory.

item.title: Politifact
item.description: [#1712] "Ok, I lit the smoke bomb and rolled it under the bed. Let's see if it--" ::FWOOOSH:: "Politifact says: PANTS ON FIRE!"

item.title: 50 ccs
item.description: [#1713] There's been a raccoon accident at an accordion bacchanalia! Double doses!

item.title: Volcano Types
item.description: [#1714] It's hard living somewhere with antlions, because every time you find one of their traps, you feel compelled to spend all day constructing a tiny model of Jabba's sail barge next to it.

item.title: Household Tips
item.description: [#1715] To make your shoes feel more comfortable, smell better, and last longer, try taking them off before you shower.

item.title: Time Travel Thesis
item.description: [#1716] 'Hey, what are those futuristic goggles for, anyway?' 'Oh, this is just a broken Google Glass. It was 2010's night at the club.'

item.title: Pyramid Honey
item.description: [#1717] They CLAIM honey was found in the chambers under the pyramids, but this conspiracy goes all the way to the TOP, where the GIANT EYE is!

item.title: Backups
item.description: [#1718] Maybe you should keep FEWER backups; it sounds like throwing away everything you've done and starting from scratch might not be the worst idea.

item.title: Superzoom
item.description: [#1719] *click* Let him know he's got a stain on his shirt, though.

item.title: Horses
item.description: [#1720] This car has 240% of a horse's decision-making ability and produces only 30% as much poop.

item.title: Business Idea
item.description: [#1721] Then we move to phase two. Gas stations store fuel in underground tanks. Normally, these are inaccessible except via the pump. However, with hydraulic fracturing, we-- Wait! Come back!

item.title: Debugging
item.description: [#1722] When you Google an error message and it gets no results, you can be pretty sure you've found a clue to the location of Martin's sword.

item.title: Meteorite Identification
item.description: [#1723] Click for an actual flowchart for identifying a meteorite. My favorite part is how 'Did someone see it fall? -> Yes' points to 'NOT A METEORITE.' This is not a mistake.

item.title: Proofs
item.description: [#1724] Next, let's assume the decision of whether to take the Axiom of Choice is made by a deterministic process ...

item.title: Linear Regression
item.description: [#1725] The 95% confidence interval suggests Rexthor's dog could also be a cat, or possibly a teapot.

item.title: Unicode
item.description: [#1726] I'm excited about the proposal to add a "brontosaurus" emoji codepoint because it has the potential to bring together a half-dozen different groups of pedantic people into a single glorious internet argument.

item.title: Number of Computers
item.description: [#1727] They try to pad their numbers in the annual reports by counting Galileo's redundant systems as multiple computers, but they're falling behind badly either way.

item.title: Cron Mail
item.description: [#1728] Take THAT, piece of 1980s-era infrastructure I've inexplicably maintained on my systems for 15 years despite never really learning how it works.

item.title: Migrating Geese
item.description: [#1729] "Hey guys! I have a great idea for a migration!" "Dammit, Kevin."

item.title: Starshade
item.description: [#1730] The New Worlds Mission is already trying to get funding for this, but NASA sponsored their proposal, so it will be hard to catch the telescope people by surprise with it.

item.title: Wrong
item.description: [#1731] Hang on, I just remembered another thing I'm right about. See...

item.title: Earth Temperature Timeline
item.description: [#1732] [After setting your car on fire] Listen, your car's temperature has changed before.

item.title: Solar Spectrum
item.description: [#1733] I still don't understand why the Sun paid the extra money for Transitions lenses.

item.title: Reductionism
item.description: [#1734] "I've noticed you physics people can be a little on the reductionist side." "That's ridiculous. Name ONE reductionist word I've ever said."

item.title: Fashion Police and Grammar Police
item.description: [#1735] * Mad about jorts

item.title: Manhattan Project
item.description: [#1736] On the plus side, we definitely killed that cancer over there, even if we caused a bunch more everywhere else.

item.title: Datacenter Scale
item.description: [#1737] Asimov's Cosmic AC was created by linking all datacenters through hyperspace, which explains a lot. It didn't reverse entropy--it just discarded the universe when it reached end-of-life and ordered a new one.

item.title: Moon Shapes
item.description: [#1738] Whenever I see a picture of the moon where the points go more than halfway around, I assume it's being eclipsed by one of those Independence Day ships and interpret the rest of the image in light of that.

item.title: Fixing Problems
item.description: [#1739] 'What was the original problem you were trying to fix?' 'Well, I noticed one of the tools I was using had an inefficiency that was wasting my time.'

item.title: Rosetta
item.description: [#1740] I WONDERED why he kept asking whether we thought the impact speed was too low.

item.title: Work
item.description: [#1741] Despite it being imaginary, I already have SUCH a strong opinion on the cord-switch firing incident.

item.title: Will It Work
item.description: [#1742] 'Copy and paste from a random thread on a website' is the hardest to predict, and depends on the specific website, programming language, tone of the description, and current phase of the moon.

item.title: Coffee
item.description: [#1743] Remind me to order another pack of coffee filters from Dyson. Man, these things are EXPENSIVE.

item.title: Metabolism
item.description: [#1744] I have this weird thing where if I don't drink enough water, I start feeling bad and then die of dehydration.

item.title: Record Scratch
item.description: [#1745] The 78-rpm era was closer to the Civil War than to today.

item.title: Making Friends
item.description: [#1746] "This seems more like a way to attract turkey vultures." "My mom always told me a turkey vulture is just a friend you haven't met yet, usually because you don't smell enough like decaying meat."

item.title: Spider Paleontology
item.description: [#1747] Whenever you see a video of birds doing something weird, remember: Birds are a small subset of dinosaurs, so the weirdness of birds is a small subset of the weirdness of dinosaurs.

item.title: Future Archaeology
item.description: [#1748] "The only link we've found between the two documents is that a fragment of the Noah one mentions Aaron's brother Moses parting an ocean. Is that right?" "... yes. Yes, exactly."

item.title: Mushrooms
item.description: [#1749] Evolutionarily speaking, mushrooms are technically a type of ghost.

item.title: Life Goals
item.description: [#1750] I got to check off 'Make something called xkcd' early.

item.title: Movie Folder
item.description: [#1751] That's actually the original Japanese version of A Million Random Digits, which is much better than the American remake the book was based on.

item.title: Interplanetary Experience
item.description: [#1752] But instead of hitting the ocean, you should land in an overheating hot tub on a sinking cruise ship, sending it crashing through the floor into the burning engine room as the ship goes under.

item.title: Thumb War
item.description: [#1753] "Seventeen, eighteen, nineteen, twenty--" / "Can't we just read Pat the Bunny?"

item.title: Tornado Safety Tips
item.description: [#1754] It's a myth that you can never cross mountains safely, but be sure you understand how the climatic situation there will affect your parent thunderstorm.

item.title: Old Days
item.description: [#1755] Lot of drama in those days, including constant efforts to force the "Reflections on Trusting Trust" guy into retirement so we could stop being so paranoid about compilers.

item.title: I'm With Her
item.description: [#1756] We can do this.

item.title: November 2016
item.description: [#1757] Once you've done this, make a note of how old they were. Then, when their age reaches double that, show them this chart again.

item.title: Astrophysics
item.description: [#1758] DEPARTMENT OF NEUROSCIENCE / Motto: "If I hear the phrase 'mirror neurons' I swear to God I will flip this table."

item.title: British Map
item.description: [#1759] West Norsussex is east of East Norwessex, but they're both far north of Middlesex and West Norwex.

item.title: TV Problems
item.description: [#1760] Certified skydiving instructors know way more about safely falling from planes than I do, and are way more likely to die that way.

item.title: Blame
item.description: [#1761] I bet if I yell at my scared friends I will feel better.

item.title: Moving Boxes
item.description: [#1762] Later, when I remember that I'm calling movers, I frantically scribble over the labels and write 'NORMAL HOUSE STUFF' on all of them, which actually makes things worse.

item.title: Catcalling
item.description: [#1763] Effect strength => [unstoppable] | Effect range => [2 miles] | Effect duration => [1 year]

item.title: XKCDE
item.description: [#1764] 4. They unplug the root machine but the thousands of leaf VMs scatter in the wind and start spinning up new instances wherever they land

item.title: Baby Post
item.description: [#1765] [bzzzt] "REMEMBER TO CHECK IN FOR YOUR FLIGHT TO LONDON." "My wha-" [bzzzt] "YOUR UBER WILL ARRIVE IN FOUR MINUTES."

item.title: Apple Spectrum
item.description: [#1766] If I were trapped on a desert island, and could have an unlimited supply of any one type of apple, I'd be like, "How did this situation happen?"

item.title: US State Names
item.description: [#1767] Technically DC isn't a state, but no one is too pedantic about it because they don't want to disturb the snakes.

item.title: Settling
item.description: [#1768] Of course, "Number of times I've gotten to make a decision twice to know for sure how it would have turned out" is still at 0.

item.title: Never Seen Star Wars
item.description: [#1769] If anyone calls you on any weird detail, just say it's from the Jedi Prince book series, which contains so much random incongruous stuff that even most Expanded Universe/Legends fans collectively agreed to forget about it decades ago.

item.title: UI Change
item.description: [#1770] I know they said this change is permanent, but surely when they hear how much we're complaining someone will find a way to change things back.

item.title: It Was I
item.description: [#1771] It me, your father.

item.title: Startup Opportunity
item.description: [#1772] While there's no formal regulation, it turns out their industry group is NOT one you want mad at you.

item.title: Negativity
item.description: [#1773] [Google search] how do I block my lawn

item.title: Adjective Foods
item.description: [#1774] Contains 100% of your recommended daily allowance!

item.title: Things You Learn
item.description: [#1775] Guess who has two thumbs and spent the night in an ER after trying to rescue a kitten that ran under his car at a stoplight and climbed up into the engine compartment? And, thanks to antibiotics, will continue having two thumbs? THIS GUY. (P.S. kitten is safe!)

item.title: Reindeer
item.description: [#1776] And then in a twinkling, a sound gave me pause / From the roof came the scratching of eight tarsal claws.

item.title: Dear Diary
item.description: [#1777] Dear Diary: UNSUBSCRIBE

item.title: Interest Timescales
item.description: [#1778] Sometimes, parts of a slowly-rising mountain suddenly rise REALLY fast, which is extra interesting.
[#1779] Things are looking good for the eclipse--Nate Silver says Earth will almost definitely still have a moon in August.

item.title: Appliance Repair
item.description: [#1780] [holding up a three-phase motor] As you can see here, the problem is that the humidifier I took this from is broken.

item.title: Artifacts
item.description: [#1781] I didn't even realize you could HAVE a data set made up entirely of outliers.

item.title: Team Chat
item.description: [#1782] 2078: He announces that he's finally making the jump from screen+irssi to tmux+weechat.

item.title: Emails
item.description: [#1783] Hey Rob, sorry it took me a while to get back to you! Sure, I'd love to see WALL-E opening weekend! Are you still doing that, or...?

item.title: Bad Map Projection: Liquid Resize
item.description: [#1784] This map preserves the shapes of Tissot's indicatrices pretty well, as long as you draw them in before running the resize.

item.title: Wifi
item.description: [#1785] Further out to the right, it works correctly, but the reason it works still involves the word 'firmware.'

item.title: Trash
item.description: [#1786] Plus, time's all weird in there, so most of it probably broke down and decomposed hundreds of years ago. Which reminds me, I've been meaning to get in touch with Yucca Mountain to see if they're interested in a partnership.

item.title: Voice Commands
item.description: [#1787] Dvorak words may sound hard to pronounce, but studies show they actually put less stress on the vocal cords.

item.title: Barge
item.description: [#1788] My life goal is to launch a barge into the air and have it land on one of Elon Musk's rockets.

item.title: Phone Numbers
item.description: [#1789] Texting should work. Unless the message is too long, in which case it gets converted to voicemails, and I think I'm locked out of my voicemail.

item.title: Sad
item.description: [#1790] With the right 90-degree rotation, any effect is a side effect.

item.title: Telescopes: Refractor vs Reflector
item.description: [#1791] On the other hand, the refractor's limited light-gathering means it's unable to make out shadow people or the dark god Chernabog.

item.title: Bird/Plane/Superman
item.description: [#1792] You can apply special translucent films to your windows to help keep birds/Superman from accidentally flying into them.

item.title: Soda Sugar Comparisons
item.description: [#1793] The key is portion control, which is why I've switched to eating smaller cans of frosting instead of full bottles.

item.title: Fire
item.description: [#1794] Billy Joel briefly detained

item.title: All You Can Eat
item.description: [#1795] After my absent-mindedness resulted in a bad posterboard-related stomachache, I learned to do the sign-making place last.

item.title: Focus Knob
item.description: [#1796] Maybe if I spin it back and forth really fast I can do some kind of pulse-width modulation.

item.title: Stardew Valley
item.description: [#1797] I have accidentally watered virtually every person and object in Pelican Town.

item.title: Box Plot
item.description: [#1798] You have to be careful doing this. Sometimes, when you push the whisker down, dynamite explodes.

item.title: Bad Map Projection: Time Zones
item.description: [#1799] This is probably the first projection in cartographic history that can be criticized for its disproportionate focus on Finland, Mongolia, and the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

item.title: Chess Notation
item.description: [#1800] I've decided to score all my conversations using chess win-loss notation. (??)

item.title: Decision Paralysis
item.description: [#1801] Good point--making no decision is itself a decision. So that's a THIRD option I have to research!

item.title: Phone
item.description: [#1802] [*disables social networking accounts*] [*social isolation increases*] Wait, why does this ALSO feel bad?

item.title: Location Reviews
item.description: [#1803] Google and Yelp keep deleting my scathing reviews of the Mariana Trench, the Chernobyl reactor core, the jet stream, and the equator.

item.title: Video Content
item.description: [#1804] "So, like, sexy news videos?" "No, people have tried that--it's still just video content. We need to actually inform people THROUGH making out. I would call it 'Mouth Content,' but I think that's already the title of a Neil Cicierega album."

item.title: Unpublished Discoveries
item.description: [#1805] If you must know, I'm currently researching how to save this emailed tax form as a regular PDF so I can print and sign it. Our work isn't a lock for the Nobel, but we're in the running.

item.title: Borrow Your Laptop
item.description: [#1806] If used with software that could keep up, a scroll wheel mapped to send a stream of 'undo' and 'redo' events could be kind of cool.

item.title: Listening
item.description: [#1807] Sure, you could just ask, but this also takes care of the host gift thing.

item.title: Hacking
item.description: [#1808] The dump also contains a list of millions of prime factors, a 0-day Tamagotchi exploit, and a technique for getting gcc and bash to execute arbitrary code.

item.title: xkcd Phone 5
item.description: [#1809] The phone will be collected by the toll operators and mailed back to you within 4-6 weeks.

item.title: Chat Systems
item.description: [#1810] I'm one of the few Instagram users who connects solely through the Unix 'talk' gateway.

item.title: Best-Tasting Colors
item.description: [#1811] I recognize that chocolate is its own thing on which reasonable people may differ. Everything else here is objective fact.

item.title: Onboarding
item.description: [#1812] 'So we just have a steady flow of metal piling up in our server room? Isn't that a problem?' 'Yeah, you should bring that up at our next bismuth meeting.'

item.title: Vomiting Emoji
item.description: [#1813] My favorite might be U+1F609 U+1F93F WINKING FACE VOMITING.

item.title: Color Pattern
item.description: [#1814] When the spacing is tight / And the difference is slight / That's a moir

item.title: Flag
item.description: [#1815] There's a compromise bill to keep the notification bar but at least charge the battery.

item.title: Mispronunciation
item.description: [#1816] I pronounce epitome "EPPY-tome", but EpiPen "uh-PIE-pen".

item.title: Incognito Mode
item.description: [#1817] They're really the worst tech support team. And their solutions are always the same. "This OS X update broke something." "LET'S INFILTRATE APPLE BY MORPHING APPLES!"

item.title: Rayleigh Scattering
item.description: [#1818] If you ask "why are leaves green?" the usual answer is "because they're full of chlorophyll, and chlorophyll is green," even though "why does chlorophyll scatter green light?" is a great question too.

item.title: Sweet 16
item.description: [#1819] Every year I make out my bracket at the season, and every year it's busted before the first game when I find out which teams are playing.

item.title: Security Advice
item.description: [#1820] Never give your password or bank account number to anyone who doesn't have a blue check mark next to their name.

item.title: Incinerator
item.description: [#1821] My trash can broke recently and I had to get rid of it. When I picked it up, I suffered a brief but harrowing existential crisis.

item.title: Existential Bug Reports
item.description: [#1822] ISSUE: If we wait long enough, the Earth will eventually be consumed by the Sun. WORKAROUND: None.

item.title: Hottest Editors
item.description: [#1823] Elon Musk finally blocked me from the internal Tesla repository because I wouldn't stop sending pull requests for my code supporting steering via vim keybindings.

item.title: Identification Chart
item.description: [#1824] Be carefulit's breeding season, and some of these can be *extremely* defensive of their nests.

item.title: 7 Eleven
item.description: [#1825] Really, the only honest 24-hour stores are the ones in places like Arizona and Hawaii, and many of them are still wrong in certain years.

item.title: Birdwatching
item.description: [#1826] No, tell the park rangers to calm down, it's fine--I put a screen on the front. I just want to get the birds a little closer.

item.title: Survivorship Bias
item.description: [#1827] They say you can't argue with results, but what kind of defeatist attitude is that? If you stick with it, you can argue with ANYTHING.

item.title: ISS Solar Transit
item.description: [#1828] I guess it's also the right setting for pictures of the Moon at night.

item.title: Geochronology
item.description: [#1829] 'The mountains near here formed when the ... Newfoundland ... microplate collided with, uhh ... Labrador.' 'Ok, now you're definitely just naming dogs.' 'Wait, no, that's actually almost correct.'

item.title: ISS Solar Transit 2
item.description: [#1830] Most people don't realize it, but they actually launch a new space station every few weeks because this keeps happening.

item.title: Here to Help
item.description: [#1831] "We TOLD you it was hard." "Yeah, but now that I'VE tried, we KNOW it's hard."

item.title: Photo Library Management
item.description: [#1832] A good lifehack is to use messy and unstable systems to organize your photos. That way, every five years or so it becomes obsolete and/or collapses, and you have to open it up and pick only your favorite pictures to salvage.

item.title: Code Quality 3
item.description: [#1833] It's like a half-solved cryptogram where the solution is a piece of FORTH code written by someone who doesn't know FORTH.

item.title: Lunch Order
item.description: [#1834] GO FOR LUNCH, REPEAT, GO FOR LUNCH.

item.title: Random Obsessions
item.description: [#1835] I take the view that "open-faced sandwiches" are not sandwiches, but all other physical objects are.

item.title: Okeanos
item.description: [#1836] WHEN I WAS ON A BOAT I DROPPED MY PHONE CAN U LOOK FOR IT

item.title: Rental Car
item.description: [#1837] Technically, both cars are haunted, but the murder ghosts can't stand listening to the broken GPS for more than a few minutes.

item.title: Machine Learning
item.description: [#1838] The pile gets soaked with data and starts to get mushy over time, so it's technically recurrent.

item.title: Doctor Visit
item.description: [#1839] According to these blood tests, you're like 30% cereal.

item.title: Genetic Testing Results
item.description: [#1840] That's very exciting! The bad news is that it's a risk factor for a lot of things.

item.title: Who?
item.description: [#1841] Gonna feel even dumber when I realize that all this time he's been talking into a bluetooth thingy and we're not actually friends.

item.title: Anti-Drone Eagles
item.description: [#1842] It's cool, it's totally ethical--they're all programmed to hunt whichever bird of prey is most numerous at the moment, so they leave the endangered ones alone until near the end.

item.title: Opening Crawl
item.description: [#1843] Using a classic Timothy Zahn EU/Legends novel is bad enough, but at least the style and setting aren't too far off. If you really want to mess with people, try using Splinter of the Mind's Eye.

item.title: Voting Systems
item.description: [#1844] Kenneth Arrow hated me because the ordering of my preferences changes based on which voting systems have what level of support. But it tells me a lot about the people I'm going to be voting with!

item.title: State Word Map
item.description: [#1845] The top search for every state is PORN, except Florida, where it's SEX PORN.

item.title: Drone Problems
item.description: [#1846] On the other hand, as far as they know, my system is working perfectly.

item.title: Dubious Study
item.description: [#1847] Sounds fine. I looked up the Academy, and it says on their MySpace page that their journal is peer-viewed and downloaded biannually.

item.title: Glacial Erratic
item.description: [#1848] "This will take a while, which sucks, because I'm already so busy chiseling out igneous intrusions from rock formations and watching Youtube loops of the Superman fault-sealing scene over and over."

item.title: Decades
item.description: [#1849] In the 90s, our variety radio station used the tagline "the best music of the 70s, 80s, and 90s." After 2000, they switched to "the best music of the 80s, 90s, and today." I figured they'd change again in 2010, but it's 2017 and they're still saying "80s, 90s, and today." I hope radio survives long enough for us to find out how they deal with the 2020s.

item.title: Air Force Museum
item.description: [#1850] I had fun visiting the museum at Dover Air Force Base, unless they don't have a museum, in which case I've never been to Delaware in my life.

item.title: Magnetohydrodynamics
item.description: [#1851] Magnetohydrodynamics combines the intuitive nature of Maxwell's equations with the easy solvability of the Navier-Stokes equations. It's so straightforward physicists add "relativistic" or "quantum" just to keep it from getting boring.

item.title: Election Map
item.description: [#1852] Luckily for my interpretation, no precincts were won by the Green Party.

item.title: Once Per Day
item.description: [#1853] I'm not totally locked into my routinetwice a year, I take a break to change the batteries in my smoke detectors.

item.title: Refresh Types
item.description: [#1854] The hardest refresh requires both a Mac keyboard and a Windows keyboard as a security measure, like how missile launch systems require two keys to be turned at once.

item.title: Telephoto
item.description: [#1855] I was banned from the airliners.net photography forum by concerned moderators after the end of my lens started brushing against planes as they flew by.

item.title: Existence Proof
item.description: [#1856] Real analysis is way realer than I expected.

item.title: Emoji Movie
item.description: [#1857] Some other studio should do the Antz/A Bug's Life thing and release The Dingbats Movie at the same time.

item.title: 4th of July
item.description: [#1858] Strangely, they still celebrate by eating hot dogs. Since they don't have mouths, they just kinda toss them in the air and let them fall back down into their propeller blades. It's pretty messy.

item.title: Sports Knowledge
item.description: [#1859] I heard they might make the wild card game, which would be cool. Do you know when that is? I have a wedding next weekend, but if it's after that we could try to go!

item.title: Communicating
item.description: [#1860] You're saying that the responsibility for avoiding miscommunication lies entirely with the listener, not the speaker, which explains why you haven't been able to convince anyone to help you down from that wall.

item.title: Quantum
item.description: [#1861] If you draw a diagonal line from lower left to upper right, that's the ICP 'Miracles' axis.

item.title: Particle Properties
item.description: [#1862] Each particle also has a password which allows its properties to be changed, but the cosmic censorship hypothesis suggests we can never observe the password itselfonly its secure hash.

item.title: Screenshots
item.description: [#1863] For the final exam, you take a screenshot showing off all the work you've done in the class, and it has to survive being uploaded, thumbnailed, and re-screenshotted through a chain of social media sites.

item.title: City Nicknames
item.description: [#1864] This place has so many demonyms. Northlanders. Fair Folk. Honey Barons. Lake Dwellers. Treasurers. Swamp Watchers. Dream Farmers. Wellfolk. Rockeaters. Forgotten Royals. Remote Clients. Barrow-Clerks. The People of Land and Sky.

item.title: Wifi vs Cellular
item.description: [#1865] According to the cable company reps who keep calling me, it's because I haven't upgraded to the XTREME GIGABAND PANAMAX FLAVOR-BLASTED PRO PACKAGE WITH HBO, which is only $5 more per month for the first 6 months and five billion dollars per month after that.

item.title: Russell's Teapot
item.description: [#1866] Unfortunately, NASA regulations state that Bertrand Russell-related payloads can only be launched within launch vehicles which do not launch themselves.

item.title: Physics Confession
item.description: [#1867] "You know lightning, right? When electric charge builds up in a cloud and then discharges in a giant spark? Ask me why that happens." "Why does tha--" "No clue. We think it's related to the hair thing."

item.title: Eclipse Flights
item.description: [#1868] The captain has turned on the 'fasten seat belt' sign.

item.title: Positive and Negative Reviews
item.description: [#1869] This restaurant is great! I was feeling really sick, but then I ate there and felt better!

item.title: Emoji Movie Reviews
item.description: [#1870] There's this idea that emoji are bad for communication because they replace ambiguity and nuance with a limited set of preselected emotions, but it doesn't really survive a collision with real-world usage of the thinking face or upside-down smiley.

item.title: Bun Alert
item.description: [#1871] Since buns range from crepuscular to nocturnal, it's recommended that you enable the scheduled "Do Not Disturb" mode on your phone to avoid being woken by alerts about Night Buns.

item.title: Backup Batteries
item.description: [#1872] If it falls below 20% full, my bag turns red and I start to panic.

item.title: Email Reply
item.description: [#1873] I would be honored, but I know I don't belong in your network. The person you invited was someone who had not yet inflicted this two-year ordeal upon you. I'm no longer that person.

item.title: Geologic Faults
item.description: [#1874] I live on a torn-bag-of-potato-chips-where-the-tear-is-rapidly-growing fault, which is terrifying.

item.title: Computers vs Humans
item.description: [#1875] It's hard to train deep learning algorithms when most of the positive feedback they get is sarcastic.

item.title: Eclipse Searches
item.description: [#1876] There were traffic jams for the eclipses in 1970 and 1979, and that was *before* we had the potential for overnight viral social media frenzies.

item.title: Eclipse Science
item.description: [#1877] I was thinking of observing stars to verify Einstein's theory of relativity again, but I gotta say, that thing is looking pretty solid at this point.

item.title: Earth Orbital Diagram
item.description: [#1878] You shouldn't look directly at a partial eclipse because of the damage that can be caused by improperly aligning the solar-lunar orbital plane with the orbital bones around your eye.

item.title: Eclipse Birds
item.description: [#1879] 'Hey! Put her down!' 'No, it's ok! The next chance for me to be carried to a blood cauldron isn't until 2024!'

item.title: Eclipse Review
item.description: [#1880] I watched from a beautiful nature reserve in central Missouri, and it was--without exaggeration--the coolest thing I've ever seen.

item.title: Drone Training
item.description: [#1881] The joke will be on him in a few weeks when animal control shows up and takes custody of his Roomba.

item.title: Color Models
item.description: [#1882] What if what *I* see as blue, *you* see as a slightly different blue because you're using Chrome instead of Firefox and despite a decade of messing with profiles we STILL can't get this right somehow.

item.title: Supervillain Plan
item.description: [#1883] Someday, some big historical event will happen during the DST changeover, and all the tick-tock articles chronicling how it unfolded will have to include a really annoying explanation next to their timelines.

item.title: Ringer Volume/Media Volume
item.description: [#1884] Our new video ad campaign has our product's name shouted in the first 500 milliseconds, so we can reach the people in adjacent rooms while the viewer is still turning down the volume.

item.title: Ensemble Model
item.description: [#1885] I'm in talks with Netflix to produce an alternate-universe crime drama about the world where sliced bread was never re-legalized, but it's going slowly because they keep changing their phone numbers and the door lock codes at their headquarters.

item.title: Typing Notifications
item.description: [#1886] Over the years I've decided I'd rather have them on than not, but I'm glad there aren't "has opened a blank note to compose a reply to you" notifications.

item.title: Two Down, One to Go
item.description: [#1887] The third row will probably have to wait until 2034, and maybe longer. If I see a daytime supernova, I'll replace the meteor storm with that and consider it 3/3.

item.title: Still in Use
item.description: [#1888] 'Which one?' 'I dunno, it's your house. Just check each object.' 'Check it for *what*?' 'Whether it looks like it might have touched a paper towel at some point and then forgotten to let go.' '...' 'You can also Google to learn how to check which things are using which resources.' 'You know, I'll just leave the towel there and try again tomorrow.'

item.title: xkcd Phone 6
item.description: [#1889] We understand your privacy concerns; be assured that our phones will never store or transmit images of your face.

item.title: What to Bring
item.description: [#1890] I always figured you should never bring a gun to a gun fight because then you'll be part of a gun fight.

item.title: Obsolete Technology
item.description: [#1891] And I can't believe some places still use fax machines. The electrical signals waste so much time going AROUND the Earth when neutrino beams can go straight through!

item.title: USB Cables
item.description: [#1892] Tag yourself, I'm "frayed."

item.title: Thread
item.description: [#1893] Since the current Twitter threadfall kicked off in early 2016, we can expect it to continue until the mid 2060s when the next Interval begins.

item.title: Real Estate
item.description: [#1894] I tried converting the prices into pizzas, to put it in more familiar terms, and it just became a hard-to-think-about number of pizzas.

item.title: Worrying Scientist Interviews
item.description: [#1895] They always try to explain that they're called 'solar physicists', but the reporters interrupt with "NEVER MIND THAT, TELL US WHAT'S WRONG WITH THE SUN!"

item.title: Active Ingredients Only
item.description: [#1896] Contains the active ingredients from all competing cold medicines, plus the medicines for headaches, arthritis, insomnia, indigestion, and more, because who wants THOSE things?

item.title: Self Driving
item.description: [#1897] "Crowdsourced steering" doesn't sound quite as appealing as "self driving."

item.title: October 2017
item.description: [#1898] And yet I have no trouble believing that the start of the 2016 election was several decades ago.

item.title: Ears
item.description: [#1899] My theory is that most humans have been colonized with alien mind-control slugs that hold the earbuds for them, and the ones who can't wear earbuds are the only surviving free ones.

item.title: Jet Lag
item.description: [#1900] I had some important research to do on proposed interstellar space missions, basketball statistics, canceled skyscrapers, and every article linked from "Women in warfare and the military in the 19th century."

item.title: Logical
item.description: [#1901] It's like I've always said--people just need more common sense. But not the kind of common sense that lets them figure out that they're being condescended to by someone who thinks they're stupid, because then I'll be in trouble.

item.title: State Borders
item.description: [#1902] A schism between the pro-panhandle and anti-panhandle factions eventually led to war, but both sides spent too much time working on their flag designs to actually do much fighting.

item.title: Bun Trend
item.description: [#1903] Our experts have characterized the ecological impact of this trend as "adorable."

item.title: Research Risks
item.description: [#1904] The 1919 Great Boston Molasses Flood remained the deadliest confectionery containment accident until the Canadian Space Agency's 2031 orbital maple syrup delivery disaster.

item.title: Cast Iron Pan
item.description: [#1905] If you want to evenly space them, it's easiest to alternate between the Arctic and Antarctic. Some people just go to the Arctic twice, near the equinoxes so the visits are almost 6 months apart, but it's not the same.

item.title: Making Progress
item.description: [#1906] I started off with countless problems. But now I know, thanks to COUNT(), that I have "#REF! ERROR: Circular dependency detected" problems.

item.title: Immune System
item.description: [#1907] It also helps with negotiation. "Look, if it were up to me, *I'd* accept your offer, but my swarm of autonomous killer cells literally can't be reasoned with. It's out of my hands!"

item.title: Credit Card Rewards
item.description: [#1908] I should make a list of all the things I could be trying to optimize, prioritized by ... well, I guess there are a few different variables I could use. I'll create a spreadsheet ...

item.title: Digital Resource Lifespan
item.description: [#1909] I spent a long time thinking about how to design a system for long-term organization and storage of subject-specific informational resources without needing ongoing work from the experts who created them, only to realized I'd just reinvented libraries.

item.title: Sky Spotters
item.description: [#1910] Where I live, one of the most common categories of sky object without a weird obsessive spotting community is "lost birthday party balloons," so that might be a good choicealthough you risk angering the marine wildlife people, and they have sharks.

item.title: Defensive Profile
item.description: [#1911] NO DRAMA ZONE -> If I've made you sad, you'd better not tell me, because I am TERRIFIED of that situation and have NO IDEA how to handle it.

item.title: Thermostat
item.description: [#1912] Your problem is so terrible, I worry that, if I help you, I risk drawing the attention of whatever god of technology inflicted it on you.

item.title: A
item.description: [#1913] If you want in on the fun, map a key on your keyboard to the sequence U+0041 U+0020 U+FFFD (or U+0021 U+0020 U+FFFD for the exclamation point version), and then no update can never take this away from you.

item.title: Twitter Verification
item.description: [#1914] When we started distributing special status tokens that signify which people are important enough to join an elite group, we never could have imagined we might be creating some problems down the line.

item.title: Nightmare Email Feature
item.description: [#1915] "...just got back and didn't see your message until just now. Sorry! -- TIME THIS MESSAGE SAT HALF-FINISHED IN DRAFTS FOLDER: 3 days, 2 hours, 45 minutes."

item.title: Temperature Preferences
item.description: [#1916] There's a supposed Mark Twain quote, "The coldest winter I ever spent was a summer in San Francisco." It isn't really by Mark Twain, but I don't know who said itI just know they've never been to McMurdo Station.

item.title: How to Make Friends
item.description: [#1917] No, wait, come back! I want to be friends at you!

item.title: NEXUS
item.description: [#1918] You also refuse to buy Cisco products because you hate the Thong Song, O. Henry, Deep Space Nine, freshwater whitefish, teenaged Incan emperors, Brak's brother, and vegetable-based shortening.

item.title: Interstellar Asteroid
item.description: [#1919] Every time we detect an asteroid from outside the Solar System, we should immediately launch a mission to fling one of our asteroids back in the direction it came from.

item.title: Emoji Sports
item.description: [#1920] No horse has yet managed the elusive Quadruple Crownwinning the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness, the Belmont Stakes, and the Missouri Horse Hole.

item.title: The Moon and the Great Wall
item.description: [#1921] And arguably sunspots, on rare occasions. But even if they count, it takes ideal conditions and you might hurt your eyes.

item.title: Interferometry
item.description: [#1922] It's important to note that while the effective size of the dog can be arbitrarily large, it's not any more of a good dog than the two original dogs.

item.title: Felsius
item.description: [#1923] The symbol for degrees Felsius is an average of the Euro symbol () and the Greek lunate epsilon ().

item.title: Solar Panels
item.description: [#1924] This works for a surprising range of sunlit things, including rooftops (sure), highway surfaces (probably not), sailboats (maybe), and jets, cars, and wild deer (haha good luck).

item.title: Self-Driving Car Milestones
item.description: [#1925] I'm working on a car capable of evaluating arbitrarily complex boolean expressions on "honk if [...]" bumper stickers and responding accordingly.

item.title: Bad Code
item.description: [#1926] "Oh my God, why did you scotch-tape a bunch of hammers together?" "It's ok! Nothing depends on this wall being destroyed efficiently."

item.title: Tinder
item.description: [#1927] People keep telling me to use the radio but I really hate making voice calls.

item.title: Seven Years
item.description: [#1928] [hair in face] "SEVVVENNN YEEEARRRSSS"

item.title: Argument Timing
item.description: [#1929] Of course, everyone has their own profile. There are morning arguers, hangry arguers, meal-time arguers, late-night arguers, and people who get in a meta-argument over what their argument timing is, dredge up examples of past arguments, and end up fighting over THOSE again as well.

item.title: Calendar Facts
item.description: [#1930] While it may seem like trivia, it (causes huge headaches for software developers / is taken advantage of by high-speed traders / triggered the 2003 Northeast Blackout / has to be corrected for by GPS satellites / is now recognized as a major cause of World War I).

item.title: Virtual Assistant
item.description: [#1931] If you ask it to please turn off that feature, it apologizes a whole bunch and promises to try to be quieter, then switches to a slightly lower-volume version of the clip with "sorry!" after the louder sounds.

item.title: The True Meaning of Christmas
item.description: [#1932] They all made fun of Autometalogolex, but someday there will be a problem with Christmas that can only be solved if Santa somehow gets a serious headache, and then they'll see.

item.title: Santa Facts
item.description: [#1933] We've gotten him up to 20% milk and cookies through an aggressive public campaign, but that seems to be his dietary limit. Anything above that and he starts developing nutritional deficiencies.

item.title: Phone Security
item.description: [#1934] ...wait until they type in payment information, then use it to order yourself a replacement phone.
[#1935] We should really start calculating it earlier, but until the end of December we're always too busy trying to figure out which day Christmas will fall on.

item.title: Desert Golfing
item.description: [#1936] I just want to stay up long enough to watch the ball drop into the hole number 2018.

item.title: IATA Airport Abbreviations
item.description: [#1937] IATA stands for International AirporT Abbreviation.

item.title: Meltdown and Spectre
item.description: [#1938] New zero-day vulnerability: In addition to rowhammer, it turns out lots of servers are vulnerable to regular hammers, too.

item.title: 2016 Election Map
item.description: [#1939] I like the idea of cartograms (distorted population maps), but I feel like in practice they often end up being the worst of both worldsnot great for showing geography OR counting people. And on top of that, they have all the problems of a chloro... chorophl... chloropet... map with areas colored in.

item.title: The Food Size Cycle
item.description: [#1940] There's data suggesting that this model may apply to deep-dish/thin-crust pizza. I've designed a thorough multi-year study to investigate this personally, but funding organizations keep denying my grant requests.

item.title: Dying Gift
item.description: [#1941] And to you, I leave my life-sized ice sculpture replica of the Piet which was blessed by the Pope. You must never let it melt! Now, remember, all gifts must be removed from my estate within 24 hours.

item.title: Memorable Quotes
item.description: [#1942] "Since there's no ending quote mark, everything after this is part of my quote. Randall Munroe

item.title: Universal Dreams
item.description: [#1943] "That's ... unsettling." "Yeah, those definitely don't sound like the normal drea ..."

item.title: The End of the Rainbow
item.description: [#1944] The retina is the exposed surface of the brain, so if you think about a pot of gold while looking at a rainbow, then there's one at BOTH ends.

item.title: Scientific Paper Graph Quality
item.description: [#1945] The worst are graphs with qualitative, vaguely-labeled axes and very little actual data.

item.title: Hawaii
item.description: [#1946] Ok, I've got it, just need to plug in my security key. Hmm, which way does the USB go? Nope, not that way. I'll just flip it and OH JEEZ IT FELL INTO THE VENT.

item.title: Night Sky
item.description: [#1947] There's a mountain lion nearby, but it didn't notice you because it's reading Facebook.

item.title: Campaign Fundraising Emails
item.description: [#1948] The establishment doesn't take us seriously. You know who else they didn't take seriously? Hitler. I'll be like him, but a GOOD guy instead of...

item.title: Fruit Collider
