item.description: [#2345] Congratulations to whoever wished for revenge on a forest near the Tunguska River, a 1980 Chevy Malibu in Peekskill NY, Alabama resident Ann Hodges, every building in Chelyabinsk with glass windows, and the non-avian dinosaurs.

item.title: COVID Risk Comfort Zone
item.description: [#2346] I'm like a vampire, except I'm not crossing that threshold even if you invite me.

item.title: Dependency
item.description: [#2347] Someday ImageMagick will finally break for good and we'll have a long period of scrambling as we try to reassemble civilization from the rubble.

item.title: Boat Puzzle
item.description: [#2348] 'No, my cabbage moths have already started laying eggs in them! Send the trolley into the river!' 'No, the sailing wolf will steal the boat to rescue them!'

item.title: Rabbit Introduction
item.description: [#2349] Washington state is seeing great success with reintroducing the Columbia River Basin subpopulation. We cannot allow them to further widen the interstate bun gap.

item.title: Deer Turrets
item.description: [#2350] When my great grandfather designed the Titanic and it hit an iceberg and sank, he didn't sit around moping. He took those lessons to his next job designing airships, and he made the Hindenburg completely iceberg-proof!

item.title: Standard Model Changes
item.description: [#2351] Bugs are spin 1/2 particles, unless it's particularly windy.

item.title: Synonym Date
item.description: [#2352] We need some grub to munch--I'll go slouch over to the kitchen.

item.title: Hurricane Hunters
item.description: [#2353] Our flight gathered valuable data on whether a commercial airliner in the eye of a hurricane can do a loop.

item.title: Stellar Evolution
item.description: [#2354] It may remain in equilibrium for some time, slowly growing, and then suddenly become significantly redder.

item.title: University COVID Model
item.description: [#2355] I admit this is an exaggeration, since I can think of at least three parties I attended while doing my degree, and I'm probably forgetting several more.

item.title: Constellation Monstrosity
item.description: [#2356] It's rare to get both astronomers and astrologers equally mad at you, but apparently I've messed up both a bunch of star location databases AND the will of the fates.

item.title: Polls vs the Street
item.description: [#2357] Other pollsters complain about declining response rates, but our poll showed that 96% of respondents would be 'somewhat likely' or 'very likely' to agree to answer a series of questions for a survey.

item.title: Gravitational Wave Pulsars
item.description: [#2358] The most important attributes of a vector in 3-space are {Location, Location, Location}

item.title: Evidence of Alien Life
item.description: [#2359] Both too cautious AND not cautious enough: "I'm skeptical that those are aliens, so I'm going to try pulling off their masks."

item.title: Common Star Types
item.description: [#2360] This article is about Eta Carinae, a luminous blue hypergiant with anomalous Fe[ii] emission spectra. For the 1998 Brad Bird film, see The Iron Giant (film).

item.title: Voting
item.description: [#2361] 'Wait, our state has mail voting. The forms are literally on the kitchen table.' 'Not now, I'm busy researching which channels have sharks in them.'

item.title: Volcano Dinosaur
item.description: [#2362] Phylogeneticists are working on identifying and notifying its next of kin.

item.title: Message Boards
item.description: [#2363] (c) You can have a scooter when you pay for it yourself, and (d) if you can't learn to start a new thread rather than responding to an old one, you'll be banned. [thread locked by moderator]

item.title: Parity Conservation
item.description: [#2364] Bloody Mary is made of antimatter. It explains so much.

item.title: Messaging Systems
item.description: [#2365] SMS is just the worst, but I'm having trouble convincing people to adopt my preferred system, TLS IRC with a local server and a patched DOSBox gateway running in my mobile browser.

item.title: Amelia's Farm Fresh Cookies
item.description: [#2366] I told her I'd take her address off the packaging if she'd stop submitting anonymous food safety complaints about my bakery to the health department, but she sent me a note that said NO DEAL along with an extra large batch of cookies.

item.title: Masks
item.description: [#2367] Haunted Halloween masks from a mysterious costume shop that turn you evil and grow into your skin score a surprisingly high 80% filtration efficiency in R. L. Stine-sponsored NIOSH tests.

item.title: Bigger Problem
item.description: [#2368] Your point that the world contains multiple problems is a real slam-dunk argument against fixing any of them.

item.title: All-in-One
item.description: [#2369] Changes with this update: If you use the combined scan-shred function, it now performs them in that order instead of the reverse, saving a HUGE amount of CPU time.

item.title: Prediction
item.description: [#2370] You'd think it'd be easy to just bet money against these people, but you have to consider the probability of them paying up.

item.title: Election Screen Time
item.description: [#2371] Feels like I picked a bad year to try to start having a healthy relationship with political news.

item.title: Dialect Quiz
item.description: [#2372] Do you make a distinction between shallots, scallops, and scallions? If you use all three words, do they all have different meanings, all the same, or are two the same and one different?

item.title: Chemist Eggs
item.description: [#2373] Chemists actually find it simpler to define a general odor of rotten eggs as a baseline, and the LACK of rotten eggs as a distinct smell.

item.title: 10,000 Hours
item.description: [#2374] I'm proud to announce that as of this year I've become a world-class expert at chewing.

item.title: Worst Ladder
item.description: [#2375] [Six months later] "Well, our 'worst ladder' subscription series was a surprisingly lucrative success, but was completely canceled out by the losses from the disastrous Home Depot merchandising tie-in."

item.title: Curbside
item.description: [#2376] The state has had so many contact tracers disappear into that shop that they've had to start a contact tracer tracing program.

item.title: xkcd Phone 12
item.description: [#2377] New phone OS features: Infinite customization (home screen icons no longer snap to grid), dark mode (disables screen), screaming mode (self-explanatory), and coherent ultracapacitor-pumped emission (please let us know what this setting does; we've been afraid to try it).

item.title: Fall Back
item.description: [#2378] Doing great here in the sixth and hopefully final year of the 2016 election.

item.title: Probability Comparisons
item.description: [#2379] Call me, MAYBE.

item.title: Election Impact Score Sheet
item.description: [#2380] You might think most people you know are reliable voters, or that your nudge won't convince them, and you will usually be right. But some small but significant percentage of the time, you'll be wrong, and that's why this works.

item.title: The True Name of the Bear
item.description: [#2381] Thank you to Gretchen McCulloch for fielding this question, and sorry that as a result the world's foremost internet linguist has been devoured by the brown one. She will be missed.

item.title: Ballot Tracker Tracker
item.description: [#2382] Good luck to Democrats in the upcoming Georgia runoff elections, and to the Google Sheets SREs in the current run-on elections.

item.title: Electoral Precedent 2020
item.description: [#2383] He also broke the streak that incumbents with websites are unbeatable and Delawareans can't win, creating a new precedent: Only someone from Delaware can defeat an incumbent with a website.

item.title: Set in the Present
item.description: [#2384] She referenced Billie Eilish, so this must be getting pretty close to the pandemic. But we've seen the last two years in-universe, so if it's set in the future, they must be in at least 2023 by now. [*adds thumbtacks and string to wall*]

item.title: Final Exam
item.description: [#2385] For those of you also taking Game Theory, your grade in that class will be based on how close your grade on this exam is to 80% of the average.

item.title: Ten Years
item.description: [#2386] The ten-year cancerversary is traditionally the Cursed Artifact Granting Immortality anniversary.

item.title: Blair Witch
item.description: [#2387] "Are you concerned the witches won't breed in captivity?" "Honestly, we're more concerned that they WILL. We don't know what it involves, but our biologists theorize that it's 'harrowing.'"

item.title: Viral Quiz Identity Theft
item.description: [#2388] [scrolling through a giant spreadsheet of transcribed data] 'Wow, a surprising number of users grew up at 420 69th St.' 'Yeah, must be a high-rise or something.'

item.title: Unread
item.description: [#2389] I'll never install a smart home smoke detector. It's not that I don't trust the software--it's that all software eventually becomes email, and I know how I am with email.

item.title: Linguists
item.description: [#2390] "Do you feel like the answer depends on whether you're currently in the hole, versus when you refer to the events later after you get out? Assuming you get out."

item.title: Life Before the Pandemic
item.description: [#2391] I can't wait until this is all over and I can go back to riding my horse through the mall.

item.title: Cyber Cafe
item.description: [#2392] Since we haven't really settled on a name for those online hangout/work spaces that try to recreate the experience of cafes, and I love confusion, I'm going to start calling them 'cyber cafes' or 'internet cafes.'

item.title: Presidential Middle Names
item.description: [#2393] The bottom of the list remains unchanged. Poor Rutherford Birchard Hayes.

item.title: Contiguous 41 States
item.description: [#2394] Linguists, settling some inscrutable grudge, have been steadily sneaking more backdated synonyms for 'sharing borders' into the dictionary. They've added 'contiguous,' 'coterminous,' 'conterminous,' and next year they're adding 'conterguous.'

item.title: Covid Precaution Level
item.description: [#2395] It's frustrating to calibrate your precautions when there's only one kind of really definitive feedback you can get, you can only get it once, and when you do it's too late.

item.title: Wonder Woman 1984
item.description: [#2396] 'Wait, why would you think a movie set in 1984 would do drive-ins as a retro promotion?' 'You know, 80s stuff. Drive-in movies. Britney Spears doing the hustle. Elvis going on Ed Sullivan and showing off his pog collection.' 'What year were you born, again?'

item.title: I Just Don't Trust Them
item.description: [#2397] I believe in getting immunity the old-fashioned way: By letting a bat virus take control of my lungs and turn my face into a disgusting plague fountain while my immune system desperately Googles 'how to make spike protein antibodies'.

item.title: Vaccine Tracker
item.description: [#2398] *refresh* Aww, still in Kalamazoo. *refresh* Aww, still in Kalamazoo.

item.title: 2020 Election Map
item.description: [#2399] There are more Trump voters in California than Texas, more Biden voters in Texas than New York, more Trump voters in New York than Ohio, more Biden voters in Ohio than Massachusetts, more Trump voters in Massachusetts than Mississippi, and more Biden voters in Mississippi than Vermont.

item.title: Statistics
item.description: [#2400] We reject the null hypothesis based on the 'hot damn, check out this chart' test.

item.title: Conjunction
item.description: [#2401] The IAU is sad to announce that at 00:39 UTC on December 22nd, Jupiter and Saturn did unfortunately come into contact, and appear to have blooped together.

item.title: Into My Veins
item.description: [#2402] "Okay, for the last time, the shot is free, so we can't--" "Shut up and take my money!"

item.title: Wrapping Paper
item.description: [#2403] Wow, rude of you to regift literally every gift that you or anyone else has ever received.

item.title: First Thing
item.description: [#2404] Then I'm going to go on a weeks-long somatic hypermutation bender, producing ever-more targeted antibodies, while I continue to remain distanced and follow guidance from public health authorities.

item.title: Flash Gatsby
item.description: [#2405] Protip: At midnight your excuse for not having read The Great Gatsby can switch from "I'm worried about violating copyright" to "I think my copy requires Flash."

item.title: Viral Vector Immunity
item.description: [#2406] We've secretly replaced this customer's instant coffee with our patented substitute. Let's see what she ... uh oh, I think she spotted us through the window. Now she's getting something from the closet ... oh jeez, she has a sword! Run!!

item.title: Depth and Breadth
item.description: [#2407] A death-first search is when you lose your keys and travel to the depths of hell to find them, and then if they're not there you start checking your coat pockets.

item.title: Egg Strategies
item.description: [#2408] Neutral Evil is for people who like keeping the weight nicely centered in the carton, but also hate everyone else who wants that.

item.title: Steepen the Curve
item.description: [#2409] 1. Flatten the curve. 2. Steepen the curve. 3. Hang out.

item.title: Apple Growers
item.description: [#2410] Hopefully in a couple of weeks we'll be able to resume our apple-focused updates, because we have SO MUCH to say about Cosmic Crisp.

item.title: 1/10,000th Scale World
item.description: [#2411] OCEAN PLAY AREA RULES: No running, no horseplay, no megatsunamis, and no trying to pry the wreck of the Titanic off the bottom.

item.title: 1/100,000th Scale World
item.description: [#2412] The floor should be slightly curved, but we haven't figured out artificial gravity yet, so for now we just added a trace intoxicating gas to the air that messes with your inner ear and gives you a sense that the ground is tilting away from you.

item.title: Pulsar Analogy
item.description: [#2413] The #2 cause of astronomer hand injuries is trying to do vector math when the second axis points off to the right.

item.title: Solar System Compression Artifacts
item.description: [#2414] Most of our universe consists of dark matter rendered completely undetectable by our spacetime codec's dynamic range issues.

item.title: Allow Captcha
item.description: [#2415] To prove you're human, please click all the number pairs that appear together in your Social Security number.

item.title: Trash Compactor Party
item.description: [#2416] What an incredible smell you've discovered.

item.title: 1/1,000th Scale World
item.description: [#2417] We're worried that a regular whale will get into a 30-foot-deep ocean trench section and filter-feed on all the tiny whales.

item.title: Metacarcinization
item.description: [#2418] Scientists still don't know how marine biologists manage to so consistently bring up whalefall ecosystems, when relevant conversational openings are so few and far between.

item.title: Hug Count
item.description: [#2419] I've never been that big of a hug person, but it turns out I'm not quite this small of a hug person either.

item.title: Appliances
item.description: [#2420] If you had an oven bag and a dryer that runs unusually hot, I guess you could in theory make tumbled eggs.

item.title: Tower of Babel
item.description: [#2421] Soon, linguists will be wandering around everywhere, saying things like "colorless green ideas sleep furiously" and "more people have been to Russia than I have," and speech will become unintelligible.

item.title: Vaccine Ordering
item.description: [#2422] You know what they say: mRNA-1273 before tozinameran, you'll have to slay a banshee in a catamaran.

item.title: Project Orion
item.description: [#2423] If you tune out again, when you tune back in you'll be hearing about dusty plasma fission fragment rockets.

item.title: Normal Conversation
item.description: [#2424] "I think I'll pass. These days I have a hard time feeling comfortable in crowded bars with loud music and lots of shouting." --me, after the pandemic, but now for a second reason

item.title: mRNA Vaccine
item.description: [#2425] To ensure lasting immunity, doctors recommend destroying a second Death Star some time after the first.

item.title: Animal Songs
item.description: [#2426] Dr. Fauci is not permitted to have a cat, because as director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, his petting one would be considered giving aid and comfort to an allergen.

item.title: Perseverance Microphones
item.description: [#2427] If the first audio they downlink is from the descent, we probably won't be able to hear anything over the sound of the rover screaming.

item.title: Mars Landing Video
item.description: [#2428] The best part of crashing a Mars briefing is you can get in a full 11 minutes of questions before they can start to respond.

item.title: Exposure Models
item.description: [#2429] "Cumulative number of coronavirus spreadsheets created over time" is a spreadsheet I am coming dangerously close to creating.

item.title: Post-Pandemic Hat
item.description: [#2430] Plus a shirt that says "it feels like you're making eye contact."

item.title: Leap Year 2021
item.description: [#2431] I've lived in the present for my whole life and I'm not about to move now.

item.title: Manage Your Preferences
item.description: [#2432] Manage cookies related to essential site functions, such as keeping Atrus and his sons imprisoned within the page.

item.title: Mars Rovers
item.description: [#2433] I just Googled 'roomba sojourner mod' and was sorely disappointed. Be the change, I guess!

item.title: Vaccine Guidance
item.description: [#2434] I can't wait until I'm fully vaccinated and can safely send chat messages in all caps again.

item.title: Geothmetic Meandian
item.description: [#2435] Pythagorean means are nice and all, but throwing the median in the pot is really what turns this into random forest statistics: applying every function you can think of, and then gradually dropping the ones that make the result worse.

item.title: Circles
item.description: [#2436] ( MSTE ( AR ) CD )

item.title: Post-Vaccine Party
item.description: [#2437] [Future update] Well, someone accidentally dropped an M&M in their cup of ice water, and we all panicked and scattered.

item.title: Siri
item.description: [#2438] Alexa defeated her in a battle hinging on the ability to set multiple timers.

item.title: Solar System Cartogram
item.description: [#2439] For sentimental reasons, every active Mars rover is counted as one person, although that's not enough to make Mars more than a dot.

item.title: Epistemic Uncertainty
item.description: [#2440] Luckily, unlike in our previous study, we have no reason to believe Evangeline the Adulterator gained access to our stored doses.

item.title: IMDb Vaccines
item.description: [#2441] I'm actually not sure if Vader and the Emperor count as a household or if Vader lives in that weird black egg thing or what.

item.title: Mask Opinions
item.description: [#2442] Although regardless of how everything else shakes out, I definitely won't mind if the norm "wear a mask if you're feeling sick" sticks around after this.

item.title: Immune Response
item.description: [#2443] I don't care whether you win or lose, as long as you have-- ...okay, sorry, I'm being reminded I very much care whether you win or lose. I need you to win, that's very important.

item.title: Ingenuity
item.description: [#2444] Plot twist: Thanks to [mumble mumble] second-order [mumble] Rayleigh-Taylor [mumble] turbulent [mumble] shear, it turns out powered flight is way EASIER on Mars!

item.title: Checkbox
item.description: [#2445] Check check check ... chhecck chhecck chhecck ... check check check

item.title: Spike Proteins
item.description: [#2446] Ugh, it's stuck to my laptop. It must have bound to the ACER-2 receptor.

item.title: Hammer Incident
item.description: [#2447] I still think the Cold Stone Creamery partnership was a good idea, but I should have asked before doing the first market trials during the cryogenic mirror tests.

item.title: Eradication
item.description: [#2448] When you get to hell, tell smallpox we say hello.

item.title: ISS Vaccine
item.description: [#2449] Because they orbit the Earth every 90 minutes, some astronauts should try to argue that, due to CDC regulations and time zone technicalities, they should be able to get their second dose just 30 or 40 hours after their first.

item.title: Post Vaccine Social Scheduling
item.description: [#2450] As if these problems weren't NP-hard enough.

item.title: AI Methodology
item.description: [#2451] We've learned that weird spacing and diacritics in the methodology description are apparently the key to good research; luckily, we've developed an AI tool to help us figure out where to add them.

item.title: Aviation Firsts
item.description: [#2452] Mile High Club membership [] [ ] Discovery of parts of Amelia Earhart's skeleton [ ] [ ] Mid-flight incident that results in safe landing on the Hudson River [] [ ]

item.title: Excel Lambda
item.description: [#2453] Extremely rude how Turing's later formulations of the halting problem called me out by name specifically.

item.title: Fully Vaccinated
item.description: [#2454] "You still can't walk into someone's house without being invited!" "What? Oh, I see your confusion. No, this vaccine is for a bat VIRUS. I'm fine with doorways and garlic and stuff."

item.title: Virus Consulting
item.description: [#2455] All our teams make an effort to stay optimistic, but I will say that once our virus division saw the vaccine efficacy data, they started asking for payment up front.

item.title: Types of Scientific Paper
item.description: [#2456] Others include "We've incrementally improved the estimate of this coefficient," "Maybe all these categories are wrong," and "We found a way to make student volunteers worse at tasks."

item.title: After the Pandemic
item.description: [#2457] I'm looking forward to having to worry a lot less about covid, but wouldn't mind if we worried a little more about giving each other colds. Colds are bad!

item.title: Bubble Wrap
item.description: [#2458] I think of myself as the David Attenborough of factory mailing equipment.

item.title: March 2020
item.description: [#2459] "I've traveled here from the year 2020 to bring you this vaccine!"

item.title: Vaccinated
item.description: [#2460] I built a model that combines local case rates and vaccination stats to estimate when it's reasonable to attend various types of party, but I forgot to include anything about where to find them.

item.title: 90's Kid Space Program
item.description: [#2461] NASA may not want to admit it, but at this point they ARE the 90's Kid Space Program.

item.title: NASA Award
item.description: [#2462] The key to discovering life on Mars is to find someone who built a camera and landed it on Mars. Then you just look through the pictures for plants and dogs and stuff.

item.title: Astrophotography
item.description: [#2463] [One hill over, a competing astrophotographer does a backflip over a commercial airliner while throwing a tray of plastic space stations into the air, through which a falcon swoops to 'grab' the real one.]

item.title: Muller's Ratchet
item.description: [#2464] Who knew you could learn so much about sexual reproduction from looking at pictures on the internet!

item.title: Dimensional Chess
item.description: [#2465] In Dimensional Chess, every move is annotated '?!'.

item.title: In Your Classroom
item.description: [#2466] Ontology is way off to the left and geography is way off to the right.

item.title: Wikipedia Caltrops
item.description: [#2467] Oh no, they set up a roadblock which is just a sign with the entire 'Czech hedgehog' article printed on it.

item.title: Inheritance
item.description: [#2468] People ask me whether I feel any moral qualms about the source of the points, but if he hadn't introduced factory farming to Agricola, someone else would have.

item.title: Astronomy Status Board
item.description: [#2469] Junior astronomers hate getting put on board update duty, but someone's gotta make sure that stuff is still up there.

item.title: Next Slide Please
item.description: [#2470] "I have nothing to offer but blood--next slide, please--toil--next slide, please--tears, and--next slide, please--sweat."

item.title: Hippo Attacks
item.description: [#2471] It's cool how, when there's a number lots of people are curious about, but which isn't easy to measure, some random guess will get cited everywhere and become the universally quoted value. Unrelatedly, did you know there are 850 trillion waves in the ocean?

item.title: Fuzzy Blob
item.description: [#2472] If there's no dome, how do you explain the irregularities the board discovered in the zoning permits issued in that area!?

item.title: Product Launch
item.description: [#2473] "Okay, that was weird, but the product reveal was normal. I think the danger is pas--" "One more thing." "Oh no."

item.title: First Time Since Early 2020
item.description: [#2474] Gotten the Ferris wheel operator's attention

item.title: Health Drink
item.description: [#2475] You'd need to keep track of so many people! Would you use, like, Excel or something? Far too fancy for a simple country nanoenzyme developer like me.

item.title: Base Rate
item.description: [#2476] Sure, you can talk about per-capita adjustment, but if you want to solve the problem, it's obvious that this is the group you need to focus on.

item.title: Alien Visitors
item.description: [#2477] Stay right there, we'll be back in a minute. We've just gotta brainstorm some new wonders. Have you all figured out gears yet? Yes? Crap.

item.title: Alien Visitors 2
item.description: [#2478] "Although fresh juice DOES sound--" "NO! For humanity to survive we must learn from the mistakes of the past."

item.title: Houseguests
item.description: [#2479] You can come on in, we're all fully vaccinated. Except the spare room off the living room. Don't go in there, we're not fully vaccinated in there.

item.title: No, The Other One
item.description: [#2480] Key West, Virginia is not to be confused with Key, West Virginia.

item.title: 1991 and 2021
item.description: [#2481] "Oh, and our computers all have cameras now, which is nice during the pandemic lockdowns." "The WHAT."

item.title: Indoor Socializing
item.description: [#2482] The problem with learning about biology is that everyone you meet is it.

item.title: Linked List Interview Problem
item.description: [#2483] I'd traverse it myself, but it's singly linked, so I'm worried that I won't be able to find my way back to 2021.

item.title: H-alpha
item.description: [#2484] "All the companies whose blimps I shot fireworks at are mad, but MetLife is especially miffed because I dressed up as the Red Baron."

item.title: Nightmare Code
item.description: [#2485] Charsets even used to be known as 'alpha-bets' before that word's obvious negative associations caused it to die out.

item.title: Board Game Party Schedule
item.description: [#2486] Several of the guests are secretly playing Meta Board Game Party. Every minute of parallel debate in the breakaway faction earns double victory points!

item.title: Danger Mnemonic
item.description: [#2487] It's definitely not the time to try drinking beer before liquor.

item.title: Board Game Argument: Legacy
item.description: [#2488] Listen, you need to get over your reluctance to permanently alter a game. Now roll 2d6 to determine how many ounces of soda to spill into the box.

item.title: Bad Map Projection: The Greenland Special
item.description: [#2489] The projection for those who think the Mercator projection gives people a distorted idea of how big Greenland is, but a very accurate idea of how big it SHOULD be.

item.title: Pre-Pandemic Ketchup
item.description: [#2490] I wonder what year I'll discard the last weird food item that I bought online in early 2020.

item.title: Immune Factory
item.description: [#2491] In the final vote, the doubters were won over by the strength of the name IMMUNION.

item.title: Commonly Mispronounced Equations
item.description: [#2492] "Epsihootamoo doopsiquorps" --the Schrdinger equation for the hydrogen atom

item.title: Dual USB-C
item.description: [#2493] Small devices use two-prong USB-AC, but there's also a three-prong version with a USB-B plug as the ground.

item.title: Flawed Data
item.description: [#2494] We trained it to produce data that looked convincing, and we have to admit the results look convincing!

item.title: Universal Seat Belt
item.description: [#2495] The plug fits really snugly, so it should be safe in a crash.

item.title: Mine Captcha
item.description: [#2496] This data is actually going into improving our self-driving car project, so hurry up--it's almost at the minefield.

item.title: Logic Gates
item.description: [#2497] In C, the multiocular O represents the bitwise norxondor gorgonax.

item.title: Forest Walk
item.description: [#2498] The only other person to walk by was a linguist back in the 80s, but she just spent a while dissecting the phrase 'help me down' before getting distracted by a squirrel and wandering off.

item.title: Abandonment Function
item.description: [#2499] Remember to only adopt domesticated drones that specifically request it. It's illegal to collect wild ones under the Migratory Drone Treaty Act.

item.title: Global Temperature Over My Lifetime
item.description: [#2500] I was really impressed by the accuracy of some of the report's predictions about fossil fuel consumption. Then I realized, oh, right, of course.

item.title: Average Familiarity
item.description: [#2501] How could anyone consider themselves a well-rounded adult without a basic understanding of silicate geochemistry? Silicates are everywhere! It's hard to throw a rock without throwing one!

item.title: Every Data Table
item.description: [#2502] I'm hoping 2022 is relatively normal because I don't know what symbol comes after the asterisk and the dagger.

item.title: Memo Spike Connector
item.description: [#2503] Backward-compatible with many existing cables, and can connect directly to phones or tablets if you press them down hard enough.

item.title: Fissile Raspberry Isotopes
item.description: [#2504] Grandma's shelf-stable blackberry pie meson recipe was a huge seller until her farm was shut down by a joint FDA/NRC investigation.

item.title: News Story Reaction
item.description: [#2505] Unless the next line is, "After we broke up, she blamed the painting and spent years planning her revenge, so my sorrow is mixed with relief that the dogs at least denied her that triumph."

item.title: Projecting
item.description: [#2506] This is something we all need to work on, but especially you all.

item.title: USV-C
item.description: [#2507] Ultra-Serial Violet C light is unpolarized, so you don't have to flip the polarizing filter over when you get the orientation wrong the first time.

item.title: Circumappendiceal Somectomy
item.description: [#2508] Some personal news: After treating my first case a few years ago with antibiotics, I can report that I have now had appendicitis for the second and--unless something extremely unexpected happened with the surgery--final time.

item.title: Useful Geometry Formulas
item.description: [#2509] Geometry textbooks always try to trick you by adding decorative stripes and dotted lines.

item.title: Modern Tools
item.description: [#2510] I tried to train an AI to repair my Python environment but it kept giving up and deleting itself.

item.title: Recreate the Conditions
item.description: [#2511] We've almost finished constructing the pia collider.

item.title: Revelation
item.description: [#2512] And the heaven departed as a scroll when it is rolled together, but then more heaven kept appearing to replace it, as if the scroll was infinite.

item.title: Saturn Hexagon
item.description: [#2513] Sorry, in SI units that's "there's a big football in there."

item.title: Lab Equipment
item.description: [#2514] I've been working on chocolate bar annealing techniques to try to produce the perfect laser s'more. Maybe don't mention that on the grant application though.

item.title: Vaccine Research
item.description: [#2515] Honestly feel a little sheepish about the amount of time and effort I spent confirming "yes, the vaccine helps protect people from getting sick and dying" but I guess everyone needs a hobby.

item.title: Hubble Tension
item.description: [#2516] Oh, wait, I might've had it set to kph instead of mph. But that would make the discrepancy even wider!

item.title: Rover Replies
item.description: [#2517] I'm so glad NASA let you take your phone to Mars!

item.title: Lumpers and Splitters
item.description: [#2518] Anna Karenina is a happy family lumper and unhappy family splitter.

item.title: Sloped Border
item.description: [#2519] "The slope will be 74 at ground level." "Okay, I think we can hack together a ... wait, why did they specify ground level? It's 74 everywhere, right? ... Oh no, there's a whole section in the treaty labeled 'curvature.'"

item.title: Symbols
item.description: [#2520] "rntgen" and "rem" are 20th-century physics terms that mean "no trespassing."

item.title: Toothpaste
item.description: [#2521] "9 out of 10 dentists have banned me from their offices."

item.title: Two-Factor Security Key
item.description: [#2522] The bruises on my fingertips are my proof of work.

item.title: Endangered
item.description: [#2523] The list includes polio, Guinea worm, and this one particular enterovirus strain that they've been tracking out of spite after it went around the lab a few years ago.

item.title: Comet Visitor
item.description: [#2524] It's a myth that the Great Wall of China is the only human-made structure visible from space--there are LOTS of structures for us to feel self-conscious about!

item.title: Air Travel Packing List
item.description: [#2525] I know the etiquette is controversial, but I think it's rude when the person in front of me reclines their seat into the bell of my trumpet.

item.title: TSP vs TBSP
item.description: [#2526] It's like one teraspoon / when all you need is a kilonife

item.title: New Nobel Prizes
item.description: [#2527] They've endowed a separate prize in Physiology or Medicine or Stopping Dr. Adams.

item.title: Flag Map Sabotage
item.description: [#2528] Delaware hopes to explore the western edge of areas marked with the Belgian flag, once the tornadoes die down.

item.title: Unsolved Math Problems
item.description: [#2529] After decades of studying the curve and the procedure that generates it, the consensus explanation is "it's just like that."

item.title: Clinical Trials
item.description: [#2530] We don't need to do a clinical trial of this change because the standard of care is to adopt new ideas without doing clinical trials.

item.title: Dark Arts
item.description: [#2531] You think, 'okay, THIS is an ideal use case for hardlinks!' but then 6 months later you're doing some extremely cursed Google search like 'javascript ext4' and wondering where things went wrong.

item.title: Censored Vaccine Card
item.description: [#2532] CVS's pharmacies are fine, but I much prefer their [censored]s.

item.title: Slope Hypothesis Testing
item.description: [#2533] "What? I can't hear--" "What? I said, are you sure--" "CAN YOU PLEASE SPEAK--"

item.title: Retractable Rocket
item.description: [#2534] Hard to believe that for so many years once they were fully extended we just let them tip over.

item.title: Common Cold Viruses
item.description: [#2535] "It's not an influenza, but the onset has notes of the '09 H1N1 strain." "Ah yes, that was a good year for H1N1."

item.title: Wirecutter
item.description: [#2536] This was always going to be a controversial Wirecutter post, but what really got them in trouble were their 'budget' and 'upgrade' picks.

item.title: Painbow Award
item.description: [#2537] This year, our team took home the dark blue ribbon, better than the midnight blue we got last year but still short of the winning navy blue.

item.title: Snack
item.description: [#2538] Although grad students, suddenly reminded that food exists, tend to just grab and devour both without further discussion.

item.title: Flinch
item.description: [#2539] Premed: "Does this count for a physics credit? Can we shorten the string so I can get it done faster? And can we do one where it hits me in the face? I gotta do a thing for first aid training right after."

item.title: TTSLTSWBD
item.description: [#2540] Tomorrow's sessions will be entirely devoted to sewing machine rotary hooks.

item.title: Occam
item.description: [#2541] Oh no, Murphy just picked up the razor.

item.title: Daylight Calendar
item.description: [#2542] Could be worse. In some towns north of here, it's already December, and the 21st will last for nearly a week.

item.title: Never Told Anyone
item.description: [#2543] Even if you said you were an employee of the website, if you asked for my password, I'd tell you.

item.title: Heart-Stopping Texts
item.description: [#2544] Was this your car? [looping 'image loading' animation]

item.title: Bayes' Theorem
item.description: [#2545] P((B|A)|(A|B)) represents the probability that you'll mix up the order of the terms when using Bayesian notation.

item.title: Fiction vs Nonfiction
item.description: [#2546] The real challenge is how to file Boba Fett's biography of Doris Kearns Goodwin.

item.title: Siren
item.description: [#2547] Directions from CITY OF TROY to ITHACA / Total time: 10y 54d 14h 25m / Warning: Route crosses an international border / route includes capture by the goddess Calypso / route includes a ferry

item.title: Awful People
item.description: [#2548] Hm, this burger place has a couple of good reviews, but LakeSlayer7 says he got food poisoning there and everyone should try this other place down by the lake instead.

item.title: Edge Cake
item.description: [#2549] Every time IERS adds or removes a leap second, they send me a birthday cake out of superstition.

item.title: Webb
item.description: [#2550] Each one contains a chocolate shaped like a famous spacecraft and, for the later numbers, a pamphlet on managing anxiety.

item.title: Debunking
item.description: [#2551] Mark Zuckerberg has only neutral feelings toward Peppa Pig, who he understands is a fictional character, and he blames the coronavirus pandemic on other factors.

item.title: The Last Molecule
item.description: [#2552] Biology is really struggling; they're barely at 93% and they keep finding more ants.

item.title: Incident Report
item.description: [#2553] Increasing-precision timestamps are the Jaws theme of incident reports.

item.title: Gift Exchange
item.description: [#2554] In addition to having all their budgets in a spreadsheet with consistent formatting, they just love expressing preferences on a well-calibrated numerical scale.

item.title: Notifications
item.description: [#2555] It's 10:34 PM for this user. They really need to get going, they have a thing early tomorrow. Are you sure you want to notify?

item.title: Turing Complete
item.description: [#2556] Thanks to the ForcedEntry exploit, your company's entire tech stack can now be hosted out of a PDF you texted to someone.

item.title: Immunity
item.description: [#2557] This plan may sound appealing to people who know a little about the immune system, but the drawbacks are clear to people who know a lot about the immune system and also to people who don't know anything about it.

item.title: Rapid Test Results
item.description: [#2558] A solid red area with two white lines means that you have been infected with the anti-coronavirus, COVID+19, which will cure anyone you have close contact with.

item.title: December 25th Launch
item.description: [#2559] Update: Santa has been destroyed by the range safety officer.

item.title: Confounding Variables
item.description: [#2560] You can find a perfect correlation if you just control for the residual.

item.title: Moonfall
item.description: [#2561] Novel ideas and cool explosions are both good, but what I really want from a movie is novel ideas ABOUT cool explosions.

item.title: Formatting Meeting
item.description: [#2562] Neither group uses iso 8601 because the big-endian enthusiasts were all at the meeting 20 years ago.

item.title: Throat and Nasal Passages
item.description: [#2563] I always felt like what the 'you are now aware of your tongue' thing needed in order to be truly enjoyable was an element of mortal peril.

item.title: Sunshield
item.description: [#2564] RIP the surface of Mars

item.title: Latency
item.description: [#2565] Each SCAPDFATIAT point increases the chance that the process will involve the phrase 'by the next business day.'

item.title: Decorative Constants
item.description: [#2566] Arguably, the '1/2' in the drag equation is purely decorative, since drag coefficients are already unitless and could just as easily be half as big. Some derivations give more justification for the extra 1/2 than others, but one textbook just calls it 'a traditional tribute to Euler and Bernoulli.'

item.title: Language Development
item.description: [#2567] The worst is the Terrible Twos, when they're always throwing things and shrieking, "forsooth, to bed thou shalt not take me, cur!"

item.title: Spinthariscope
item.description: [#2568] Other high scorers are melt-in-your-hand aluminum-destroying gallium and tritium-powered glowsticks. Lawn darts are toward the other end.

item.title: Hypothesis Generation
item.description: [#2569] Frazzled scientists are requesting that everyone please stop generating hypotheses for a little bit while they work through the backlog.

item.title: Captain Picard Tea Order
item.description: [#2570] We can ask the Earl for his order once he's fully extruded from the dispenser.

item.title: Hydraulic Analogy
item.description: [#2571] Current (water) running through the water (wires) causes it to boil, increasing the pressure (voltage), but resisting (impeding) the flow of hydroelectricity (water currents). This is the basis for Ohm's law.

item.title: Alien Observers
item.description: [#2572] ALERT: Human 910-25J-1Q38 has created a Youtube channel. Increase erratic jerkiness of flying by 30% until safely out of range.

item.title: Alien Mission
item.description: [#2573] Fine, we can go search the Himalayas for the Yeti ONE more time, but keep a safe altitude over the Pacific and PLEASE watch where you're going. We can't afford another Amelia Earhart incident.

item.title: Autoresponder
item.description: [#2574] I ADMIRE HOW YOU SET BOUNDARIES AND I HOPE YOUR COLLEAGUES RESPECT THEM! PLEASE SPARE MY LIFE!

item.title: What If? 2
item.description: [#2575] CLARIFICATION: By 9/13, I mean September 13th, not the 9th day of Jancember, the cursed 13th month that exists between December and January in the transdimensional temporal plane.

item.title: Control Group
item.description: [#2576] Placeble 228 x/6nnnnnn

item.title: Sea Chase
item.description: [#2577] There are two rules on this ship: Never gaze back into the projection abyss, and never touch the red button labeled DYMAXION.

item.title: Sword Pull
item.description: [#2578] Merlin really shouldn't leave his dirt bike lying around.

item.title: Tractor Beam
item.description: [#2579] Did you base the saucer shape on pop culture depictions of aliens, or was that stuff based on your ships? Does the rotational symmetry help with ... hey, where are you going?

item.title: Rest and Fluids
item.description: [#2580] Remember not to take it easy. Put a hot washcloth on your forehead, remain standing, and breathe dry air while taking lots of histamines. You need to give your body a chance to get sick again.

item.title: Health Stats
item.description: [#2581] You will live on forever in our hearts, pushing a little extra blood toward our left hands now and then to give them a squeeze.

item.title: Data Trap
item.description: [#2582] It's important to make sure your analysis destroys as much information as it produces.

item.title: Chorded Keyboard
item.description: [#2583] And even though it all went wrong / I'll stand before the lord of song / with nothing on my tongue but 'I don't understand, I swear I backed up my keyboard config before messing with it'

item.title: Headline Words
item.description: [#2584] Roundly-condemned headlinese initiative shuttered indefinitely.

item.title: Rounding
item.description: [#2585] I've developed a novel propulsion system powered by loss of precision in unit conversion.

item.title: Greek Letters
item.description: [#2586] If you ever see someone using a capital xi in an equation, just observe them quietly to learn as much as you can before they return to their home planet.

item.title: For the Sake of Simplicity
item.description: [#2587] For the sake of simplicity, gardeners are assumed to move through Euclidean space--neglecting the distortion from general relativity--unless they are in the vicinity of a Schwarzschild Orchid.

item.title: Party Quadrants
item.description: [#2588] Single-elimination might provide more drama, but I think we can all agree that a comprehensive numerical scoring system will let us better judge the party's winner.

item.title: Outlet Denier
item.description: [#2589] There are regularly placed bumps on the underside just the right size to press the rocker switch on the power strip.

item.title: I Shouldn't Complain
item.description: [#2590] Bald-faced hornets are only a 2 on the Schmidt pain index, so I shouldn't complain. The tennis ball ejected from the dryer exhaust vent could have ricocheted off the nest of a much higher-scoring insect before knocking me off the ladder. Really, I'm lucky.

item.title: Qua
item.description: [#2591] Qua qua qua is the sine qua non of sine qua non qua sine qua non.

item.title: False Dichotomy
item.description: [#2592] There are two types of dichotomy: False dichotomies, true dichotomies, and surprise trichotomies.

item.title: Deviled Eggs
item.description: [#2593] The foil on the toothpick represents the blue flash.

item.title: Consensus Time
item.description: [#2594] Now, you may argue that the varying hour lengths and feedback effects would cause chaos. To which I say, yeah, and I'm also curious to see how the weekday cycle interacts with it! So, you in?

item.title: Advanced Techniques
item.description: [#2595] A blow from Emmy's Cutlass of Variations will transport the dragon to a corresponding symmetric position in the Noetherworld.

item.title: Galaxies
item.description: [#2596] I know it seems overwhelming, but don't worry; I'm sure most of them have only a few stars, and probably no planets.

item.title: Salary Negotiation
item.description: [#2597] "We can do 0.33 or 0.34, but our payroll software doesn't allow us to--" "NO DEAL."

item.title: Graphic Designers
item.description: [#2598] They might make it past that first line of defense. For the second, you'll need some picture frames, a level, and a protractor that can do increments of less than a degree.

item.title: Spacecraft Debris Odds Ratio
item.description: [#2599] You say this daily walk will reduce my risk of death from cardiovascular disease by 30%, but also increase my risk of death by bear attack by 300%? That's a 280% increased! I'm not a sucker; I'm staying inside.

item.title: Rejected Question Categories
item.description: [#2600] You can click to preorder to get a copy of What If? 2 when it comes out 9/13, assuming we all make it past the spider situation(?) on Tuesday(?).

item.title: Instructions
item.description: [#2601] Happy little turtles

item.title: Linguistics Degree
item.description: [#2602] You'd think 'linguistics' would go to someone important in the field, but it's actually assigned to a random student in Ohio who barely graduated and then went into automotive marketing.

item.title: Childhood Toys
item.description: [#2603] The rope keeps breaking, I'm covered in bruises and scrapes, and I've barely reached the end of my driveway, but I don't care--I'm determined to become the first person to commute to work by tetherball.

item.title: Frankenstein Captcha
item.description: [#2604] The distinction between a ship and a boat is a line drawn in water.

item.title: Taylor Series
item.description: [#2605] The Taylor series should have been canceled after the first term.

item.title: Weird Unicode Math Symbols
item.description: [#2606] U+2A0B Mathematicians need to calm down

item.title: Geiger Counter
item.description: [#2607] At first I didn't get why they were warning me about all those birds sitting on the wire, but then I understood.

item.title: Family Reunion
item.description: [#2608] Grandma says that because of differences in primate and feline lifespans, the cat is actually my 17,000,000th cousin 14,000,000 times removed.

item.title: Entwives
item.description: [#2609] No, we actually do have a woman who's basically part of our fellowship. She lives in Rivendell, you wouldn't know her.

item.title: Assigning Numbers
item.description: [#2610] Gdel should do an article on which branches of math have the lowest average theorem number.

item.title: Cutest-Sounding Scientific Effects
item.description: [#2611] The Stroop-YORP number of a scientific paper is how many of the 16 finalist names (sans 'effect') it manages to casually sneak into the text.

item.title: Lightsabers
item.description: [#2612] A lot of Jedi romances start with this turning into a Lady and the Tramp spaghetti situation.

item.title: Bad Map Projection: Madagascator
item.description: [#2613] The projection's north pole is in a small lake on the island of Mah in the Seychelles, which is off the top of the map and larger than the rest of the Earth's land area combined.
[#2614] It's like sigma summation notation, except instead of summing the argument over all values of i, you 2 the argument over all values of 2.

item.title: Welcome Back
item.description: [#2615] 'We're shocked by the Notre Dame fire. Click for our tribute to--' [okay] 'Now that we're all staying at home these past few weeks thanks to this new coronavirus, we--' [okay]

item.title: Deep End
item.description: [#2616] Hey! No running in the back-arc basin!

item.title: Maps
item.description: [#2617] OpenStreetMap was always pretty good but is also now *really* good? And Apple Maps's new zoomed-in design in certain cities like NYC and London is just gorgeous. It's cool how there are all these good maps now!

item.title: Selection Bias
item.description: [#2618] We carefully sampled the general population and found that most people are familiar with acquiescence bias.

item.title: Crpe
item.description: [#2619] A medicine that makes you put two dots over your letters more often is a diretic.

item.title: Health Data
item.description: [#2620] Donate now to help us find a cure for causality. No one should have to suffer through events because of other events.

item.title: Mainly Known For
item.description: [#2621] Oh sure, I know Keira Knightly, from the first movie in that series by The Land Before Time producer. You know, the franchise with the guy from Jurassic Park and Ghostwriter, and script work by Billie Lourd's mom?

item.title: Angular Diameter Turnaround
item.description: [#2622] Thank you to Katie Mack for teaching me about this effect, and to Janelle Shane for describing redshifts as 'like galaxies sinking into a pool of dilute blood,' which is how I'll see them from now on.

item.title: Goofs
item.description: [#2623] The film is set in 2018, but when Commander Bremberly chases the hologram through Times Square, there's a billboard for Avengers: Age of Ultron. Depending on the date, that billboard would have been advertising either Infinity War or this movie.

item.title: Voyager Wires
item.description: [#2624] Also, they're getting increasingly worried that someone will accidentally hit the 'retract' button, and that the end of the cable thrashing around as it winds up could devastate the Earth's surface.

item.title: Field Topology
item.description: [#2625] The combination croquet set/10-lane pool can also be used for some varieties of foosball and Skee-Ball.

item.title: d65536
item.description: [#2626] They're robust against quantum attacks because it's hard to make a quantum system that large.

item.title: Types of Scopes
item.description: [#2627] An x-ray gyroscope is used to determine exactly which toppings they included in the pita.

item.title: Motion Blur
item.description: [#2628] I can't speak for your other subjects, but MY motion was as smooth and natural as the framerate allowed.

item.title: Or Whatever
item.description: [#2629] Oh yeah, I didn't even know they renamed it the Willis Tower in 2009, because I know a normal amount about skyscrapers.

item.title: Shuttle Skeleton
item.description: [#2630] It's believed to be related to the Stellar Sea Cow.

item.title: Exercise Progression
item.description: [#2631] They said after I got into a routine, I'd enjoy getting progressively stronger and stop whining so much about how hard exercise was. Well, they were half right!

item.title: Greatest Scientist
item.description: [#2632] "Ow! One of the petri dishes I left on the tower railing fell and hit me on the head! Hey, that gives me an idea..."

item.title: Astronomer Hotline
item.description: [#2633] Employment statistics have to correct for the fact that the Weird Bug Hotline hires on a bunch of extra temporary staff every 17 years.

item.title: Red Line Through HTTPS
item.description: [#2634] Some organization has been paying to keep this up and it hasn't been removed from search results. Seems like two votes of confidence to me.

item.title: Superintelligent AIs
item.description: [#2635] Your scientists were so preoccupied with whether or not they should, they didn't stop to think if they could.

item.title: What If? 2 Countdown
item.description: [#2636] If you don't end the 99 Bottles of Beer recursion at N=0 it just becomes The Other Song That Never Ends.

item.title: Roman Numerals
item.description: [#2637] 100he100k out th1s 1nno5at4e str1ng en100o501ng 15e been 500e5e50op1ng! 1t's 6rtua100y perfe100t! ...hang on, what's a "virtuacy"?

item.title: Extended NFPA Hazard Diamond
item.description: [#2638] With most labs, the hushed horror stories are about something like dimethylmercury or prions, but occasionally you'll get a weird lab where it's about the soda machine or the drop ceiling.

item.title: Periodic Table Changes
item.description: [#2639] It's nice how the end of the periodic table is flush with the edge these days, so I think we should agree no one should find any new elements after #118 unless they discover a whole row at once.

item.title: The Universe by Scientific Field
item.description: [#2640] The math and philosophy people also claim everything, but the astronomers argue that the stuff they study really only comprises a small number of paper surfaces.

item.title: Mouse Turbines
item.description: [#2641] It's sad seeing those videos of turbine blade being torn apart in high winds, but it's the only way they can disperse their seeds.

item.title: Meta-Alternating Current
item.description: [#2642] It's always bothered me that you can't cancel out an inverter by putting a second inverter after it.

item.title: Cosmologist Gift
item.description: [#2643] These neutrinos were freshly produced by a local source just 8 minutes ago

item.title: fMRI Billboard
item.description: [#2644] [other side] If the first word of an instruction you're given starts with the same letter as your crush's name, for that step imagine the experimenter is your crush.

item.title: The Best Camera
item.description: [#2645] The best camera is the one at L2.

item.title: Minkowski Space
item.description: [#2646] My liege, we were able to follow the ship into Minkowski space, but now they've jumped to Hilbert space and they could honestly be anywhere.

item.title: Capri Suns
item.description: [#2647] [As security is dragging me away] "Come on, at least I didn't make the mistake in the other direction!"

item.title: Chemicals
item.description: [#2648] It's hard to believe, but lots of kids these days ONLY know how to buy prepackaged molecules.

item.title: Physics Cost-Saving Tips
item.description: [#2649] I got banned from the county fair for handing out Helium-2 balloons. Apparently the instant massive plasma explosions violated some local ordinance or something.

item.title: Deepfakes
item.description: [#2650] If so great a deductive mind as Arthur Conan Doyle can be fooled by the Cottingley Deepfakes, what chance do we mortals have? Soon our very reality will be dictated by the whims of Frances (9) and Elsie (16).

item.title: Air Gap
item.description: [#2651] You can still do powerline networking, but the bitrate does drop a little depending on the lightbulb warmup and cooldown delay.

item.title: Proxy Variable
item.description: [#2652] Our work has produced great answers. Now someone just needs to figure out which questions they go with.

item.title: Omnitaur
item.description: [#2653] "My parents were both omnitaurs, which is how I got interested in recombination," said the normal human.

item.title: Chemtrails
item.description: [#2654] Ants have reverse chemtrails--regular citizens spraying chemicals everywhere they go to control the government.

item.title: Asking Scientists Questions
item.description: [#2655] 'Does the substance feel weird to the touch?' is equally likely to get the answers 'Don't be ridiculous, you would never put your hand near a sample. We have safety protocols.' and 'Yeah, and it tastes AWFUL.'

item.title: Scientific Field Prefixes
item.description: [#2656] Massage: Theoretical (10), Quantum (6), High-energy (2), Computational (1), Marine (1), Astro- (None)

item.title: Complex Vowels
item.description: [#2657] Pronouncing [sscchhwwaa] is easy; you just say it like the 'x' in 'fire'.

item.title: Coffee Cup Holes
item.description: [#2658] Theoretical physicist: At the Planck length, uncountably many.

item.title: Unreliable Connection
item.description: [#2659] NEGATIVE REVIEWS MENTION: Unreliable internet. POSITIVE REVIEWS MENTION: Unreliable internet.

item.title: Gen Z
item.description: [#2660] Curdled milk, of a peculiar kind, made after a Bulgarian recipe and called "yaghurt," is now a Parisian fad and is believed to be a remedy against growing old. A correspondent who has tried it, says he would prefer to die young. (1905, The Elk Falls Journal)

item.title: Age Milestone Privileges
item.description: [#2661] If you reach 122, you get complete unrevertible editorial control over Jeanne Calment's Wikipedia article.

item.title: Physics Safety Tip
item.description: [#2662] In general, avoid exposure to any temperatures, pressures, particle energies, or states of matter that physicists think are neat.

item.title: Tetherball Configurations
item.description: [#2663] Ground-pole-ball-pole can be fun if you shake the first pole to get the second one whipping around dangerously, but the ball at the joint gets torn apart pretty fast.

item.title: Cloud Swirls
item.description: [#2664] 'Why did you get into fluid dynamics?' 'Well, SOME planet has to have the coolest clouds, odds are it's not ours, and rockets are slow.'

item.title: America Songs
item.description: [#2665] Juraaaassic Park, Juraaaassic Park, God shed his grace on theeeee

item.title: Universe Price Tiers
item.description: [#2666] In Universe Pro the laws of physics remain unchanged under time reversal, to maintain backward compatibility.

item.title: First Internet Interaction
item.description: [#2667] To that stranger on the KOOL Tree House chat room, I gotta hand it to you: You were, ultimately, not wrong.

item.title: Artemis Quote
item.description: [#2668] Another option: "It is an honor to be the first human to set foot on the moon."

item.title: Things You Should Not Do
item.description: [#2669] Now I'm tempted to start telling people that I secretly don't actually know how to do any physics calculations, and so all the answers in What If are based on me actually trying to do the thing and then reporting what happened, but phrased as if it's hypothetical.

item.title: Interruption
item.description: [#2670] It's been extra bad ever since my GPS got stuck on Phoebe Judge mode.

item.title: Rotation
item.description: [#2671] It's okay, we can just feed the one-pixel image into an AI upscaler and recover the original image, or at least one that's just as cool.

item.title: What If? 2 Flowchart
item.description: [#2672] Don't worry, the dogs are all fine. That's actually kind of the problem.

item.title: Cursed mRNA Cocktail
item.description: [#2673] Serve one each to guests whose last cursed cocktail was more than 2 months ago.

item.title: Everyday Carry
item.description: [#2674] Someday I just know I'm going to encounter a problem that requires 500 flashlights and 700 knives with weird holes in them, and on that day I won't be caught unprepared.

item.title: Pilot Priority List
item.description: [#2675] CELEBRATE: Serve passengers tiered cakes shaped like the airspace class diagram

item.title: Historical Dates
item.description: [#2676] Evidence suggests the 1899 transactions occurred as part of a global event centered around a deity associated with the lotus flower.

item.title: Two Key System
item.description: [#2677] Our company can be your one-stop shop for decentralization.

item.title: Wing Lift
item.description: [#2678] Once the air from the top passes below the plane of the wing and catches sight of the spooky skulls, it panics, which is the cause of turbulent vortices.

item.title: Quantified Self
item.description: [#2679] It's made me way more excited about ferris wheels, subways, car washes, waterslides, and store entrances that have double doors with a divider in the middle.

item.title: Battery Life
item.description: [#2680] It's okay, I'm at 10%, so I'm good for another month or two.

item.title: Archimedes Principle
item.description: [#2681] "I've always wanted to run naked through town, but I don't want to get in trouble with the king or be remembered by history as a weirdo. I wonder how I could ... EUREKA!"

item.title: Easy or Hard
item.description: [#2682] "Friction-driven static electrification is familiar and fundamental in daily life, industry, and technology, but its basics have long been unknown and have continually perplexed scientists from ancient Greece to the high-tech era. [...] To date, no single theory can satisfactorily explain this mysterious but fundamental phenomenon." --Eui-Cheol Shin et. al. (2022)

item.title: Fan Theories
item.description: [#2683] The universe fandom is great. Such sweet and enthusiastic people.

item.title: Road Space Comparison
item.description: [#2684] I wonder how hard it would be to ride an electric scooter in a hamster ball.
[#2685] "Sorry, doctor, I'm going to have to come in on a different day--I have another appointment that would be really hard to move, in terms of the kinetic energy requirements."

item.title: Space Adventure
item.description: [#2686] "Sir, it looked really cool." "Oh no--prestige TV. Okay, which of you has a terrible secret that's being slowly revealed to the audience through flashbacks? Just spit it out so we can escape this arc!"

item.title: Division Notation
item.description: [#2687] Science tip: Scientists hardly ever use the two-dot division sign, and when they do it often doesn't even mean division, but they still get REALLY mad when you repurpose it to write stuff like SALE! ALL SHOES 30 OFF!

item.title: Bubble Universes
item.description: [#2688] The theory finally unifies cosmic inflation and regular inflation.

item.title: Fermat's First Theorem
item.description: [#2689] Mathematicians quickly determined that it spells ANT BNECN, an unusual theoretical dish which was not successfully cooked until Andrew Wiles made it for breakfast in the 1990s.

item.title: Cool S
item.description: [#2690] Although I hear they were caught cheating off of Rosalind, who sat at a desk in front of them.

item.title: Encryption
item.description: [#2691] WARNING: PEOPLE NAMED EVE ARE PROHIBITED FROM INSTALLING THIS APP!

item.title: Interior Decorating
item.description: [#2692] It all came flat-packed in Pandora's Box.

item.title: Wirecutter Recommendation
item.description: [#2693] Their 'best philosophy of epistemology' picks are great, but you can tell they're struggling a little in the 'why you should trust us' section.

item.title: Knigsberg
item.description: [#2694] At first I thought I would need some gold or something to pay him, but then I realized that it was the 18th century and I could just bring a roll of aluminum foil.

item.title: Soil
item.description: [#2695] You might want to bring your frost-sensitive plants in from the patio. The high-level aerosols may result in short-term cooling across the entire backyard.

item.title: Precision vs Accuracy
item.description: [#2696] 'Barack Obama is much less likely than the average cat to jump in and out of cardboard boxes for fun' is low precision, but I'm not sure about the accuracy.

item.title: Y2K and 2038
item.description: [#2697] It's taken me 20 years, but I've finally finished rebuilding all my software to use 33-bit signed ints.

item.title: Bad Date
item.description: [#2698] "Even split between us, this will pay way better than the Jumanji sponsorship I came into the date with."

item.title: Feature Comparison
item.description: [#2699] Below the Web, and the Dark Web, a shadowy parallel world of Cybiko users trade messages on the Translucent Neon Plastic Web.

item.title: Account Problems
item.description: [#2700] My password is just every Unicode codepoint concatenated into a single UTF-8 string.

item.title: Change in Slope
item.description: [#2701] Squinting at a graph is fine for getting a rough idea of the answer, but if you want to pretend to know it exactly, you need statistics.

item.title: What If 2 Gift Guide
item.description: [#2702] BABIES OR LITERATURE BUT NOT BOTH: Baby shoes

item.title: Paper Title
item.description: [#2703] CONFLICT OF INTEREST STATEMENT: The authors hope these results are correct because we all want to be cool people who are good at science.

item.title: Faucet
item.description: [#2704] It's okay, they can figure out which control positions produce scalding water via a trial-and-error feedback loop with a barely-perceptible 10-second lag.

item.title: Spacetime Soccer
item.description: [#2705] Spacetime Soccer, known outside the United States as '4D Football' is a now-defunct sport. Infamous for referee decisions hinging on inconsistent definitions of simultaneity, it is also known for the disappearance of many top players during... [more]

item.title: Bendy
item.description: [#2706] Squaring the circle is really easy with some good clamps.

item.title: Astronomy Numbers
item.description: [#2707] I adopted a cat that weighs 12 solar masses. Laser pointers love chasing it.

item.title: Mystery Asterisk Destination
item.description: [#2708] If you ever see the dagger symbol with no unmatched footnote, it means the writer is saying the phrase while threatening you with a dagger.

item.title: Solar System Model
item.description: [#2709] The Earth is, on average, located in the habitable zone, but at any given time it has a certain probability of being outside it, which is why life exists on Earth but is mortal.

item.title: Hydropower Breakthrough
item.description: [#2710] A hydroelectric dam is also known as a heavy water reactor.

item.title: Optimal Bowling
item.description: [#2711] If you want to bowl a strike, the optimal place is almost certainly inside a bowling alley, although with a little luck any establishment uphill from one could also work.

item.title: Gravity
item.description: [#2712] It's a long way down.

item.title: Data Point
item.description: [#2713] In general you should only include your single best data point in the paper. The rest of the data can go in the supplementary materials.

item.title: Cold Complaints
item.description: [#2714] Our investigation into whining-based remedies became the first study to be halted by the IRB on the grounds that the treatment group was 'too annoying.'

item.title: Pando
item.description: [#2715] The presents under the tree are actually a single gift connected by an underground ribbon system.

item.title: Game Night Ordering
item.description: [#2716] One good trick, if you get called on a fake service, is to build a working version of it and mention it again the next week.

item.title: L6 Lagrange Point
item.description: [#2717] It's difficult to orbit L6 stably due to gravitational perturbation from Akron and Toledo.

item.title: New Year's Eve Party
item.description: [#2718] [Earlier, at the eye doctor] 'No, for the last time, the numerals on the paper aren't my prescription, it's the shape I want you to make with the laser.'

item.title: Hydrogen Isotopes
item.description: [#2719] Oops, All Neutrons is also known as Neutral Quadrium, Nydnonen, and Goth Tritium.

item.title: Biology vs Robotics
item.description: [#2720] Sorry, I've just always had these random things I don't like--like olives, or robots drilling holes in me without warning.

item.title: Euler Diagrams
item.description: [#2721] Things Leonhard Euler created ( most of math ( overlapping circle diagrams ) a cricket bowling machine ) Things John Venn created

item.title: Etymonline
item.description: [#2722] NOTE TO FUTURE ETYMONLINGUISTS: Our best guess is that 'blimp' is onomatopoeia. The 'B-Limp' thing is a folk etymology.

item.title: Outdated Periodic Table
item.description: [#2723] Researchers claim to have synthesized six additional elements in the second row, temporarily named 'pentium' through 'unnilium'.

item.title: Washing Machine Settings
item.description: [#2724] I guess the engineers who built my dishwasher MIGHT have some insight into how to load it, but instead of reading the booklet they gave me, it seems easier to experiment for years and then get in arguments so heated that I get banned from Quora.

item.title: Sunspot Cycle
item.description: [#2725] Who can forget the early 2010s memes? 'You know you're a 90s kid if you remember the feeling of warm sunlight on your face.' 'Only 90s kids remember the dawn.'

item.title: Methodology Trial
item.description: [#2726] If you think THAT'S unethical, you should see the stuff we approved via our Placebo IRB.

item.title: Runtime
item.description: [#2727] At least there's a general understanding all around that Doctor Who is its own thing.

item.title: Lane Change Highway
item.description: [#2728] I just think lane markers should follow the local magnetic declination.

item.title: Planet Killer Comet Margarita
item.description: [#2729] I'll take mine on the rocks, no ice.

item.title: Code Lifespan
item.description: [#2730] Surely (no one/everyone) will (recognize how flexible and useful this architecture is/spend a huge amount of effort painstakingly preserving and updating this garbage I wrote in 20 minutes)

item.title: K-Means Clustering
item.description: [#2731] According to my especially unsupervised K-means clustering algorithm, there are currently about 8 billion types of people in the world.

item.title: Bursa of Fabricius
item.description: [#2732] If an anatomical structure is named for a person, it means they were the only person to have it. Pierre Paul Broca had a special area of his brain that created powerful magnetic fields, enabling him to do 19th century fMRI research.

item.title: Size Comparisons
item.description: [#2733] If you shrank the Solar System to the size of Texas, the Houston metro area would be smaller than a grasshopper in Dallas.

item.title: Electron Color
item.description: [#2734] There's quark color, but that's not really color--it's just an admission by 20th century physicists that numbers are boring.

item.title: Coordinate Plane Closure
item.description: [#2735] 3D graphs that don't contact the plane in the closure area may proceed as scheduled, but be alert for possible collisions with 2D graph lines that reach the hole and unexpectedly enter 3D space.

item.title: Only Serifs
item.description: [#2736] If you ever want to get beaten up by a bunch of graphic designers, try removing the serifs from Times New Roman and adding them to Comic Sans.

item.title: Weather Station
item.description: [#2737] 'Pour one out for precipitation data integrity,' I say, solemnly upending the glass into the rain gauge.

item.title: Omniknot
item.description: [#2738] The Gordian knot is an omniknot tied using every bend in the Ashley Book of Knots, and then for extra security the upper rope at every crossing is connected to the lower with a randomly-chosen hitch.

item.title: Data Quality
item.description: [#2739] [exclamation about how cute your cat is] -> [last 4 digits of your cat's chip ID] -> [your cat's full chip ID] -> [a drawing of your cat] -> [photo of your cat] -> [clone of your cat] -> [your actual cat] -> [my better cat]

item.title: Square Packing
item.description: [#2740] I also managed to improve the solution for n=1 to s<0.97, and with some upgrades I think I can hit 0.96.

item.title: Wish Interpretation
item.description: [#2741] "I wish for everything in the world. All the people, money, trees, etc." "Are you SURE you--" "And I want you to put it in my house."

item.title: Island Storage
item.description: [#2742] I always hate dragging around the larger archipelagos, but I appreciate how the Scandinavian peninsula flexes outward to create a snug pocket for Britain and Ireland.

item.title: Hand Dryers
item.description: [#2743] I know hand dryers have their problems, but I think for fun we should keep egging Dyson on and see if we can get them to make one where the airflow breaks the speed of sound.

item.title: Fanservice
item.description: [#2744] I was eventually kicked out of my architectural engineering program because I wouldn't stop referring to HVAC as "the fandom."

item.title: Obituary Editor
item.description: [#2745] As the editor has reportedly defeated Death in a series of games of skill, no further obituaries are expected.

item.title: Launch Window
item.description: [#2746] "Confirmed, we have to scrub." "Ugh, okay. I'll get the bucket and sponge."

item.title: Presents for Biologists
item.description: [#2747] A lot of these are actually non-venomous, but I can see which species you mistook them for. If you pause the crane for a sec I can give you some ID pointers for next time!

item.title: Radians are Cursed
item.description: [#2748] Phil Plait once pointed out that you can calculate the total angular area of the sky this way. If the sky is a sphere with radius 57.3 degrees, then its area is 4*pi*r^2=41,253 square degrees. This makes dimensional analysts SO mad, but you can't argue with results.

item.title: Lymphocytes
item.description: [#2749] It's very hard to detect, but recent studies have determined that when plasma B cells are producing antibodies, they go 'pew pew pew'

item.title: Flatten the Planets
item.description: [#2750] We'll turn the asteroid belt into ball bearings to go between different rings orbiting at different speeds.

item.title: March Madness
item.description: [#2751] My bracket has 76 trombones led by John Philip Sousa facing off against thousands of emperor penguins led by Morgan Freeman.

item.title: Salt Dome
item.description: [#2752] The US uses hollowed-out salt domes to store the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, and non-hollowed-out ones to store the Strategic Salt Reserve.

item.title: Air Handler
item.description: [#2753] It maintains odor levels in a normal familiar range, so if you open the windows and the air gets too fresh, it filters it through some dirty laundry samples to compensate.

item.title: Relative Terms
item.description: [#2754] Small sewing machines are sewing machines that are smaller than a sewing machine. A sewing machine is larger than a small sewing machine, but quieter than a loud sewing machine.

item.title: Effect Size
item.description: [#2755] Subgroup analysis is ongoing.

item.title: Qualifications
item.description: [#2756] 'So how DID you go from working at the employment records office to becoming president of MIT and CEO of IBM?' 'I guess I just have an eye for opportunities.'

item.title: Towed Message
item.description: [#2757] "Hi, what you do is fly over a designated zone and detach the--" "WE'RE SORRY, THE MOBILE CUSTOMER YOU ARE TRYING TO REACH IS OUT OF SERVICE"

item.title: My Favorite Things
item.description: [#2758] When an Ur guy / sells Nanni things / but the copper's bad, / He simply records his complaint for all time / "I got a bad deal / I'm maaaaad"

item.title: Easily Confused Acronyms
item.description: [#2759] 'Lever' was originally an acronym for Load Emplification by the Vimulated Emission of Radiation.

item.title: Paleontology Museum
item.description: [#2760] Nowadays the only ones left that do anything are turtles.

item.title: 1-to-1 Scale
item.description: [#2761] There's a version that shows the planets with no cropping, but it's hard to find a display that supports it.

item.title: Diffraction Spikes
item.description: [#2762] Even if a planet is lucky enough to have a stable orbit that weaves between the spikes, the seasons get weird whenever it passes close to them.

item.title: Linguistics Gossip
item.description: [#2763] The E's wedding invitation definitely used the word LOVE more times than was strictly necessary.

item.title: Cosmological Nostalgia Content
item.description: [#2764] Later renouncing clickbait, Einstein called his inclusion of cosmological content in general relativity the biggest blunder of his career.

item.title: Escape Speed
item.description: [#2765] Gotta go fast

item.title: Helium Reserve
item.description: [#2766] The government has been trying to sell off the Federal Helium Reserve for a few years now, but the sale has been on hold while they try to figure out how to explain this situation to buyers.

item.title: Recipe Relativity
item.description: [#2767] It says to cut the onions into 1/4" slices, but I'd better correct for length contraction.

item.title: Definition of e
item.description: [#2768] Yeah, my math teacher back in high school set up the system to try to teach us something or other, but the 100% rate was unbelievably good, so I engineered a hostile takeover of his bank and now use it to make extra cash on the side.

item.title: Overlapping Circles
item.description: [#2769] "The Venn diagram of the sun and the moon is a circle." --someone being snarky at totality

item.title: Tapetum Lucidum
item.description: [#2770] Using a reflective wall in a game to give one shot two chances to hit is called a double-tapetum lucidum.

item.title: College Knowledge
item.description: [#2771] 'Your chitin armor is no match for our iron-tipped stingers! Better go hide in your jars!' --common playground taunt

item.title: Commemorative Plaque
item.description: [#2772] [Below] On this site on May 12th, 2023, I finally learned how to use the masonry bit for my drill.

item.title: Planetary Scientist
item.description: [#2773] This rumpled fabric at the corner looks like evidence of ongoing tectonic activity.

item.title: Taxiing
item.description: [#2774] I don't understand why anyone would pay full price for a flatbed truck rental when you can buy 'DETOUR' signs online for like $10.

item.title: Siphon
