item.description: [#2775] ADDITIONAL NOTES: Fixed a bug that caused some rocks to generate virtually infinite heat while just sitting there.

item.title: Crystal Ball
item.description: [#2776] They often use ball lenses to collect light at the ends of optical fibers, so when you look stuff up on the internet you're actually scrying through a crystal ball.

item.title: Noise Filter
item.description: [#2777] Party Mode also enables the feature, but reverses the slider.

item.title: Cuisine
item.description: [#2778] My connection to it goes way back, to my early days, when I was just a cloud of primordial hydrogen collapsing in the darkness of space.

item.title: Exoplanet High-5
item.description: [#2779] Tau Ceti is farther away, so it took me 36 years to start the war over updog.

item.title: Physical Quantities
item.description: [#2780] The Hubble length is about 1.9 meters lying down; Edwin Hubble was a tall guy.

item.title: The Six Platonic Solids
item.description: [#2781] Plato made the solids, and five were gifted to the mathematicians. But in secret Plato forged a sixth solid to rule over all the others.

item.title: Wikipedia Article Titles
item.description: [#2782] I would never stoop to vandalism, but I'm not above discreetly deleting the occasional 'this article contains excessive amounts of detail' tag.

item.title: Ruling Out
item.description: [#2783] We were able to replicate and confirm prior authors' detection of a moon orbiting the Earth with high confidence.

item.title: Drainage Basins
item.description: [#2784] After a pail of water was thrown on the Wicked Witch of the West outside Salt Lake City, Utah's Great Salt Lake was measured to be 7 parts per trillion witch by volume.

item.title: Marble Run
item.description: [#2785] I have so many plans. It would incorporate a Galton board, a Ranque-Hilsch marble vortex tube, and a compartment lined with pinball bouncers with a camera-and-servo Maxwell's Demon that separated the balls into fast and slow sides.

item.title: UFO Evidence
item.description: [#2786] [Decades in the future] "Well, the good news is that we've received definitive communication from aliens. The bad news is that they're asking about Cats (2019)."

item.title: Iceberg
item.description: [#2787] 90% of the iceberg is hidden beneath the water, but that 90% only uses 10% of its brain, so it's really only 9%.

item.title: Musical Scales
item.description: [#2788] In the Hall of the Mountain King was accidentally composed on log/log paper.

item.title: Making Plans
item.description: [#2789] Oh no, I haven't checked in with Yvonne in YEARS.

item.title: Heat Pump
item.description: [#2790] If I'm not going to upgrade to a powered one, I should at LEAST stop leaving the door open so often.

item.title: Bookshelf Sorting
item.description: [#2791] Of course, I sort all my bookshelves the normal way, alphabetically (by first sentence).

item.title: Summer Solstice
item.description: [#2792] Then I'll start work on my lunar engines to line the Moon up with the ecliptic so we can have a solar eclipse every month (with a little wobble so they're not always on the equator.)

item.title: Garden Path Sentence
item.description: [#2793] Arboretum Owner Denied Standing in Garden Path Suit on Grounds Grounds Appealing Appealing

item.title: Alphabet Notes
item.description: [#2794] Listen, you're very cute, but if you rearrange the alphabet to put U and I together it will RUIN the spacing!

item.title: Glass-Topped Table
item.description: [#2795] You can pour a drink into it while hosting a party, although it's a real pain to fit in the dishwasher afterward.

item.title: Real Estate Analysis
item.description: [#2796] Mars does get a good score on 'noise levels' and 'scenic views,' but the school district ranking isn't great; the only teacher--the Perseverance rover--is too busy with rock samples to teach more than the occasional weekend class.

item.title: Actual Progress
item.description: [#2797] Slowly progressing from 'how do protons behave in relativistic collisions?' to 'what the heck are protons even doing when they're just sitting there?'

item.title: Room Temperature
item.description: [#2798] They're also refusing to fund my device that demonstrates uncontrolled hot fusion.

item.title: Frankenstein Claim Permutations
item.description: [#2799] When I began trying to form a new claim by stitching together these parts in such an unnatural way, some called me mad.

item.title: Down
item.description: [#2800] It's just that I get nervous about heights.

item.title: Contact Merge
item.description: [#2801] I actually kind of feel like John and Surf King wouldn't like each other, which is a lot to unpack.

item.title: Fireflies
item.description: [#2802] I feel bad for Earth 2 and their shadowflies.

item.title: Geohydrotypography
item.description: [#2803] The Atlantic is expanding at about 10 ppm (points per month).

item.title: Marshmallow
item.description: [#2804] The increasing number of graham crackers and chocolate bars in orbit has created a growing risk of Kessler s'mores.

item.title: Global Atmospheric Circulation
item.description: [#2805] Refs generally say that you can exercise enough altitude control to avoid the ground, but if you start strategically choosing air layers to steer yourself, that's traveling.

item.title: Anti-Vaxxers
item.description: [#2806] The vaccine stuff seems pretty simple. But if you take a closer look at the data, it's still simple, but bigger. And slightly blurry. Might need reading glasses.

item.title: Bad Map Projection: ABS(Longitude)
item.description: [#2807] Positive vibes/longitudes only

item.title: Daytime Firefly
item.description: [#2808] Mr. Jones, watch out for Ms. Lenhart! She's from genus Photuris!

item.title: Moon
item.description: [#2809] I mean, it's pretty, but it doesn't really affect us beyond that. Except that half the nights aren't really dark, and once or twice a day it makes the oceans flood the coasts.

item.title: How to Coil a Cable
item.description: [#2810] The ideal mix for maximum competitive cable-coiling energy is one A/V tech, one rock climber, one sailor, and one topologist.

item.title: Free Fallin'
item.description: [#2811] Their crash investigation team had some particularly harsh words for Dave Matthews.

item.title: Solar Panel Placement
item.description: [#2812] Getting the utility people to run transmission lines to Earth is expensive, but it will pay for itself in no time.

item.title: What to Do
item.description: [#2813] FYI: The 'drop, cover, and hold on' advice only applies to earthquakes. If you encounter a mountain lion, you should absolutely not drop to the ground, crawl under it, and hold on to one of its legs.

item.title: Perseids Pronunciation
item.description: [#2814] When speaking out loud, you can can call it the 'Perseids meatier shower' and no one will ever know. (If you do get caught somehow, just tell them to Google the 'Kentucky meat shower' and that will distract them while you escape.)

item.title: Car Wash
item.description: [#2815] I'm glad modern car washes use synthetic baleen, instead of harvesting it from whales like 1800s car washes did.

item.title: Types of Solar Eclipse
item.description: [#2816] The best place to be for a hug eclipse is a scenic natural area with good views and few clouds. The worst place to be is the lunar surface.

item.title: Electron Holes
item.description: [#2817] They tried to report me to the authorities, but because I had the device they couldn't charge me.

item.title: Circuit Symbols
item.description: [#2818] A circle with an A in it means that the circuit has committed a sin and has been marked as punishment.

item.title: Pronunciation
item.description: [#2819] I pronounce the 'u' in 'pronunciation' like in 'putting' but the 'ou' in 'pronounce' like in 'wound'.

item.title: Inspiration
item.description: [#2820] An apple fell on Isaac Newton's head and gave him the idea that the moon might be a tasty apple, though this turned out not to be true--the Apollo program eventually determined that it was just a desolate and bland Red Delicious.

item.title: Path Minimization
item.description: [#2821] Of course you get an ice cream cone for the swimmer too! You're not a monster.

item.title: *@gmail.com
item.description: [#2822] Hi all, just replying to loop in *@outlook.com and *@yahoo.com.

item.title: Fossil
item.description: [#2823] The two best reasons to get into fossils are booping trilobites and getting to say the word "fossiliferous" a lot.

item.title: Abstract Pickup
item.description: [#2824] Escape Artist Frees Self From Conversation With Pickup Artist

item.title: Autumn and Fall
item.description: [#2825] Of course in reality this is just a US/UK thing; in British English, 'fall' is the brief period in between and 'autumn' is the main season.

item.title: Gold
item.description: [#2826] It can be expensive to hire a professional spectroscopist for your wedding, but the quality of the spectra you get is worth it.

item.title: Brassica
item.description: [#2827] Sequoia Brussels sprouts are delicious but it's pretty hard to finish one.

item.title: Exoplanet Observation
item.description: [#2828] NASA prefers to say that their rovers are 'looking for signs of past life on Mars' and not 'ghost hunting.'

item.title: Iceberg Efficiency
item.description: [#2829] Our experimental aerogel iceberg with helium pockets manages true 100% efficiency, barely touching the water, and it can even lift off of the surface and fly to more efficiently pursue fleeing hubristic liners.

item.title: Haunted House
item.description: [#2830] You can leave at any time through the door over there. It's a Louisville door, so you'll need to find a compatible knob. No, don't be silly, that one is a Lexington knob! Of course it won't fit.

item.title: xkcd Phone Flip
item.description: [#2831] Theranos partnership: Sorry, we know, but we signed the contract back before all the stuff and the lawyers say we can't back out, so just try to keep your finger away from the bottom of the phone.

item.title: Urban Planning Opinion Progression
item.description: [#2832] If they're going to make people ride bikes and scooters in traffic, then it should at LEAST be legal to do the Snow Crash thing where you use a hook-shot-style harpoon to catch free rides from cars.

item.title: Lying
item.description: [#2833] I was, at least at the start of this disastrous game night, your friend.

item.title: Book Podcasts
item.description: [#2834] I've been working my way through this 1950s podcast by someone named John Tolkien called 'Lord of the Rings'--it's a deep dive into this fictional world he created. Good stuff, really bingeable!

item.title: Factorial Numbers
item.description: [#2835] So what do we do when we get to base 10? Do we use A, B, C, etc? No: Numbers larger than about 3.6 million are simply illegal.

item.title: A Halloween Carol
item.description: [#2836] [after a minute] "Okay, I think I've got it, thanks. Can I--" "oOOOooOOooo!"

item.title: Odyssey
item.description: [#2837] Ugh, it says they attempted delivery but "Nobody was home."

item.title: Dubious Islands
item.description: [#2838] Running for office in Minnesota on the single-issue platform 'dig a permanent channel through the Traverse Gap because it will make this map more satisfying.'

item.title: Language Acquisition
item.description: [#2839] My first words were 'These were my first words; what were yours?'

item.title: Earth Layers
item.description: [#2840] The Earth's magnetic field is primarily generated by currents in the liquid outer core, though some geophysicists argue that an unexplained mismatch with models suggests that the Kinder toy contains a magnet.

item.title: Sign Combo
item.description: [#2841] Speed Limit: 45 MPH / Minimum: 65 MPH

item.title: Inspiraling Roundabout
item.description: [#2842] Look, I just think we need to stop coddling those hedonistic roundabout hogs who get into the inner lane and circle for hours, wasting valuable capacity.

item.title: Professional Oaths
item.description: [#2843] Interpretations of the Hermeneutic Oath differ.

item.title: Black Holes vs Regular Holes
item.description: [#2844] Created by the collapse of: [massive stars] [Florida limestone bedrock]

item.title: Extinction Mechanisms
item.description: [#2845] The Late Heavy Bombardment was followed a few billion years later by the Comparatively Light but Oddly Specific Bombardment.

item.title: Daylight Saving Choice
item.description: [#2846] I average out the spring and fall changes and just set my clocks 39 minutes ahead year-round.

item.title: Dendrochronology
item.description: [#2847] These anomalies are known as Miyake events, named for the pioneering scientist who discovered them and was tragically devoured by a carnivorous tree.

item.title: Breaker Box
item.description: [#2848] Any electrician will warn you to first locate and flip the house's CAUSALITY circuit breaker before touching the CIRCUIT BREAKERS one.

item.title: Under the Stars
item.description: [#2849] If you live in Los Angeles (around 3352'N, roughly the latitude of Hermosa Beach) the black hole in V404 Cygni passes over you each day. On Christmas Day it will be directly overhead around 2pm.

item.title: Doctor's Office
item.description: [#2850] "The police told me I can't be a doctor, but whenever they show up I just go into the Google Maps settings page I found and change the house to 'Police Headquarters' and then they have to do what I say."

item.title: Messier Objects
item.description: [#2851] The debate over the correct Messier number for the Ship of Theseus is ongoing.

item.title: Parameterball
item.description: [#2852] The ball's density also varies, but players don't learn the value until after choosing their raquets. The infamous 'bowling ball table tennis' region of the parameter space often leads to equipment damage.

item.title: Redshift
item.description: [#2853] So do you have any plans for z=-0.000000000000045?

item.title: Date Line
item.description: [#2854] They estimate the rocket should be free by approximately ... uh ... well, in about two hours.

item.title: Empiricism
item.description: [#2855] The problems started with my resolution next year to reject temporal causality.

item.title: Materials Scientists
item.description: [#2856] If a materials scientist gives you a present, always ask whether regifting will incur any requirements for Federal paperwork.

item.title: Rebuttals
item.description: [#2857] The mainstream dogma sparked a wave of dogmatic revisionism, and this revisionist mainstream dogmatism has now given way to a more rematic mainvisionist dogstream.

item.title: Thanksgiving Arguments
item.description: [#2858] An occasional source of mild Thanksgiving tension in my family is that my mother is a die-hard fan of The Core (2003), and various family members sometimes have differing levels of enthusiasm for her annual tradition of watching it.

item.title: Oceanography Gift
item.description: [#2859] Shipping times vary. Same-ocean delivery may only take a few years, but delivery from the Weddell Sea in Antarctica may take multiple decades, and molecules meant for inland seas like the Mediterranean may be returned as undeliverable by surface currents.

item.title: Decay Modes
item.description: [#2860] Unlike an Iron Age collapse, a Bronze Age collapse releases energy, since copper and tin are past the iron peak on the curve of binding energy.

item.title: X Value
item.description: [#2861] The value of n is still unknown, but new results constrain it to fall between 8 and 10^500, ruling out popular 'n=1' and 'n=2' theories.

item.title: Typical Seating Chart
item.description: [#2862] Now that airlines have started adding wheel locks to their drink carts, less than half of flights have one accidentally fall out through the hole.

item.title: Space Typography
item.description: [#2863] And over heeee[...]eeeere (i)s Saturn.

item.title: Compact Graphs
item.description: [#2864] People may complain about readability, but even with jpeg compression, extracting the data points is usually computationally feasible if there aren't too many of them.

item.title: The Wrong Stuff
item.description: [#2865] The phantom found Edward Everett Hale a century too early; by the time we invented satellites, the specifics of his 'brick moon' proposal were dismissed as science fiction.

item.title: Snow
item.description: [#2866] For someone who has ostensibly outgrown staying up late waiting for Santa, I do spend an awful lot of time refreshing websites to see if packages are here yet.

item.title: DateTime
item.description: [#2867] It's not just time zones and leap seconds. SI seconds on Earth are slower because of relativity, so there are time standards for space stuff (TCB, TGC) that use faster SI seconds than UTC/Unix time. T2 - T1 = [God doesn't know and the Devil isn't telling.]

item.title: Label the States
item.description: [#2868] Even with a blank map, a lot of people can only name 45-50 of the 64 states.

item.title: Puzzles
item.description: [#2869] Why couldn't the amulet have been hidden by Aunt Alice, who understands modern key exchange algorithms?

item.title: Love Songs
item.description: [#2870] The Pia Colada song carves a trajectory across the chart over the course of the song.

item.title: Definitely
item.description: [#2871] A really mean prank you can play on someone who's picky about words is to add a 'definitely->definitively' autocorrect rule to their keyboard.

item.title: Hydrothermal Vents
item.description: [#2872] Benthic Santas weren't even discovered until the 1970s, but many scientists now believe Christmas may have originally developed around hydrothermal vents and only later migrated to the surface.

item.title: Supersymmetry
item.description: [#2873] High-speed collisions at the Baby Park track may support the hypothesis that Daisy is her own evil twin, a theory first suggested by Nintendo in the game Majorana's Mask.

item.title: Iceland
item.description: [#2874] The HVAC bill for installing the Gulf Stream was enormous.
[#2875] It wasn't originally constitutionally required, but presidents who served two terms have traditionally followed George Washington's example and gotten false teeth.

item.title: Range Safety
item.description: [#2876] The Range Mischief Officer has modified the trajectory to add a single random spin somewhere in the flight, but won't tell us where.

item.title: Fever
item.description: [#2877] Hypothermia of below 98.6 K should be treated by leaving the giant molecular cloud and moving to the vicinity of a star.

item.title: Supernova
item.description: [#2878] They're a little cagey about exactly where the crossover point lies relative to the likelihood of devastating effects on the planet.

item.title: Like This One
item.description: [#2879] A lot of sentences undergo startling shifts in mood if you add 'like this one' to the end, but high on the list is 'I'm a neurologist studying dreams.'

item.title: Sheet Bend
item.description: [#2880] A left-handed sheet bend creates a much weaker connection, especially under moderate loads.

item.title: Bug Thread
item.description: [#2881] After some account issues, we've added 6 new people from the beach house rental website support forum.

item.title: Net Rotations
item.description: [#2882] For decades I've been working off the accumulated rotation from one long afternoon on a merry-go-round when I was eight.

item.title: Astronaut Guests
item.description: [#2883] They didn't bring us a gift, but considering the kinetic energy of a bottle of wine at orbital speed, that's probably for the best.

item.title: Log Alignment
item.description: [#2884] A video can have a log scale that's misaligned with both the time AND space axes.

item.title: Spelling
item.description: [#2885] Any time I misspell a word it's just because I have too much integrity to copy answers from the dictionary.

item.title: Fast Radio Bursts
item.description: [#2886] Dr. Petroff has also shown that the Higgs boson signal was actually sparks from someone microwaving grapes, the EHT black hole photo was a frozen bagel someone left in too long, and the LIGO detection was just someone slamming the microwave door too hard.

item.title: Minnesota
item.description: [#2887] In addition to 'squishy', after reviewing my submitted intraplate ground motion data, the National Geodetic Survey has politely asked me to stop using the word 'supple' so often when describing Midwestern states.

item.title: US Survey Foot
item.description: [#2888] Subway refuses to answer my questions about whether it's an International Footlong or a US Survey Footlong. A milligram of sandwich is at stake!

item.title: Greenhouse Effect
item.description: [#2889] Once he had the answer, Arrhenius complained to his friends that he'd "wasted over a full year" doing tedious calculations by hand about "so trifling a matter" as hypothetical CO2 concentrations in far-off eras (quoted in Crawford, 1997).

item.title: Relationship Advice
item.description: [#2890] Good to be a little wary of advice that sounds too much like a self pep talk.

item.title: Log Cabin
item.description: [#2891] I'm sure the building inspectors will approve my design once they finally manage to escape.

item.title: Banana Prices
item.description: [#2892] It's a linear extrapolation, Michael. How big could the error be? 10%?

item.title: Sphere Tastiness
item.description: [#2893] Baseballs do present a challenge to this theory, but I'm convinced we just haven't found the right seasoning.

item.title: Research Account
item.description: [#2894] Focus of your research: EXTREME PETTINESS AND UNWILLINGNESS TO LET ANYTHING GO

item.title: Treasure Chests
item.description: [#2895] [earlier] "Your vintage-style handmade chest business is struggling. But I have a plan."

item.title: Crossword Constructors
item.description: [#2896] Also, we would really appreciate it if you could prominently refer to it as an 'eHit'.

item.title: Light Leap Years
item.description: [#2897] When Pope Gregory XIII briefly shortened the light-year in 1582, it led to navigational chaos and the loss of several Papal starships.

item.title: Orbital Argument
item.description: [#2898] "Some people say light is waves, and some say it's particles, so I bet light is some in-between thing that's both wave and particle depending on how you look at it. Am I right?" "YES, BUT YOU SHOULDN'T BE!"

item.title: Goodhart's Law
item.description: [#2899] [later] I'm pleased to report we're now identifying and replacing hundreds of outdated metrics per hour.

item.title: Call My Cell
item.description: [#2900] 'Hey, can you call my cell?' '...I'm trying, but it says this number is blocked?' 'Ok, thanks, just checking.'

item.title: Geographic Qualifiers
item.description: [#2901] 'Thank you for the loveliest evening I've ever had...' [normal] '...east of the Mississippi.' [instant intrigue!]

item.title: Ice Core
item.description: [#2902] If you find an ash deposition layer from a year in which an eruption destroyed an island that had Camellia sinensis growing on it, you can make a Gone Island Ice_.

item.title: Earth/Venus Venn Diagram
item.description: [#2903] Actually, the fact that Mars is still orbiting safely over here means that it was technically an *Euler* apocalypse, not a Venn one.

item.title: Physics vs. Magic
item.description: [#2904] 'At the stroke of midnight, your brother will be hurtling sideways at an altitude of 150 meters' is a regular physics prediction about your nonmagical trebuchet, whereas 'you are cursed to build a brother-launching trebuchet' falls out of the Lagrangian.

item.title: Supergroup
item.description: [#2905] I love their cover of 1,200 Balloons, Dalmatians, and Miles.

item.title: Earth
item.description: [#2906] Just think of all the countless petty squabbles and misunderstandings, of all the fervent hatreds, over so insignificant a thing as the direction and duration of a rocket engine firing.

item.title: Schwa
item.description: [#2907] Doug's cousin, the one from London, runs a Bumble love cult.

item.title: Moon Armor Index
item.description: [#2908] Astronomers are a little unsure of the applicability of this index, but NASA's Planetary Protection Officer is all in favor.

item.title: Moon Landing Mission Profiles
item.description: [#2909] If you pick a low enough orbit, it gives you a lot of freedom to use a lightweight launch vehicle such as a stepladder.

item.title: The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald
item.description: [#2910] You know that asteroid that almost destroyed Earth in the 90s? Turns out the whole thing was secretly created by Michael Bay, who then PAID Bruce Willis and Ben Affleck to look heroic while blowing it up!

item.title: Greenland Size
item.description: [#2911] The Mercator projection drastically distorts the size of almost every area of land except a small ring around the North and South Poles.

item.title: Cursive Letters
item.description: [#2912] , .

item.title: Periodic Table Regions
item.description: [#2913] Cesium-133, let it be. Cesium-134, let it be even more.

item.title: Eclipse Coolness
item.description: [#2914] A partial eclipse is like a cool sunset. A total eclipse is like someone broke the sky.

item.title: Eclipse Clouds
item.description: [#2915] The rare compound solar-lunar-nephelogical eclipse

item.title: Machine
item.description: [#2916] The Credible Machine

item.title: Types of Eclipse Photo
item.description: [#2917] The most rare, top-tier eclipse photo would be the Solar Earth Eclipse, but the Apollo 12 crew's attempt to capture it was marred by camera shake. They said it looked spectacular, though.

item.title: Tick Marks
item.description: [#2918] If you're really savvy, you can hide an entire set of illicit transactions by timing them to draw what looks like a graph inset.

item.title: Sitting in a Tree
item.description: [#2919] First comes blood / Then we perish / Then comes Death in his Eternity Carriage.

item.title: Survey Marker
item.description: [#2920] Fun fact: The standard North American NAD83 coordinate system is misaligned from the actual Earth, off-center by about 7 feet. Someone knows where I am, and I'm in the wrong place.

item.title: Eclipse Path Maps
item.description: [#2921] Okay, this eclipse will only be visible from the Arctic in February 2063, when the sun is below the horizon, BUT if we get lucky and a gigantic chasm opens in the Earth in just the right spot...

item.title: Pub Trivia
item.description: [#2922] Bonus question: Where is London located? (a) The British Isles (b) Great Britain and Northern Ireland (c) The UK (d) Europe (or 'the EU') (e) Greater London

item.title: Scary Triangles
item.description: [#2923] Concealed mostly beneath the surface, sharks are the icebergs of the sea.

item.title: Pendulum Types
item.description: [#2924] The creepy fingers that grow from a vibrating cornstarch-water mix can be modeled as a chain of inverted vertical pendulums (DOI:10.1039/c4sm00265b) and are believed to be the fingers of Maxwell's Demon trying to push through into our universe.

item.title: Earth Formation Site
item.description: [#2925] It's not far from the sign marking the exact latitude and longitude of the Earth's core.

item.title: Doppler Effect
item.description: [#2926] The Doppler effect is a mysterious wavelength-shifting phenomenon which seems to primarily affect sirens, which is why the emoji is red.

item.title: Alphabetical Cartogram
item.description: [#2927] Poor Weeoming.

item.title: Software Testing Day
item.description: [#2928] The company tried to document how often employees were celebrating Software Testing Day, but their recordkeeping system kept mysteriously crashing.

item.title: Good and Bad Ideas
item.description: [#2929] While it seemed like a fun prank at the time, I realize my prank fire extinguishers full of leaded gasoline were a mistake.

item.title: Google Solar Cycle
item.description: [#2930] From Google Trends, it looks like the lag between people Googling cocktail recipes and 'hangover cure' is 14 hours.

item.title: Chasing
item.description: [#2931] Certain hybrid events can only happen in certain locations where all the conditions are present; chasers flock to the area in and around Kansas known as tumbleweed-colliding-with-possum alley.

item.title: Driving PSA
item.description: [#2932] This PSA brought to you by several would-be assassins who tried to wave me in front of speeding cars in the last month and who will have to try harder next time.

item.title: Elementary Physics Paths
item.description: [#2933] ==COSMOLOGY==> 'Uhhh ... how sure are we that everything is made of these?'

item.title: Bloom Filter
item.description: [#2934] Sometimes, you can tell Bloom filters are the wrong tool for the job, but when they're the right one you can never be sure.

item.title: Ocean Loop
item.description: [#2935] I can't believe they wouldn't even let me hold a vote among the passengers about whether to try the loop.

item.title: Exponential Growth
item.description: [#2936] Karpov's construction of a series of increasingly large rice cookers led to a protracted deadlock, but exponential growth won in the end.

item.title: Room Code
item.description: [#2937] Sorry to make you memorize this random string of digits. If it helps, it can also double as a mnemonic for remembering your young relatives' birthdays, if they happened to have been born on February 5th, 2018.

item.title: Local Group
item.description: [#2938] Cosmologists estimate the spaghetti strand to be about 200 septillion calories, though it could be higher depending on the nutritional value of dark matter.

item.title: Complexity Analysis
item.description: [#2939] PERPETUALLY OPTIMISTIC CASE: Early in the execution, our research group makes a breakthrough on proving P=NP.

item.title: Modes of Transportation
item.description: [#2940] My bold criticism might anger the hot air balloon people, which would be a real concern if any of them lived along a very narrow line directly upwind of me.

item.title: Cell Organelles
item.description: [#2941] It's believed that Golgi was originally an independent organism who was eventually absorbed into our cells, where he began work on his Apparatus.

item.title: Fluid Speech
item.description: [#2942] Thank you to linguist Gretchen McCulloch for teaching me about phonetic assimilation, and for teaching me that if you stand around in public reading texts from a linguist and murmuring example phrases to yourself, people will eventually ask if you're okay.

item.title: Unsolved Chemistry Problems
item.description: [#2943] I'm an H denier, in that I refuse to consider loose protons to be real hydrogen, so I personally believe it stands for 'pretend'.

item.title: Magnet Fishing
item.description: [#2944] The ten-way tie was judged a ten-way tie, so no one won the grand prize, a rare fishing monopole.

item.title: Broken Model
item.description: [#2945] In addition to eating foxes, rabbits can eat grass. The grass also eats foxes. Our equations chart the contours of Fox Hell.

item.title: 1.2 Kilofives
item.description: [#2946] 'Oh yeah? Give me 50 milliscore reasons why I should stop.'

item.title: Pascal's Wager Triangle
item.description: [#2947] In contrast to Pascal's Wager Triangle, Pascal's Triangle Wager argues that maybe God wants you to draw a triangle of numbers where each one is the sum of the two numbers above it, so you probably should, just in case.

item.title: Electric vs Gas
item.description: [#2948] An idling gas engine may be annoyingly loud, but that's the price you pay for having WAY less torque available at a standstill.

item.title: Network Configuration
item.description: [#2949] If you repeatedly rerun the development of technological civilization, it turns out that for some reason the only constant is that there is always a networking utility called 'netcat', though it does a different thing in each one.

item.title: Situation
item.description: [#2950] We're right under the flight path for the scheduled orbital launch, but don't worry--it's too cold out for the rockets to operate safely, so I'm sure they'll postpone.

item.title: Bad Map Projection: Exterior Kansas
item.description: [#2951] Although Kansas is widely thought to contain the geographic center of the contiguous 48 states, topologists now believe that it's actually their outer edge.

item.title: Routine Maintenance
item.description: [#2952] The worst was the time they accidentally held the can upside down and froze all the Earth's magma chambers solid.

item.title: Alien Theories
item.description: [#2953] They originally came here to try to investigate our chemtrail technology, and got increasingly frustrated when all their samples turned out to just be water ice with trace amounts of jet exhaust.

item.title: Bracket Symbols
item.description: [#2954] "" means "I edited this text on both my phone and my laptop before sending it"

item.title: Pole Vault
item.description: [#2955] Ugh, and we JUST went through this yesterday with javelin.

item.title: Number Line Branch
item.description: [#2956] Attention all passengers: This is an express sequence to infinity. If your stop is not a power of two, please disembark now.

item.title: A Crossword Puzzle
item.description: [#2957] Hint: If you ever encounter this puzzle in a crossword app, just [term for someone with a competitive and high-achieving personality].

item.title: Hatchery
item.description: [#2958] Anadromous fish are more vulnerable in rivers, since the lack of salt means you can quickly crack passwords using rainbow trout tables.

item.title: Beam of Light
item.description: [#2959] Einstein's theories solved a longstanding mystery about Mercury: Why it gets so hot. "It's because," he pointed out, "the sun is right there."

item.title: Organ Meanings
item.description: [#2960] IMO the thymus is one of the coolest organs and we should really use it in metaphors more.

item.title: CrowdStrike
item.description: [#2961] We were going to try swordfighting, but all my compiling is on hold.

item.title: President Venn Diagram
item.description: [#2962] Hard to imagine political rhetoric more microtargeted at me than 'I love Venn diagrams. I really do, I love Venn diagrams. It's just something about those three circles.'

item.title: House Inputs and Outputs
item.description: [#2963] People think power over ethernet is so great, and yet when I try to do water over ethernet everyone yells at me.

item.title: Olympic Sports
item.description: [#2964] Thankfully for everyone involved, the Winter Olympics officials spotted me and managed to stop me before I got to the ski jump.

item.title: Chili Tornado Quake
item.description: [#2965] Buildings constructed from softer materials were damaged by chili pepper impacts to the storm's high Richter-Fujita-Scoville-Mohs hardness rating.

item.title: Exam Numbers
item.description: [#2966] Calligraphy exam: Write down the number 37, spelled out, nicely.

item.title: Matter
item.description: [#2967] He was the first person to land a 900, which is especially impressive because pulling off a half-integer spin requires obeying Fermi-Dirac statistics.

item.title: University Age
item.description: [#2968] This only makes it more urgent that we adopt my roadmap for the next 10 years, which should put us solidly in the lead.

item.title: Vice President First Names
item.description: [#2969] [Political pundit on the ScrabbleTV News channel] "After four years of defying orthographic pressure, Joe ceded the top of the ticket to Kamala, who--after considering Josh, Mark, Andy, Roy, and Pete--picked Tim."

item.title: Meteor Shower PSA
item.description: [#2970] If you hold the meteor too long, it may imprint on you and form a contact binary, making reintroduction to space difficult.

item.title: Celestial Event
item.description: [#2971] If we can get a brood of 13-year cicadas going, we might have a chance at making this happen before the oceans evaporate under the expanding sun.

item.title: Helium Synthesis
item.description: [#2972] Our lawyers were worried because it turns out the company inherits its debt from the parent universe, but luckily cosmic inflation reduced it to nearly zero.

item.title: Ferris Wheels
item.description: [#2973] They left the belt drive in place but switched which wheel was powered, so people could choose between a regular ride, a long ride, and a REALLY long ride.

item.title: Storage Tanks
item.description: [#2974] We're considering installing a pressurization system to keep the tanks at constant pressure solely to deter them.

item.title: Classical Periodic Table
item.description: [#2975] Personally I think mercury is more of a 'wet earth' hybrid element.

item.title: Time Traveler Causes of Death
item.description: [#2976] Many a hungry time traveler has Googled 'trilobites shellfish allergy' only to find their carrier had no coverage in the Ordovician.

item.title: Three Kinds of Research
item.description: [#2977] The secret fourth kind is 'we applied a standard theory to their map of every tree and got some suspicious results.'

item.title: Stranded
item.description: [#2978] At least they're not alone down there.

item.title: Sky Alarm
item.description: [#2979] During the day it also activates for neat clouds and pretty sunsets.

item.title: Lava Lakes
item.description: [#2980] Hey, golf balls float on lava, so this should make recovering them from the hazards easier.

item.title: Slingshots
item.description: [#2981] In my reboot, Dennis the Menace was just trying to send Mr. Wilson a nice comet, but accidentally wiped out his dinosaur garden.

item.title: Water Filtration
item.description: [#2982] You'd think the most expensive part would be the quark-gluon plasma chamber, but it's actually usually the tube to the top of the atmosphere to carry the cosmic rays down.

item.title: Monocaster
item.description: [#2983] My competitors say the tiny single tiny caster is unsafe, unstable, and offers no advantages over traditional designs, to which I say: wow, why are you guys so mean? I thought we were friends!

item.title: Asteroid News
item.description: [#2984] Their calculations show it will 'pass within the distance of the moon' but that it 'will not hit the moon, so what's the point?'

item.title: Craters
item.description: [#2985] It's annoying that the Nastapoka Arc isn't a meteor impact crater, but I truly believe that--with enough time, effort, and determination--we could make it one.

item.title: Every Scientific Field
item.description: [#2986] Conveniently for everyone, it turns out that dark energy is produced by subterranean parasitoid wasps.

item.title: Tectonic Surfing
item.description: [#2987] The worst is when you wipe out in the barrel and you're trapped for several million years until erosion frees you.

item.title: Maslow's Pyramid
item.description: [#2988] The local police, building inspector, and fire marshal are all contesting my 'safety' assertion, or would be if they could reach me past all the traps.

item.title: Physics Lab Thermostat
item.description: [#2989] Hopefully the HVAC people set it to only affect the AIR in the room.

item.title: Late Cenozoic
item.description: [#2990] Our nucleic acid recovery techinques found a great deal of homo sapiens DNA incorporated into the fossils, particularly the ones containing high levels of resin, leading to the theory that these dinosaurs preyed on the once-dominant primates.

item.title: Beamsplitters
item.description: [#2991] Under quantum tax law, photons sent through a beamsplitter don't actually choose which path they took, or incur a tax burden, until their wavefunction collapses when the power is sold.

item.title: UK Coal
item.description: [#2992] The Watership Down rabbits removed an additional 0.1 nanometers constructing their warren, although that was mostly soil. British rabbits have historically mined very little coal; the sole rabbit-run coal plant was shut down in the 1990s.

item.title: Ingredients
item.description: [#2993] Add main-belt asteroids to taste.

item.title: Nmenor Margaritaville
item.description: [#2994] I see white shores, and beyond it, a far green country under a tequila sunrise.

item.title: University Commas
item.description: [#2995] The distinctive 'UCLA comma' and 'Michigan comma' are a long string of commas at the start and end of the sentence respectively.

item.title: CIDABM
item.description: [#2996] There's a heated debate over whether the big island of Tierra del Fuego should qualify for membership.

item.title: Solar Protons
item.description: [#2997] If any of you want to meet some cool local oxygen atoms, I can introduce you!

item.title: Ravioli-Shaped Objects
item.description: [#2998] It's a real accomplishment to mess up a ravioli recipe badly enough that the resulting incident touches all four quadrants of the NFPA hazard diamond.

item.title: Bad Map Projection: The United Stralia
item.description: [#2999] This projection distorts both area and direction, but preserves Melbourne.

item.title: Experimental Astrophysics
item.description: [#3000] Our experiment will be expensive, but we believe it will produce important spin-offs, especially if we manage to hit the sun from the right angle.

item.title: Temperature Scales
item.description: [#3001] In my new scale, X, 0 is Earths' record lowest surface temperature, 50 is the global average, and 100 is the record highest, with a linear scale between each point and adjustment every year as needed.

item.title: RNAWorld
item.description: [#3002] Disney lore: Canonically, because of how Elsa's abiogenesis powers work, Olaf is an RNA-only organism.

item.title: Sandwich Helix
item.description: [#3003] The number one rule of string manipulation is that youve got to specify your encodings.

item.title: Wells
item.description: [#3004] You do have to be careful, though--sometimes, instead of water, you hit this free fuel that you can sell for a lot of money instead.

item.title: Disposal
item.description: [#3005] We were disappointed that the rocket didn't make a THOOOONK noise when it went into the tube, but we're setting up big loudspeakers for future launches to add the sound effect.

item.title: Demons
item.description: [#3006] Though they do appreciate how much he improved the heating system for the flame pit.

item.title: Probabilistic Uncertainty
item.description: [#3007] "One popular strategy is to enter an emotional spiral. Could that be the right approach? We contacted several researchers who are experts in emotional spirals to ask them, but none of them were in a state to speak with us."

item.title: Proterozoic Rocks
item.description: [#3008] These rocks are from a time before eyes, brains, and bones, pieces of a land warmed by an unseen sun.

item.title: Number Shortage
item.description: [#3009] "10 minutes ago we were down to only 2 0s!" "How many do we have now?" "I ... don't know!!"

item.title: Geometriphylogenetics
item.description: [#3010] There's a maximum likelihood that I'm doing phylogenetics wrong.

item.title: Europa Clipper
item.description: [#3011] They had BETTER make this a sample return mission.

item.title: The Future of Orion
item.description: [#3012] Dinosaur Cosmics

item.title: Kedging Cannon
item.description: [#3013] The real key was inventing the windmill-powered winch.

item.title: Arizona Chess
item.description: [#3014] Sometimes, you have to sacrifice pieces to gain the advantage. Sometimes, to advance ... you have to fall back.

item.title: D&D Combinatorics
item.description: [#3015] Look, you can't complain about this after giving us so many scenarios involving N locked chests and M unlabeled keys.

item.title: Cold Air
item.description: [#3016] We also should really have checked that the old water tower was disconnected from the water system before we started filling it with compressed air.

item.title: Neutrino Modem
item.description: [#3017] Our sysadmin accidentally won a Nobel Prize while trying to debug neutrino oscillation error correction.

item.title: Second Stage
item.description: [#3018] Hmm, they won't do in-flight delivery, so let's order a new first and second stage to our emergency landing site and then try to touch down on top of them to save time.

item.title: Advent Calendar Advent Calendar
item.description: [#3019] The growth rate of items per day may may seem absurd, but it's actually much less than the acceleration in the 12 Days of Christmas song.

item.title: Infinite Armada Chess
item.description: [#3020] Stockfish 16 suggests the unconventional opening 1. RuntimeError: Out of bounds memory access

item.title: Seismologists
item.description: [#3021] And even when they're not distracted, they usually get kicked out for illegal under-the-net 'subduction spikes'.

item.title: Making Tea
item.description: [#3022] No, of course we don't microwave the mug WITH the teabag in it. We microwave the teabag separately.

item.title: The Maritime Approximation
item.description: [#3023] It works because a nautical mile is based on a degree of latitude, and the Earth (e) is a circle.

item.title: METAR
item.description: [#3024] In the aviation world, they don't use AM/PM times. Instead, all times are assumed to be AM unless they're labeled NOTAM.

item.title: Phase Change
item.description: [#3025] Even when you try to make nice, smooth ice cubes in a freezer, sometimes one of them will shoot out a random ice spike, which physicists ascribe to kiki conservation.

item.title: Linear Sort
item.description: [#3026] The best case is O(n), and the worst case is that someone checks why.

item.title: Exclusion Principle
item.description: [#3027] Fermions are weird about each other in a standoffish way. Integer-spin particles are weird about each other in a 'stand uncomfortably close while talking' kind of way.

item.title: D&D Roll
item.description: [#3028] Under some circumstances, if you throw a D8 and then a D12 at an enemy, thanks to the D8's greater pointiness you actually have to roll a D12 and D8 respectively to determine damage.

item.title: Sun Avoidance
item.description: [#3029] C'mon, ESA Solar Orbiter team, just give the Parker probe a LITTLE nudge at aphelion. Crash it into the sun. Fulfill the dream of Icarus. It is your destiny.

item.title: Lasering Incidents
item.description: [#3030] I still don't know how the police found my compound where I ran an illegal searchlight depot/covert blimp airfield/fireworks testing range.

item.title: Time Capsule Instructions
item.description: [#3031] Inside is a third box, labeled DO NOT OPEN UNLESS YOU ARE IN THE TIME ZONE WHERE YOU OPENED BOTH PREVIOUS BOXES.

item.title: Skew-T Log-P
item.description: [#3032] The most important quantity for meteorologists is of course the product of latent pressure and temperostrophic enthalpy, though 'how nice the weather is' is a close second.

item.title: Origami Black Hole
item.description: [#3033] You may notice the first half of these instructions are similar to the instructions for a working nuclear fusion device. After the first few dozen steps, be sure to press down firmly and fold quickly to overcome fusion pressure.

item.title: Features of Adulthood
item.description: [#3034] I don't dig pit traps and cover them with sticks and a thin layer of leaves nearly as much as I expected; I find a chance to do it barely once a month.

item.title: Trimix
item.description: [#3035] You don't want the nitrogen percentage to be too high or you run the risk of eutrophication.

item.title: Chess Zoo
item.description: [#3036] The zoo takes special care to keep kings separated from opposite-color pieces as part of their conservation program to prevent mating in captivity.

item.title: Radon
item.description: [#3037] A good Umbrella policy should cover it.

item.title: Uncanceled Units
item.description: [#3038] Speed limit c arcminutes^2 per steradian

item.title: Human Altitude
item.description: [#3039] I wonder what surviving human held the record before balloons (excluding edge cases like jumping gaps on a mountain bridge). Probably it was someone falling from a cliff into snow or water, but maybe it involved something weird like a gunpowder explosion or volcano.

item.title: Chemical Formulas
item.description: [#3040] Can you pass the nackle?

item.title: Unit Circle
item.description: [#3041] They're continuing to search for a square with the same area as the circle, as efforts to construct one have run into difficulties.

item.title: T. Rex Evolution
item.description: [#3042] Unfortunately, body size and bite force continue to increase.

item.title: Muons
item.description: [#3043] Update: I've been banned from the physics department for the way I pronounce "Doppler effect."

item.title: Humidifier Review
item.description: [#3044] They should add a little sticker that certifies that the humidifier supports water conservation, but in the sense of energy conservation or momentum conservation.

item.title: AlphaMove
item.description: [#3045] It struggles a little with complex positions, like when there are an even number of moves and it has to round down, but when run against itself it's capable of finding some novelties. At one point I saw six knights on the board at once; Stockfish rarely exceeds four.

item.title: Stromatolites
item.description: [#3046] If only my ancestors had been fortunate enough to marry into the branch of the bacteria family that could photosynthesize, like all my little green cousins here.

item.title: Rotary Tool
item.description: [#3047] It was great until my thumb slipped and I accidentally launched my telescope into the air at Mach 8.

item.title: Suspension Bridge
item.description: [#3048] As a first step, they can put in a secondary deck, to help drivers try it out and find out how fun the jumps are. After a while no one will use the old flat deck and they can remove it.

item.title: Incoming Asteroid
item.description: [#3049] The bottom ones are also potentially bad news for any other planets in our solar system that have been counting on Earth having a stable orbit.

item.title: Atom
item.description: [#3050] What's weirder is that muons turned out to be INCREDIBLY cute.

item.title: Hardwood
item.description: [#3051] They may technically have been softwoods at some point, but they definitely aren't now.

item.title: Archive Request
item.description: [#3052] They just want researchers in the enclosure to feel enriched and stimulated. ('The Enclosure' is what archivists call the shadowy world outside their archives in which so many people are trapped.)

item.title: KM3NeT
item.description: [#3053] Unfortunately, KM3NeT led to the discovery of the Pauli anglerfish, which emits Cherenkov radiation to prey on neutrino researchers.

item.title: Scream Cipher
item.description: [#3054] AAAAAA A AAAAA AAAAAAA AAAAAAA!

item.title: Giants
item.description: [#3055] I can't get over the suspicion that all those viral pictures are photoshopped and 'Flemish' belongs in the lower right circle.

item.title: RNA
item.description: [#3056] 2040s: RNA formed the basis for life each of the five known times it arose on the early Earth.

item.title: Excusing Yourself
item.description: [#3057] The most awkward part is when you have to pause to put on your shoes before you continue rolling out the door.

item.title: Tall Structures
item.description: [#3058] Briefly set a new record for tallest human-made structure by getting my knit sweater snagged on the skydiving plane door as I jumped and not noticing until I'd landed.

item.title: Water Damage
item.description: [#3059] Your homeowner's insurance might cover it, but be sure to check the subductible.

item.title: Omniroll
item.description: [#3060] It seems wrong that Fruit by the Foot is only sold by weight or by number of rolls.

item.title: Water Balloons
item.description: [#3061] Update: The physics department has recruited an astronomer who studies meteor fireballs.

item.title: Off By One
item.description: [#3062] It does come at the small cost of a LOT more off-by-40-or-50 errors.

item.title: Planet Definitions
item.description: [#3063] Under the 'has cleared its orbital neighborhood' and 'fuses hydrogen into helium' definitions, thanks to human activities Earth technically no longer qualifies as a planet but DOES count as a star.

item.title: Lungfish
item.description: [#3064] I know having so many base pairs makes rebasing complicated, but you're in Bilateria, so shouldn't you at LEAST be better at using git head?

item.title: Square Units
item.description: [#3065] The biggest I've seen in a published source in the wild is an 80-fold error in a reported distance, which I think came from a series of at least three unit conversions and area/length misinterpretations.

item.title: Cosmic Distance Calibration
item.description: [#3066] This is the biggest breakthrough since astronomers noticed that the little crosshairs around red giant stars starting to burn helium are all the same size.

item.title: SawStart
item.description: [#3067] Unfortunately, SawStart is one-use-only. Once started, the blade cannot be stopped, and must be replaced with a fresh blade while the running one is carefully disposed of.

item.title: Rock Identification
item.description: [#3068] 'Is it worth anything?' 'I dunno, is the answer to that question worth another $5?'

item.title: Terror Bird
item.description: [#3069] There has long been debate about Big Bird's species, with some experts claiming he was a canary, but recent genetic analysis places him firmly in Cariamiformes.

item.title: Orogeny
item.description: [#3070] Most properties can only boast INDOOR heated floors.

item.title: Decay Chain
item.description: [#3071] If you have an old phone in a drawer, and you listen very carefully, you can occasionally hear the occasional tap of an emitted SIM card hitting the side of the drawer as the phone transmutes to a lower-end model.

item.title: Stargazing 4
item.description: [#3072] We haven't actually seen a star fall in since we invented telescopes, but I have a list of ones I'm really hoping are next.

item.title: Tariffs
item.description: [#3073] [later] I don't get why our pizza slices have such terrible reviews; the geotextile-infused sauce gives the toppings incredible slope stability!

item.title: Push Notifications
item.description: [#3074] NOTIFICATION: Now dismissing a head of the Notification Hydra NOTIFICATION: Success! You have dismissed a head of the Notification Hydra!

item.title: Anachronym Challenge
item.description: [#3075] I have to pay with paper money.

item.title: The Roads Both Taken
item.description: [#3076] When you worry that you're missing out on something by not making both choices simultaneously by quantum superposition, that's called phomo.

item.title: de Sitter
item.description: [#3077] Our anti-de Sitter club is small at the moment, but I've started corresponding with the conformal field theory people.

item.title: Anchor Bolts
item.description: [#3078] The biggest expense was installing the mantle ducts to keep the carbonate-silicate cycle operating.

item.title: Air Fact
item.description: [#3079] 'Wow, that must be why you swallow so many of them per year!' 'No, that's spiders. You swallow WAY more ants.'

item.title: Tennis Balls
item.description: [#3080] After initial tests created a series of large holes in the wall of the lab, the higher-power Scanning Tunneling Tennis Ball Microscope project was quickly shut down.

item.title: PhD Timeline
item.description: [#3081] Rmeysa ztrk was grabbed off the street in my town one month ago.

item.title: Chess Position
item.description: [#3082] It's important to learn the moves that take you into the vortex, but it's best not to study vortex itself too closely. Even grandmasters who have built up a tolerance lose the ability to play for a few hours after studying it.

item.title: Jupiter Core
item.description: [#3083] Juno mission data suggests that Jupiter actually contains Matryoshka doll-style nested copies of every other planet in the Solar System.

item.title: Unstoppable Force and Immovable Object
item.description: [#3084] Unstoppable force-carrying particles can't interact with immovable matter by definition.

item.title: About 20 Pounds
item.description: [#3085] In addition to gravity, burritos interact through the strong, weak, and electromagnetic forces, which is believed to be a major contributor to their popularity.

item.title: Globe Safety
item.description: [#3086] Frankly, given their extreme gravitational fields and general instability, even 12-inch globes should probably be banned.

item.title: Pascal's Law
item.description: [#3087] Reductio ad absurdum fails when reality is absurd.

item.title: Deposition
item.description: [#3088] P.S. If you have time travel, come to my birthday party Saturday!

item.title: Modern
item.description: [#3089] Scholars are still debating whether the current period is post-postmodern or neo-contemporary.

item.title: Sail Physics
item.description: [#3090] Turning in other directions can be accomplished by using a magnetized centerboard and ocean currents, since a current flowing through a magnetic field induces a Laplace force.

item.title: Renormalization
item.description: [#3091] Applying renormalization to bullies successfully transformed Pete & Pete's Endless Mike into Finite Mike.

item.title: Baker's Units
item.description: [#3092] 169 is a baker's gross.

item.title: Drafting
item.description: [#3093] A 5% efficiency gain at the cost of a 99% efficiency loss

item.title: Mass Spec
item.description: [#3094] Patients at least found it to be an improvement over Millikan's incredibly messy and unpleasant oil drop suspension procedure.

item.title: Archaea
item.description: [#3095] Under the two-domain system, anyone who punches you is technically an Archaean pathogen.

item.title: Check Engine
item.description: [#3096] They say it's probably safe to keep orbiting for a while, but if it stays on or starts flashing we might have to call someone.

item.title: Bridge Types
item.description: [#3097] Pontoon bridges are just linear open-sided waterbeds.

item.title: Trojan Horse
item.description: [#3098] Ultimately, history would imperfectly record the story of the Foal of Troy.

item.title: Neighbor-Source Heat Pump
item.description: [#3099] The installation of the pipes on the inside of the insulation can be challenging, especially when the neighbor could come home at any minute.

item.title: Alert Sound
item.description: [#3100] With a good battery, the device can easily last for 5 or 10 years, although the walls probably won't.

item.title: Good Science
item.description: [#3101] If you think curiosity without rigor is bad, you should see rigor without curiosity.

item.title: Reading a Big Number
item.description: [#3102] [desperately] Maybe this is from some country where they use commas as decimal points, and also as digit separators after the decimal, and also use random other characters for decoration???

item.title: Exoplanet System
item.description: [#3103] Sure, this exoplanet we discovered may seem hostile to life, but our calculations suggest it's actually in the accretion disc's habitable zone.

item.title: Tukey
item.description: [#3104] Numbers can be tricky. On the day of my 110th birthday, I'll be one day younger than John Tukey was on his.

item.title: Interoperability
item.description: [#3105] We're getting a lot of complaints from commuters who were routed onto a coaster, but the theme park patrons who spent hours stuck on an intercity line are also not happy.

item.title: Farads
item.description: [#3106] 'This HAZMAT container contains radioactive material with activity of one becquerel.' 'So, like, a single banana slice?'

item.title: Weather Balloons
item.description: [#3107] Once you add the balloons into the model, it makes forecasting easier overall--the forecast is always 'cold and dark, with minimal solar-driven convection.'

item.title: Laser Danger
item.description: [#3108] To combat the threat, many airlines are installing wing-mounted spray bottles.

item.title: Dehumidifier
item.description: [#3109] It's important for devices to have internet connectivity so the manufacturer can patch remote exploits.

item.title: Global Ranking
item.description: [#3110] Starting a meta-leaderboard for tracking who holds the record for ranking behind the most distinct people on an online leaderboard.

item.title: Artificial Gravity
item.description: [#3111] Low gravity can cause bone loss, so we're pleased to report that, since we initiated capsule motion, the number of bones in each crew member has been steadily increasing.

item.title: Geology Murder
item.description: [#3112] After determining that his body was full of pipes carrying iron-rich fluid, our current theory is that the dagger-shaped object precipitated within the wound.

item.title: Fix This Sign
item.description: [#3113] We're building on our earlier success getting web developers to pay to change the backslashes in our displayed payment URL to forward slashes.

item.title: Building a Fire
item.description: [#3114] That was quicker than usual! The cabin's sprinkler system often makes it really hard to keep anything lit.

item.title: Unsolved Physics Problems
item.description: [#3115] 'Tin pest' makes more sense to me. Tin just doesn't want to be locked down in a shape like that. I get it. But why would any metal want to grow hair??

item.title: Echo Chamber
item.description: [#3116] This is almost as bad as the time I signed up for a purely partisan fishing expedition.

item.title: Replication Crisis
item.description: [#3117] Maybe encouraging the publication of null results isn't enough--maybe we need a journal devoted to publishing results the study authors find personally annoying.

item.title: iNaturalist Animals and Plants
item.description: [#3118] Washington, DC: Eastern gray squirrel, Amur honeysuckle. Puerto Rico: Crested anole, sea grape. US as a whole: Mallard, eastern poison ivy.

item.title: Flettner Rotor
item.description: [#3119] "And in maritime news, the Coast Guard is on the scene today after an apparent collision between two lighthouses."

item.title: Geologic Periods
item.description: [#3120] Geologists claim it's because the earlier Cenozoic used to be called the Tertiary, but that's just a ruse to hide the secret third geologic period, between the Neogene and the Quaternary, that they won't tell us about.

item.title: Kite Incident
item.description: [#3121] Detectives say the key to tracking down the source of the kites was a large wall map covered in thumbtacks and string. 'It's the first time that method has ever actually worked,' said a spokesperson.

item.title: Bad Map Projection: Interrupted Spheres
item.description: [#3122] During the most recent glacial maximum, it's believed that land bridges extended from the surfaces and connected several of the spheres together.

item.title: Canon
item.description: [#3123] Achilles was a mighty warrior, but his Achilles' heel was his heel.

item.title: Grounded
item.description: [#3124] We should have you at the gate in just under two hours--two and a half if we get pulled over.

item.title: Snake-in-the-Box Problem
item.description: [#3125] Chemistry grad students have been spotted trying to lure campus squirrels into laundry hampers in the hope that it sparks inspiration.

item.title: Disclaimer
item.description: [#3126] You say no human would reply to a forum thread about Tom Bombadil by writing and editing hundreds of words of text, complete with formatting, fancy punctuation, and two separate uses of the word 'delve'. Unfortunately for both of us, you are wrong.

item.title: Where Babies Come From
item.description: [#3127] Historians: Contemporaneous documentation of the initial events is often sparse, and in fact people often get testy and uncooperative when we urge better documentation for the historical record.

item.title: Thread Meeting
item.description: [#3128] Hey, so did you ever finish your video series about Cassie and the caterpillar morph? I loved the first three, but never ... no, sorry, I get it, this isn't the place. Sorry! Sorry.

item.title: Archaeology Research
item.description: [#3129] The academic archaeology establishment is suppressing my breakthroughs because of the disruption it would bring to their prepared-core flake-based toolmaking industry.

item.title: Predicament
item.description: [#3130] I dropped my phone while trying to search, and I tried to unlock it from up here, so can you also search for screen repair places?

item.title: Cesium
item.description: [#3131] Someday I hope to find a way to mess up a recipe so badly that it draws the attention of the International Air Transport Association, the International Mathematical Olympiad, or the NSA.

item.title: Coastline Similarity
item.description: [#3132] Hey! A bunch of the early Cretaceous fossils on each coast seem to have been plagiarized, too!

item.title: Dual Roomba
item.description: [#3133] I tried uploading it to a household appliance porn site I found, but apparently their content is limited to only fans.

item.title: Wavefunction Collapse
item.description: [#3134] Wavefunction collapse is only one interpretation. Under some interpretations, graduate students also have souls.

item.title: Sea Level
item.description: [#3135] They're up there with coral islands, lightning, and caterpillars turning into butterflies.

item.title: Pull
item.description: [#3136] Be careful fighting gravity. If you win, it's a long way down.

item.title: Cursed Number
item.description: [#3137] Another group of mathematicians is working to put an upper bound on the number, although everyone keeps begging them to stop.

item.title: Dimensional Lumber Tape Measure
item.description: [#3138] A person with two watches is never sure what time it is, especially if I got them one of the watches.

item.title: Chess Variant
item.description: [#3139] The draw-by-repetition rule does a good job of keeping players from sliding a tile back and forth repeatedly, but the tiles definitely introduce some weird en passant and castling edge cases.

item.title: Biology Department
item.description: [#3140] Welcome to the Linguistics Department - It has been [2] [DAYS] since someone noticed that the Biology Department sign has a one-day-long singular/plural disagreement after it resets.

item.title: Mantle Model
item.description: [#3141] Mantle plumes explain Hawaii, Yellowstone, Iceland, the East African Rift, the Adirondack uplift, the Permian extinction, the decline of Rome, the DB Cooper hijacking, and the balrog in Moria. Those little hills of sand in your yard are caused by antle plumes.

item.title: <City>-Style Pizza
item.description: [#3142] If you want to see true audacity, do an image search for 'Altoona-style pizza.'

item.title: Question Mark
item.description: [#3143] Although now people will realize three-per-em spacethat all this time I've been using weird medium mathematical spacewhitespace characters in my hair spacehair spacehair spacespeech dot dot dot...

item.title: Phase Changes
item.description: [#3144] People looking for the gaps in our understanding where the meaning of consciousness or free will might hide often turn to quantum uncertainty or infinite cosmologies, as if we don't have breathtakingly complex emergent phenomena right there in our freezers.

item.title: Piercing
item.description: [#3145] Some lava around the piercing site is normal, but keep an eye out for spreading earthquakes and eruptive activity that might indicate rifting.

item.title: Fantastic Four
item.description: [#3146] One perk of being born at 0.88c is that your birthday is over two days long.

item.title: Hiking
item.description: [#3147] Every downhill walk is a waterslide that might have been.

item.title: 100% All Achievements
item.description: [#3148] I'm trying to share my footage of the full run to prove it's not tool-assisted, but the uploader has problems with video lengths of more than a decade.

item.title: Measure Twice, Cut Once
item.description: [#3149] "Measure zero times, cut zero times." --carpenter who has achieved enlightenment and realized the wood is fine where it is

item.title: Ping
item.description: [#3150] Progress on getting shipwrecked sailors to adopt ICMPv6 has been slow.

item.title: Window Screen
item.description: [#3151] The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine or Home Improvement or DIY

item.title: Skateboard
item.description: [#3152] I understand it's hard to do more than 300 feet on these 90-second rush jobs, but with a smaller ramp I'm worried the gee forces will be too high for me to do any tricks.

item.title: Hot Water Balloon
item.description: [#3153] Despite a reputation for safety, the temperatures and surprisingly high pressures make them even more dangerous than the air kind, but the NTSB refuses to investigate accidents because they insist there is no 'transportation' involved.

item.title: Physics Insight
item.description: [#3154] When Galileo dropped two weights from the Leaning Tower of Pisa, they put him in the history books. But when I do it, I get 'detained by security' for 'injuring several tourists.'

item.title: Physics Paths
item.description: [#3155] If nothing else, that reasoning definitely overturns syllogisms.

item.title: Planetary Rings
item.description: [#3156] If you don't know where you are on Earth, the angle of satellite dishes can help constrain your latitude. If some of them are pointing straight up, you're probably near the Equator, right under the ring.

item.title: Emperor Palpatine
item.description: [#3157] Many things about Star Wars were not well planned out, but having a 37-year-old in old-age makeup play the Emperor in Return of the Jedi was such an incredible call.

item.title: Shielding Chart
item.description: [#3158] Sharks can occasionally travel short distances through air when pursuing prey, but their attenuation coefficient is pretty high.

item.title: Continents
item.description: [#3159] The inflection point was probably in late 1966 or 1967, so when Neil Armstrong flew to space on Gemini 8, plate tectonics was not widely accepted, but when he landed on the Moon three years later it was the mainstream consensus.

item.title: Document Forgery
item.description: [#3160] It comes with a certificate of authenticity, which comes with a certificate of authenticity, which comes with a...

item.title: Airspeed
item.description: [#3161] Carefully maneuvering the balloon down a mineshaft in an effort to break the OTHER altitude record

item.title: Heart Mountain
item.description: [#3162] Even geology papers about Heart Mountain are like, "Look, we all agree this 'volcanic gas earthquake hovercraft' thing seems like it can't possibly be right, but..."

item.title: Repair Video
item.description: [#3163] The statue should be in the likeness of whatever sculptor posted the sculpting tool repair video that was most helpful during the installation of the statue.

item.title: Metric Tip
item.description: [#3164] The package weighs 7 kg 9 oz.

item.title: Earthquake Prediction Flowchart
item.description: [#3165] At least people who make religious predictions of the apocalypse have an answer to the question 'Why didn't you predict any of the other ones that happened recently?'

item.title: Big and Little Spoons
item.description: [#3166] Are you the annoying spoon or the sleepy spoon?

item.title: Car Size
item.description: [#3167] 'They really shouldn't let those small cars drive in traffic. I worry I'm going to kill someone if I hit one! They should have to drive on the sidewalk, safely out of the way.'

item.title: Beam Dump
item.description: [#3168] We're adding some industrial flypaper to minimize reflection or scattering of customers who might complain.

item.title: EPIRBs
item.description: [#3169] 'Oh no, the box is drifting out into the harbor!' 'Yeah, I wouldn't worry about losing it.'

item.title: Service Outage
item.description: [#3170] Now, if it were the *Canon* wiki, it's possible to imagine someone with a productivity-related reason for consulting it, but no one's job requires them to read that much about Admiral Daala.

item.title: Geologic Core Sample
item.description: [#3171] If you drill at the right angle and time things perfectly, your core sample can include a section of a rival team's coring equipment.

item.title: Fifteen Years
item.description: [#3172] "Want to feel old?" "Yes."

item.title: Satellite Imagery
item.description: [#3173] Every weekend I take an ATV out into the desert and spend a day tracing a faint "(C) GOOGLE 2009" watermark across the landscape.

item.title: Bridge Clearance
item.description: [#3174] A lot of the highway department's budget goes to adjusting the sign whenever the moon passes directly overhead.

item.title: Website Task Flowchart
item.description: [#3175] Tired of waiting on hold? Use our website to chat with one of our live agents, who are available to produce words at you 24/7!

item.title: Inverted Catenaries
item.description: [#3176] Some tires are marketed as 'all-shape tires,' but if driven in a climate with both inverted catenary falls and triangle falls, they wear out really fast.

item.title: Chessboard Alignment
item.description: [#3177] Luckily, the range is limited by the fact that the square boundary lines follow great circles.

item.title: Hyperacute Interdynamics
item.description: [#3178] Our models fall apart where the three theories overlap; we're unable to predict what happens when a nanometer-sized squirrel eats a grapefruit with the mass of the sun.

item.title: Fishing
item.description: [#3179] 'That's definitely above the catch-and-release size minimum for planetesimals.' 'I'm going to throw it back anyway.'

item.title: Apples
item.description: [#3180] The experimental math department's budget is under scrutiny for how much they've been spending on trains leaving Chicago at 9:00pm traveling at 45 mph.

item.title: Jumping Frog Radius
item.description: [#3181] Earth's r_jf is approximately 1.5 light-days, leading to general relativity's successful prediction that all the frogs in the Solar System should be found collected on the surface of the Earth.

item.title: Telescope Types
item.description: [#3182] I'm trying to buy a gravitational lens for my camera, but I can't tell if the manufacturers are listing comoving focal length or proper focal length.

item.title: Pole Vault Pole
item.description: [#3183] My goal in life is to be personally responsible for at least one sports rule change.

item.title: Funny Numbers
item.description: [#3184] In 1899, people were walking around shouting '23' at each other and laughing, and confused reporters were writing articles trying to figure out what it meant.

item.title: Sauropods
item.description: [#3185] Vertebrae Georg

item.title: Truly Universal Outlet
item.description: [#3186] Building Inspectors HATE This One Weird Trick

item.title: High Altitude Cooking Instructions
item.description: [#3187] 1,300,000-1,400,000 ft: Ask a crew member to show you how to use the ISS food warmer.

item.title: Anyone Else Here
item.description: [#3188] Anyone else watching this Youtube video in 1954? If so, my last trip definitely messed with the timeline.

item.title: Conic Sections
item.description: [#3189] They're not generally used for crewed spacecraft because astronauts HATE going around the corners.

item.title: Tensegrity
item.description: [#3190] Some people argue that the tension and compression in the human skeleton is technically tensegrity, but it's missing the defining characteristic: making people say 'wtf, how is that thing floating?' when they see it.
